Bottle. Pours motor oil black with light head around the edges. Aroma of expresso. Tastes of chocolates with a deep expresso lasting note.
If you like your coffee this is well worth a try, full on flavour. What a well made stout.

Number 500, share with the wife. When I started this thing I didnt think Id be drinking Japanese Espresso Stout, so how great is this? Ive made friends and had much fun. My wife left a card and cash in Cotteridge Wines for me for Fathers Day. Brilliant.

Bottle at Gaasa, june 11th 2013. Black body, big tanned head. Roasty aroma, espresso, chocolate, light vanilla. Lots of coffee in the taste, also dark chocolate, fruits, cream and cardamom. Thick body, dry bitterness, good roasty coffee aftertaste. An excellent beer, and surely the best Ive tasted from Japan ever. Lovely.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer Market Jaffa. Thanks zvikar. Black-colored, not completely opaque, with a light brown head. Nice strong coffee aroma. Bittersweet flavor, a bit acidic, with lots of coffee and a dry roasty finish. Medium-bodied. Very nice.

Black pour with a tan head. Aromas of roasted malts and coffee. The coffee flavor isnt as integrated into the rest of the beer as I would like it to be. It also has a lighter mouthfeel than other coffee stouts Ive had. It just feels a bit weak all around flavor wise. It is smooth and easy to drink Ill give it that but far from a great coffee stout.
Really fuckin good. A little unexpected fizz on my tongue which just helped it linger. Delicious roasted yum.
Mellow, fruity, low acid coffee on the nose. A little more roast wouldnt hurt. The star is the texture, smooth and rich. There is just too much raisin in this for me. Makes it a little cakey.

330ml bottle. Black pour, small milk chocolate head. Taste and aroma are discernibly espresso as opposed to merely coffee, lending an intense espresso bitterness. Really good if you like that sort of thing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On draft at Mead Hall. Pours black with a tan head. Lots of sweet malty flavors, most notably chocolate. Espresso notes were there but much less subtle than expected. Not bad.

Pours an opaque black from the bottle with lots of bubbly tan head that sticks nicely. Aroma of soy, roasted malts, and slight dark chocolate. Taste is not on the coffee, not a whole lot else. A little thin on the mouth, but otherwise not too bad, definitely the best Japanese beer Ive had.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 24.05.2013, 0,35l bottle shared with Palme @ Øltorget, Mathallen:
Nice creamy longlasting head. Aroma is heavy espresso, grass, chili, licorice, caramel, cocoa. Taste is a little flat and watery, strong coffee, caramel, grass, chili, licorice, cocoa. Medium bitterness. Nice one, but the taste doesnt really live up to the aroma.

Draft @ Meadhall, Cambridge, MA. Served in a 10 oz. Hitachino Nest glass. This is a stout I could drink until I cant stand up. Pleasant aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and deep, strong espresso. The smell really leads to the rich flavors. Flavors of rich espresso beans, bitter chocolate, long lingering roasted malts, and some burnt sugar. Medium to full body. The palate is creamy and smooth. I hate to use the tired term feels like velvet but it really is smooth and silky. Coffee stout lovers should seek this out on draft. Dont trust some of the bottles that sit around on the shelves of some beer shops.Get this bad boy fresh, it is delightful!

Appearance: Oily, dark black-brown with a thick coffee-crema coloured head. Head lasts for a good amount of time, and leaves sticky lacing down the glass. 

Aroma: A shot of coffee straight up, followed by some dark chocolate, vanilla, and burnt caramel.

Taste: The first thing that I could taste was a strong, almost creamy, bitterness that quickly dissipated into smooth burnt-caramel / brown-sugar and roasted malt. A very deep and complex palate, but without any of the usual lingering bitterness that espresso stouts often have. This is potentially the best espresso stout that I have tasted yet!

Mouthfeel: Creamy and balanced, with carbonation that matches the style well. Possibly slightly thinner than an Imperial Stout should be, but only if you are thinking about it.

Overall: This is probably the best espresso stout that I have tasted. Where most others leave a lingering sharpness or bitterness on the tongue, this one is very smooth and only traces of espresso remain after swallowing. Creamy and rich, like a good espresso should be, it is quite morish and is one that I will definitely repurchase and introduce to others.

A- deep brown with mahogany edges and a nice light tan head that is sustained. S- bakers chocolate, cocoa and espresso is prevalent with chalk, licorice, vegetable notes and toasted malts making a strong run. M- light palate and airy with a lot of water and virtually no carbonation. T- pretty smile. Heavy espresso and chalk, with some earth and chocolate to follow. Quick drop off in taste afterward. Mostly watery in the middle with some vegetable notes and toasted malts. Ending is once again a mild and pleasant chocolate that slowly fades. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Botella at "home" in Obatake mura, Yamaguchi. Black colour with a nice big creamy brown head leaving a good lacing. Pleasant aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, some dark fruit and bit vanilla. Good filling mouthfeel. Flavour is just so pleasant: lots of roasted malt  with coffee and chocolate along with dark fruit and some vanilla, soft bitterness. Smooth like. I have been looking forward to taste this for some years. Not disappointed at all! Great brew!

A - Dark black-brown with a finger of frothy khaki-chocolate colored head. Fades normal.

S - Roasted chocolate and caramel malts, molasses, roasted coffee, black licorice, touch of vanilla.

T - Dark chocolate and caramel malts, roasted coffee, molasses, black licorice, a touch of vanilla and dark fruit.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a sweet, roasted, and dry finish.

D - Nice coffee stout. Good overall balance.

Aroma is bitter, roasted malt and heavy coffee. Appearance is a deep black, with a light brown half finger head. Taste is somewhat light, deep coffee and roasted malt, no hint of sweetness. Mouthfeel is watery, and a normal carbonation. Overall, I suppose this is what I should expect from a Japanese stout, but it was decent.

Aroma: Burnt / roasted coffee and malts.
Appearance: Almost black, but clear. Only a light head on mine, but nice and creamy.
Taste: Very strong coffee flavours, sour malt undertones, extremely accurate for a coffee influenced stout. Medium bitterness, not as strong as a regular imperial stout, but very suited to match the coffee flavours.
Palate: Surprisingly smooth, carbonation and coffee tones work very well together. Aftertaste of coffee and off-milk.
Overall: An extremely interesting beer, taken for its aim its a pleasure to drink. Recreates the coffee flavour very well. Suprisingly drinkable as well.

Pours a deep black with a collapsing cappucino head. Nice strong aroma of coffee dominates the nose, but some cream and spice also come through. The coffee is more restrained in the mouth but still definitely there, along with some dark caramel and a little pine, with a really pleasant chocolate aftertaste. Its out there, but really good all the same.

Dark black with froffy head that dissipates quickly. Chocolate and coffee aromas with a hint of smoke. Initial flavours of dark chocolate malts lead into a progressive bitterness beginning with coffee working through to strong hop flavours, leaving the beer highly drinkable despite the 7.5% abv. The heavy bitterness doesnt linger, instead returning to the mid level  bitter coffee flavour throughout the long aftertaste with a hint of the smoke detected on the aroma.
Amazingly rich flavoured yet easy to drink version of a Russian imperial stout.

Pours a very dark brown with little light allowed through and a fair tan ring around the glass. Aroma is strong espresso, cocoa, roasted malts, light vanilla, and some light dark fruity notes. Flavour is espresso, dark malts that give a good dry bitterness, a nice sweetness in there, slightly burnt, and cocoa.
Waaaaay too much coffee for me but I can see why many like this beer. One of the 4 or so good beers that Nest actually make.

From a bottle. Pours very dark brown with a light brown creamy head. Tastes like coffee and cocoa, but not an overpowering flavor. Very smooth. Smells like espresso and nutmeg. Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown with thick, creamy tan head; short retention and some lacing. Aroma is roasted and chocolate malts, espresso, cocoa, figs, plums, earthy hops, and light vanilla. Flavor is roast malts forward with supporting dark fruit esters, cocoa, espresso, light ash, and light earthy and spicy hops; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Very brown black, tan sml-med head. Smells.. Malts, coffee and hops, some choc. Tastes..loads of malt, chocolate and good medium coffee flavour more pronounced as it warms, slight bitterness. Nice.

Bottle. Pours black as night with fine, aromatic tan head. Huge coffee and dark chocolate nose. Got some vanilla and fruit as well. Palate thick as, could have eaten it with a spoon. Fantastic stuff, will have to get this more often.

Bottle at Taps Beer Bar, Kuala Lumpur. Poured a dark mahogany with a long lasting frothy tan head and bags of lace. The aroma is dry and peaty with lots of malt. The flavour is rich and bitter with bags of liqourice and roasted coffee.  Its rather hoppy too and a little fruity and spicy on the palate. Its quite a departure from a standard Espresso Stout and very refreshing and drinkable.

Pours deepest black with a finger of creamy looking brown head. Coffee, vanilla and liquorice in the aroma. Coffee, vanilla and bitter chocolate in the flavour. Finishes slightly tart, reminiscent of a coffee aftertaste again mixed with more vanilla. The vanilla flavour is just lovely and natural in this one. Full, thick and coating mouthfeel while remaining quite drinkable. Very nice.
Very strong coffee nose and taste. If you like coffee then you will love this. Roasted malts flavor but a dry after taste. Not bad but ones enough.

Uploading old ratings that were missing comments. Really nice stout with just enough espresso punch to cut through the sweetness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very good. Dark brown with tan head. Aroma of licorice and espresso. Tastes the same with a sweet vanilla start and nicely balanced bitter finish.

I want to love this beer. It might be the best beer Ive had from Asia. That said, there is almost no aroma to speak of, and it very dry. The espresso is dominant, with few other flavors, making for a bit of a simple beer. Short flavor profile, with some currants on the back end.
Bottle.  Great brew with loads of roasted malt and coffee flavor.  I could see coming back to this again and again.

Ive had plenty of coffee stouts, but I cant recall ever having one claiming to be an espresso stout per se. I usually like coffee stouts, so Hitachino Nest Espresso Stout sounded really intriguing. Unfortunately it didnt deliver much in the way of any coffee character and instead drank like a decent Russian Imperial Stout (which is the base style). 

I poured an 11.2oz bottle into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Dark opaque black body, no carbonation or sediment visible. Forms a large, dark tan, foamy/soapy head which retains and laces well.

Smell: Reminiscent of a "foreign extra stout" with notes of black licorice and some dairy. Slight roasty notes but nothing overtly coffee-smelling. Mild overall.

Taste: To be fair, I should disclaim this review by mentioning I was probably drinking an old bottle. Though I havent been able to find a credible source on how to decipher the date on it. An old bottle would probably account for the lack of coffee presence in this beer. Much like the nose theres an FES character to this beer. Black licorice, some currants or dark berries and maybe even a hint of sour grape are quite prominent through the first half. Theres a dry bitterness at the apex which has the bitterness of black coffee, but not the taste. Theres also a distinct tang or metallic off-flavor on the finish and in the aftertaste. Its a noticeable, but tolerable flaw. In the end what youre left with is a pretty standard and enjoyable FES-style brew and thats satisfactory.

Drinkability: Since Hitachino Nest Espresso Stout isnt all that intense of a beer its quite easy to drink. The mouthfeel is a little thin, on the calmer, more tepid end, and it goes down quite smooth. There is a dry bitter aftertaste, though, which might be attributed to the use of espresso beans in the boil. The 7.5% ABV is not noticeable at all as it drinks like something much smaller.

Pours totally black with a light brown head. Aroma is malty, roasted, plenty of coffee of course, dark fruits, chocolate and vanilla. Taste is lightly sweet, quite roasty leading to a medium bitter finish. Great stuff!

pitch black poor with mocha like head all the usual tasty stout flavour coming through with this one with just a little more from the coffee. Feels a bit rough but tasty and enjoyable regardless. Wee bit more awake afterward? Would drink again.

Pours a deep burnt umber color with a traces amount of khaki foam. The nose is roasty and full of deep coffee notes and a touch of molasses sweetness. The palate is bubbly yet full and rich. Nice robust flavor and balance between sweet chocolate, burnt sugar, roasted dark malt and a well integrated blend of rich espresso and dark fruit.
Slight mocha aroma. Taste is sweet and bitter coffee with some choc in there. Almost sessionable with a nice caffeine hit. Nothing on the aphrodisiac, but still tasty.

Pours a dark brown.  Light, thinner in body than I expected, with virtually no head; very strong coffee flavor--almost more coffee than beer. If youre not a coffee enthusiast but, out of curiosity, would like to try a coffee-infused brew, Id suggest steering away from this one, as you might as well be drinking an alcoholic version of espresso.  However, since I adore coffee--particularly dark, bold roasts--this one appealed to me.

I was a little disappointed with this one. I like coffee flavored stouts but the coffee flavor was way too strong. It overpowered the beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Strong coffee aroma, Overpowers everything else. Dark black. Nice head, but fades quickly.  very tasty bitter dark chocolate and coffee flavor.  almost to bitter to have with a meal, but thin enough texture.  A nice stout.

caramel, roasty, chocolate, coffee, vanilla.
Come ci si può aspettare dal nome, il gusto di caffè domina sugli altri aromi. Forse un po troppo. Ottima al palato. Classico colore stout, corposa.In generale una discreta stout.

Refrigerated 11.2 oz. brown bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours black with medium dark brown hightlights with medium light brown head.  Some thin small bubble lacing, medium body, medium/light carbonation, and light dark chocolate aroma.  Taste is dark chocolate, espresso, herbal hops, some salt, hint of vanilla, and bitter hop finish.  Pretty good.

Bottle fromTMW Sterling - pours pitch was a nice pillowy milk chocolate head. Aroma is complex, chocolate, vanilla, malt, dark fruits, and finally a subtle coffee finish. Taste is sweet with a nice creamy thickness. Overall, a coffee stout that gets it right for once!

Huge aroma of burnt malt and coffee. Black with a fine, dense tan head. Initial sweetness quickly overwhelmed with roasted grain and bitter coffee and cacao. If one likes to mix there coffee with stout this perfectly hits all the right notes - personally I prefer to keep my espresso out of my stout.

Black, with a dark,thick, whipped head.
Scent is vanilla, chocolate, sweet coffee.
Taste is creamy, chocolate and vanilla, again, just more-so.
Roasty, velvety soft.
Rich, just absolutely packed with flavour...
Quite exceptional.

Pours a pitch black color with a nice tan head that lingers a bit.  Aromas are deep roasted malt, espresso, chocolate, vanilla, cream, and a hint of dark fruit.  Taste has a slight sweetness up front but then bitter dark chocolate and roasted malt take over.  Finish leaves a long lingering espresso taste.  Slight vanilla taste in the finish too.  A really nice stout.

Aroma of burnt coffee, licorice, chocolate and vanilla beans.  Pours beautiful black with a big dark brown head.  Taste is super roasty with deep licorice and dark chocolate up front and a creamy chocolate/vanilla coffee towards the end.  Fabulous.

Bottle: Thanks Andrew:
Fucking Gusher lost at least half the bottle of beer on my clothes, telephone, couch, floor and everything in a radius of 1 meter.
This sucks on both ways, less beer and everything is dirty and needs to be cleaned. Unto this beer:
Lovely dark black pour, bigger sized tan head, disappears slowly, on top of a black colored beer.
Smell coffee, brett, lots of chalk, wood, yeast, roast, espresso, light vinous, earth and some chalky barrels.
Taste is creamy and not so high carbonated as I thought it would be, after that damn gusher: lots of bitters, coffee, espresso, yeast, spicy, barley roast, coffee roast, chalk, roasted wood, hint of coal, roasted to slightly burned barley malts, some darker chocolate, coffee beans, darker herbs and spices and a slight hint of dark fruits.
Thick, creamy, bitter and balanced.
Aftertaste is bitter, spicy, roast, espresso, chalk and some barley roast.
Low to lightly more carbo, soft creamy silky mouthfeel, full body and a sticky thick creamy almost oily texture.
If it didnt gush (that bad!) it would have scored a bit higher! But a damn good beer!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
UPDATED: JAN 11, 2014 1/11/14:
Bottle. Pours dark brown with fine tan head, settles quickly with moderate lace. Aroma is roasted, coffee, nutty malt. Flavor is roasted, coffee, toffee, caramel, cocoa. Soft carbonation, medium body, and smooth texture. 

12/13/12:
Pours an opaque dark brown with a finger and a half of light brown head. Settles quickly with minimal lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, and alcohol. Flavor is coffee, cocoa/dark chocolate, roasted malt, caramel. Soft carbonation, medium body, and a smooth mouthfeel. A rich and tasty beer.

Pours black with a thick tan head and plenty of lace. Aroma is chocolate, fruity. Taste is bitter chocolate, roasted malt, coffee and some sweetness. Body is a little thin, slightly dry and sticky with bitter chocolate on the palate.

At just on cool and into a tulip. Viscous, oily pour has a thin tannish pad settle out that is resilient. Below is a blackest ruby body that offers a shimmer when held to the lights. There is a rich Ovaltine, Bovril, Horlicks and Worcestershire mix on the nose with a sickly sweet, creamy, milk chocolate roundness that is continuously wafting. Creamy, powdery smooth body. Big and full with a dry finish that is sharp and obscenely burnt coffee bean bitter on the finish. The chocolate and Ovaltine of the aroma fills out the palate as does a little Worcester late. Quite warming for a 7.5% ABV ale. A vinous astringency develops after a few sips,; works in well. A great stout I must say. Mellowing (coffee?) and very enjoyable to quaff!  (33cL, BBE 08/13, The Beer Store Morley)
Sweet coffee aromas. Coffee, milk and sugar flavors. A little light in color. Overall a very good coffee stout.

Hitachino does it again! Nose is roast, some slight coffee, chocolate, and grain. Pour is deep, dark brown. Nearly black with a vigorous tan head. This is a nicely executed stout with tons of coffee flavor, roast, smooth chocolate notes, and a dry finish. Awesome stuff.

330ml Bottle
Appearance - Murky brown, whopper-candy head
Aroma - Rice vinegar, chocolate, roast
Taste - Coffee, caramel, bitter cocoa

This is a beer Ill buy every time I see it from now on. The coffee flavors are so mellow and soothing to the palate... its as if youre really drinking beer flavored coffee!

Bottle in the Globe, HK. This was fantastic stuff. I often read about beer described as tasting of coffee, and often use the term myself in ratings -  but this one really did taste of coffee. Or to be more precise, the taste you get when you crunch a roasted coffee bean, perhaps with a thin coating of dark chocolate. Aroma malty, ever so slight hint of marmite. Palate a little bit slick. Booze wonderfully concealed. Really good.

Bottle consumed Oct 2012, brought back from trip to Japan in April 2011.  

Accidental aging (in back of beer cupboard) seemed to have brought out vinous notes in it, almost a hint of barrel-aging character. The coffee was muted on the nose, but it was still there subtly in its full-bodied rich roasty flavour  not as much perhaps as a younger version of the beer, but I savoured the increased structure that had come through with time, and the subtle blending of roast malt, coffee, sweetness, wine and oakey tones.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2016 355ml bottle (SBWF2012) (7:5:7:4:15=3.8)
Super rich espresso aroma, great roast. Lovely full body - tons of esters. A good beany espresso. Very burnt roast. Anna says ashy, but I dont get that. A great rich beer.
Rerate: Tap (Pudel, Tallinn) (8-:4:8:4:15-=3.9-)
Kaboom! Lovely fresh coffee, moccamaster with Presidentti, just like what I used to make and love. Black, and a dark tan tight head, nicely persistent. Tons of rich roast, no ashiness this time, lots of dark coffee, just gorgeous. Mouthfeel starts simple, its full, but with the carbonation its nicely light. However, as you swallow something magical happens, a lovely softness and smoothness hugs your tongue, and basically puts a huge smile on your face. Covers the alcohol very well. Finish is heavily burnt, but again not ashy and has great bitter hops. Dang - keg beats bottle this time.
Rerate: Old bottle 1 year past BB
No numbers, no words, just a recommmendation - DO NOT AGE THIS BEER.

Bottle @ SBWF 2012. Very dark brown, almost black color, with nice red hue. Very thin beige head appears, but almost flat. Coffee, roasted malts, cocoa and very faint vanilla in aroma. Roasted, coffee beans, watery, bit minerals in flavor.
Tap at Gingerman, pours jet black and looks and smells delicious.  And luckily it tastes delicious as well.  Tastes of dark fruits, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, earth, light soy sauce, and toast.  Yum

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of sweet roasted malt, vanilla, caramel, raisin, dark fruits, and nougat.  Flavor of the same sweet malt and dark fruits with some roast in the finish but no real espresso flavors.  Good RIS, I guess I would have liked more coffee notes here, but otherwise its quite a tasty brew.
7/4/8/4/14 [3.7/5]
Bottle @ SBWF12. Black colour. Aroma of espresso, thick, taste is more coffee and dark fruits.

Aroma: Smelling coffee and chocolate, soy sauce and licorice.Appearance: A black/brownish brew, a tan head, little lacing and small curtains.Taste: Sweet brown bread, espresso and chocolate chip cookies.Palate: Medium carbonation, soft, a big body, a smooth dry finish.Overall: A really powerful after dinner stout.Note: Bottle at ShinNori. Reviewed 2012-09-29.

5 oz. pour from bottle at Encinitas Ale House in Encinitas, CA.   

Opaque, black brown with tan head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of roast coffee, roast malt, toast and vanilla  

Taste of roast malt, dark roast coffee and brown sugar with a sweet finish.

Medium body and medium carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Pours super dark and thick with moderate head. Great coffee notes to the nose. Thick and heavy on the palate, like a dessert beer. Chocolate notes when you taste it. Interesting...

This beer immediately smells like an espresso shot with hints of chocolate. The correct is dark black with a foamy brown/orangish head. The big bold favor gives it a bit of an oakey taste and finishes with the hint of vanilla. At 7.5% this is a great big beer but it is likely enjoyed best while sipping on it. More flavor comes out the warmer it gets I find the ideal temp is in the 10-12 degree range.

The pour is a thick motor oil black with what seems to be an orange thin head.  The aroma is full of expresso & some faint hints of chocolate. The taste is thick & exploding with expresso in flavor.  A nice sipping dessert beer but certainly not sessionable. Nevertheless, tasty!

Fra flaske på Cardinaltreff  i 2008 (?), fritt etter hukommelsen: en strålende smaksopplevelse som virkelig fikk meg til å tenne på mørke øl med kaffe. Myk og fyldig, nesten som mørk sjokolademousse. Mmmmmersmak!

#3cl botle from Iphonefan 
Thin tan head.  Dark clear pour..  A GREAT BEER :-)  Reminds me of the Emelisse ESPRESSO stout
Poured from a bottle.  Nice coffee and chocolate aroma. Very dark with tab head.  Some red fruits in the taste. Bitter roasted coffee finish. Lovely beer.

Bottle from Whole Foods Roosevelt

Dark pour, yellow-brown head. Molasses, soy, and baking cocoa, rich mouthfeel. Nice, but not an exceptional >7% stout nor at the top of the Hitachino nest lineup.

A-- Poured black. Pretty straight forward there. Decently aggressive pour got a long lasting two finger dark mocha colored head. Lots of lacing on the glass. Thick and streaky. Well maintained head and good head retention. 

S-- Espresso, more like over drawn espresso, chocolate, and roasted malts. A little bit of sweetness that sort of reminds me of Sticky Date Pudding. Just no Carmel sauce.

T-- Big hit of espresso, not real bitter but strong. Chocolate somewhat smooths out the espresso taste. 

M-- Big espresso followed buy chocolate. Chocolate is a tad bit sweetened. Medium to full bodied low carbonation. Chocolate smooths out the espresso. Has bitterness but it is not over bitter.

D-- Good drinkable beer.

A very nice beer... but definitly not worth the price.  There are good espreso stouts like this out there...  Strong cofee with sweetness... at first watery until the palate catches up then very nice. With only a hint of water... Bitter builds a little but not to bad.  Id rather have Austin Beer Works.

Bottle purchased from Mondo Vino, Denver and drank in hotel room (03/06/12) whilst waiting for the other half to get ready !
Black to very dark brown in colouration with a dirty finger of brown head.
Coffee hits the nose allied to a small pinch of chocolate bitterness and a whiff of smoke, maybe a little sour whiff?
In tasting I get a bitter chocolate hit first, then coffee to the finish. Sweet in taste but bitters out to a drier finish. Mouthfeel spot on and carbonation fairly low. Would revisit this one!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottled. Pitch Black coloured. Dense Light brown head. Aroma of coffee, roast, sweetness, Chocolate, cocoa. Flavour of roast, chocolate, coffee, grass. Medium bodied. Roasted bitter coffee end.

Bottle at Neighborhood, San Diego. Clear, deep brown/black liquid with medium tan head. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, espresso, dark fruit, biscuit and cereal. Taste is dry and medium bitter with notes of coffee (espresso), dark fruit and licorice. Medium to full bodied with medium carbonation.

This stuff pours about the same color as strong coffee with orangish highlights around the edges, and it has a small head that fades fast.  The aroma is coffee and strong chocolate with the presence of some hops.  The flavor is very rich chocolate, coffee, and hearty malts.  The finish is very smooth.  This stuff tastes good, but its very rich and fairly simple.  A nice option for dessert, but not something Id drink often.

Pours solid chocolate brown with big tan head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, malt, and caramel. Taste is sweet, but not too much like stouts can often be. Full bodied, creamy, but not too thick. Finish is very mild, almost undetectable. Great stout with solid (but not overwhelming) flavors and balanced palate.

Poured from a bottle into a chalice. Pours a dark brown with a dark brown head of foam. Nice retention. Aroma is all coffee and dark chocolate with just a hint of sweetness. Some roasty notes come throughout as well. Taste is nutty and roasty coffee with some interesting peat notes. Some heat across on the back of the tongue in the finish. Nice coffee stout, thats for sure.

12oz bottle poured into an English Pint. Pours black with a ring of dark tan head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is strongly coffee with a good bit of dark chocolate and some dark fermented fruits. Taste is light bitter. Coffee with chocolate and dark fruits. Medium bodied with a creamy yet somewhat thin texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, not bad. I would gladly drink this again.

Bottle at GBBF2011
DArk brown with a ruby corona. Strong rich fruity coffee nose, thick body. Rich coffee, chocolate, slightly bitter finish. Fantastic coffee beer.

Bottle. Reddish brown with a foamy light tan head. Aroma is big coffee, toffee and some chocolate. Flavor is bitter roast, coffee, sweet caramel and some light alcohol warming. Medium-full body with average carbonation. Great coffee stout.

330ml bottle from mane liquor. Pours a deep tar black with a healthy size tan/brown head. Strong mocha aroma which really hits you from the word go! Staying true with the aroma the taste of mocha really stands out with a mild burnt caramel after taste. Very little carbonation makes this stout go down quicker than youd want it too and just left me wanting for more. Definitely worth a try for any stout fan!
Aromas of dark chocolate, espresso, molasses. Body is thinner than expected. Little bit of espresso. I was slightly disappointed, but its no bad.

Dark coffee brown with a chocolate head with a slight orange hue. Aromas of brownies, chocolate, chocolate pudding, cocoa, coffee. Flavors of brownie, coffee, chocolate, hint of vanilla (but hidden), slight caramel. Roasty, medium sweet, roasted malt aftertaste, lightly bitter, delicious.

Poured almost black, viscous with a small tan head.
Smells of coffee with a bit of sweetness, chocolate?
Tastes of roasted malt, fairly bitter coffee and a bit of cocoa.
The mouth feel is very smooth.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2012 Pours thick and black with mocha head. Sediment throughout. Beautiful. Smells like all things good in this world. Coffee, chocolate, sweetness. Awesome slick palate. Slightly bitter coffee beans balanced perfectly with fruit sweetness. An all around amazing amazing stout. Hard for me to find anything wrong with this.
Medium palate, very dark.  Minimal head and lacing.  Very dark roasted malts and lots of coffee on nose and in taste.  Tasty, but pricey.  Glad I tried it but wont be buying it again.

330ml bottle pours black in color with a big beige head that leaves a few spots of lacing as it settles.  Aroma is dominated by coffee with hints of chocolate and roasted malts.  Taste is also coffee dominant with some chocolate malt sweetness and roasted malt bitterness.  Medium to heavy body with decent carbonation.  As I am not a coffee drinker, I did not enjoy the coffee dominant flavors of this brew.  Although it is a top quality beer, it is just not for me.

Bottle pours opaque fizzy cola black with tan head, somewhat dissipating to a light covering. Big coffee bean aroma mixed with a nice roast, burnt toffee, chocolate and grains. Some light grassy noble hop character and pitted fruits are also apparent. Medium body of nice roast and coffee bean expanding into a big rich body of chocolate and caramel to boost the other key flavours with lingering coffee bean bitter and reflective finish. Average carbonation. Top! top! beer!
Pours a black black color with a thick brown head.  Looks pretty creamy.  Smells of coffee and some chocolate.  Pretty creamy taste.  Nice burnt aftertaste.  Smooth chocolately flavors.

Style et résumé:  Espresso Stout. 
Comment: Bouteille de 341ml nectar partagé par mon ami Patrick. 
Description: Ce stout est brun foncé avec une mousse brune. Le nez a quelque chose dacide, il y a aussi du chocolat et de la vanille. En bouche le liquide a une belle texture. On y retrouve les saveurs de chocolat et de vanille qui étaient présentes au nez. Le café est peu présent malgré quil devrait être le goût dominant. Cette bière manque de fraicheur. 
Note:  6/10

Poured very dark, almost black, with a tall thick and foamy brown head. The aroma was mild with espresso, dark chocolate, licorice and some sweetness from dark fruits. The beer had a thick creamy texture and a smooth initial taste. There was a building coffee flavor with a bit of smokiness there too. The flavor remand on the mild side and finished with a mellow coffee flavor that had some milk chocolate as well. The head left nice thick clingy lacing. The 7.5% ABV was not detected at all. This was very smooth and mellow. I guess with the name Espresso Stout I was thinking more up front coffee and more bitterness, but this was good.

(Via a trade with dresden.  Thanks!)  Un beau regard foncé.  Une mousse beige en anneau.  Un nez de chocolat et de vanille qui me semble être faiblement touché par le café.  En bouche, le café se manifeste davantage.  Des malts doux sempressent de sétendre sur mes papilles.  Un retour inopiné de la vanille et des chocolats bruns.  Un certain goût fruité.  Fermentation?  Levure?  Des malts rôtis qui tendent à développer une certaine âcreté.  Un corps de moyenne densité.  Une texture agréable avec son profil crémeux.  Une effervescence bien présente.  En fin de parcours, des notes maltées qui sont à la remorque de notes torréfiées.  Impossible de savoir si la bouteille est jeune ou vieille.

A nice stout underneath it all - full bodied, roasty, bitter, good. overlaid with heaps of coffee - which is fine - only this coffee isnt very good. husky, ashtray-flavoured and acrid cheap overroasted coffee flavour ruins it. im retrospectively appreciating mikkeller weasel more now.

Pours as black as black could be with a relatively small head. Obvious smells of chocolate and coffee. Taste is dominated by firstly coffee then with chocolate and a hint of vanilla. A great to sip with on a cold night.

Aroma of coffee, chocolate. Black appearance, with frothy brown head. Strong coffee taste, bitter and pleasant. Full bodied.
"I cant believe this is from Japan!" - Doc.
"All the best stuff comes from Japan" - Marty McFly.
including, apparently, this beer.

Please note that Im not a big coffee fan, and this is certainly a coffee-heavy stout. The appearance is black with brown head. Very aromatic coffee aroma. Taste is bitter coffee, dark chocolate, some sweet fruit. Great beer, even though Im not a coffee drinker.

Bottle at BrewDog Camden. It pours jet black, with a thick tan head. The nose is rich espresso coffee, roasted malt, caramel, molasses, burnt sugar and lactose. The taste is salted caramel, espresso, roasted malt, dark fruit (prune, date, blackcurrant...), toffee and lactose, with a long dry-roasted finish. Medium-full body and moderate carbonation. Great coffee character. A tasty beer.
Bottle @ BrewDog. Coffee aroma & flavour. Dark brown colour, not much head. Barbecue aftertaste. Nice & mellow.

Bottle from liquor express. Pours black with two fingers of thick khaki head. A hint of coffee on the nose. Lots of bitterness on the tongue. Slight hint of chocolate and coffee as well. Finish lingers a bit which means this should be drunk after dinner. Not my favorite example of the style.

11.2 oz bottle. My first Japanese brew, Ive been looking forward to this... Black color, nice brown head, some lace. Shared with my mom, she really liked it. Really nice and satisfying espresso aroma. This hits the spot in the same way that FBS does for me. Great, lighter smooth carbonation with an awesome long aftertaste. Nice light bitter and roasty taste. Awesome, satisfying beer. Great to enjoy with some cold rare-cooked steak strips and tomato and avocado that my mom prepared for me as a birthday lunch last week, before an 18 hour drive for a spring break vacation.
12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is of the roasted malt and coffee.  Taste is the same plus bitter chocolate.

33cl bottle. Black colour with a nice formation of tan head, nice lacing and perfect lasting, creamy and frothy. Aroma is toasty with slightly dark coffee notes. Flavour has notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, strong black coffee, toasty and roasty malts. Carbonation is soft. Body is medium to high. Texture is oily.
Lovely, tasty stout with a rich toasted aroma. Very drinkable with a fair smack of chocolate bitterness coupled to a smooth velvety body. One to try again.

Bottle from Bellport Daves.  Pours dark with tan head. Looks like a stout.  Smells like a stout.  A little sharper, perhaps a tad hoppy. Cola and dark coffee. Slightly bitter and black coffee tasting.  Surprisingly good.  Doesnt blow my socks off but its nice. And its nice to have a stout thats not overly soft or sweet or chocolately.  If stouts had a black coffee version, this would be it.  Straightforward.  Will buy more.  Arigato!

From the bottle poured a VERY dark brown brew with a Very dark, thick, brown head. Toasty malt and coffee with a hint of chocolate met mynose and tounge. Medium mouth feel made for a pleasing, but not wonderful tasting esperience.
Bottle. Dark brown with creamy light brown head. Smells sweet like caramel and grassy and brassy. Tastes like chocolate and coffee with a slight lemon hint. Light and dry.

Bottle @ BrewDog Edinburgh 140212
Black with tan white head
Aroma - dark malts.....not much roast...light white wine notes...slightly herbal aromatic notes... bit peppery...hint of rice....unusual aroma for a stout
Taste - light coffee....mellow roasted malts...light white wine...slight sourness...bit of aromatic pepper....some chocolate.
Palate As main flavour...smooth
Overall - A really good stout with a mellow coffee flavour. I really liked this one. Need to try this again.

Black with a decent brown head. some lacing going on. Robust coffee and dark roasted malts on the nose, plus a little soy sauce. Has the taste of very dark roasted malts, sweet dark fruit and coffee. Bitter after taste mainly from the dark roasted malts, but also from some fresh hops as well. Very smooth and silky texture, kinda seductive really. This is a well balanced, not overly coffee flavored stout, but not one of my favorite stouts.

330ml bottle poured into a snifter. Bottle stamped E.8.12 which Im guessing either means it was brewed in December, 2008 or it is best by August, 2012. Im hoping for the latter.

Appearance is pitch black like used motor oil with a tiny dark tan head that quickly fades to a ring around the glass.

Smells quite strongly of espresso and roasted malt with a touch of caramel.

Taste is sweet caramel, coffee, an roasted malt. Much like a caramel mocha. Lots of bitterness from the malt and coffee. There is an earthy quality to this, kind of woody, that is chicory-like in nature. Mouthfeel is silky and smoothe but quite full-bodied.

Overall this is an excellent beer. The coffee is nicely balanced and I really like the earthy quality. One that I would like to have again.

12 oz bottle, split with a friend.  Pours a thick black color, nearly opaque.  Foamy tan head with good lacing.  Aroma was strongly coffee and malt.  Flavor was coffee, roasted malt, and some chocolate.  Had a very nice sour backside as well.  Overall, this was an excellent beer, and Id definitely get it again.

pours jet black, minimal head, quickly dissipating head, ringed retention, small CO2, some sticky-some runny lacing, opaque. Abundant roasted espresso beans on the nose, wow. Fresh roasted coffee 101. Smooth gentle roasted coffee up front, mellowed malts in the mids and a long 6/10 deep coffee bitter finish. Somewhat fruity. The transitions and elegant and the mouthfeel is extremely silky. Virtually no sour aftertaste. Medium complexity, high depth, long length, great carry, good body. Excellent choice for coffee lovers. Overall a solid beer but I cant say its extremely complex.

pours pitch black with a nice dark beige head, some retention and lacing. roasted smokiness, figs, raisins - foreign stout feeling. espresso, bitter coffee, resin, grassiness, med long finish, medium body - oily.

Bottled.  A black beer with a gorgeous beige coloured head.  Subtle coffee in the nose with lactic notes.  The coffee is more noticeable in the mouth where there are the typical stout veggy notes.  It needs more roast.  Its reasonable but pretty unexceptional.
Dark brown with a medium brown head. Coffee and roasted tones. Malt, fruit, coffee and chocolate. Medium to full body with a nice, balanced bitter finish.

Sample from bottle at Haket 2012-01-14 Göteborg 
AR: chocolate, heavy coffey, melas, boubone barrell
AP: dark brown body, wee dark beige head
F: ash, rich chocolate, slippery/sugery feeling, vanilla, kavring, rusk (bread)
Black with a golden brown head. Aroma is espresso, caramel, vanilla. Medium body with a woody feel and dry finish. Taste if coffee, oak and a hint of chocolate. Enjoyable.

35cl bottle.Pours black, with a thick medium-tan head. Good lacing and long lasting foam. Nose is rich coffee and roasted notes. Taste is coffe with ashes, bitter chocolate, roasty malt and a hint of dark fruits. Bitter and dry finish. Good carbonation and creamt texture. Excellent.
Pours a deep brown with a brown head.  Overwhelming aroma of coffee and cocoa.  Smells great!  Lots of espresso in the taste.  Quite bitter.  Lots of carbonation.  Really good beer!

[bottle]
Sweet roasted barley aroma with some plums, raisins, and currants. Opaque brown-black under a thick, brown ring and patches. Sweet roasted barley vanilla and coffee flavour with plenty of cereal grain pumpernickel together with dried fruit--mostly prunes and tobacco. Coffee and faint chocolate come out a bit late and linger pleasantly. Full body, medium carbonation, almost syrupy sweet feel together with some walnuts in the finish.
Nice coffee aroma and aftertaste, full bodied. Will want to have it again. Tried in Singapore after a pint of German dunkel. Still this espresso stout can stand out.

From notes: Pours innk black with some bubbles along the glass and a 1-finger, caramel-colored head.  Aroma of coffee, with a healthy mix of cocoa.  Medium-thick, with a pleasant depth.  Nice, bright note to the flavor up front, possibly of mild citrus.  The coffee blooms in the finish to produce a nice aftertaste.  As it warms, the "citrus" disappears and it takes on a cocoa note that blends very nicely with the coffee.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Inky dark brew with two plus fingers of tan head. Head settles down to about 1/4th inch with good lacing. Aroma aroma dominated by coffe, burn grains, roasted malts, hints of dark fruit, sweet malts. Taste is sweetened coffee, a little chocolate and burn grains. Dry finish verging on bitter when melding with the coffeee / raosted grain flavor. Palate is  moderate, a little thin. Overall a fine stout.
En botella,cerveza negra con espuma marron,buena retención.Aromas a café,chocolate,vainilla......menos densidad de la esperada pero muy agradable de beber.

33 cl bottle. Bottled on 06/2011. BBE 12/2011.
Pours pitch black colour with medium beige head. Aroma of smoke, roasted malts, mild espresso notes, burnt chocolate, mild hints of whiskey, vanilla notes ash and mild vegetables. Flavour of chocolate, espresso, vanilla, burnt malts, mild spicy notes and earth. Bitter and dry palate.
4425

330ml bottle

Pours pitch black with a small sticky brown head. Aroma has notes of vanilla, roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Taste is quite roasty and sweet with hints of vanilla, coffee and chocolate. Finish is long lasting, bitter and roasty. Good stout, but was hoping for more coffee notes.

330 ml bottle.
Pours a black colour with a thick beige head. Aroma of rich espresso coffee with some vanilla notes. Rich flavour of espresso, roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla and some bitter hops in the background. Light vegetable notes. Full bodied, soft carbonation and a long finish with some roastiness and coffee. Very well balanced but a fresh bottle would be better.
Bottle. Pours black with thin brown head. Big chocolaty aroma with coffee background. Taste is similar, lots of chocolate. Silky smooth. Excellent

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2015 Tap at True Brew Mito. Black coloured with small golden head with big bubbles. Aroma is smoky, lots of coffee and cocoa. Taste is espresso. Lots of bitterness, particularly at the end. Totally roasty. Nice oliy texture and pleasant spritziness. Hints of caramel in the taste once you get used to the bitterness, and a bit of smooth milk chocolate too. Lovely.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2011 Sampled at SBWF. Stockholm, September 30th, 2011. 

Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate and heavy roasted malts. The body is not that heavy but the flavours are intense. Lots of chocolate, dark malts, dark fruits and berries. Nice!

Bottle.  Pours opaque with a large, creamy brown head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is dark malt, coffee, roast, nutty, earthy hops, and dark fruits.  Flavor is dark malt, roast and coffee, caramel with dark fruits, bitter malt and hops with a lightly dry finish.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

I had this one several time before and I didnt like it so much every time but this particular bottle was even in a bad shape evidently. First no coffee aroma at all; bad start. Chocolate, cocoa powder, roast malt, some herbs and, here the nightmare begins, a lot of licorice. The taste had even a bigger amount of licorice. The chocolate and cocoa presences stay but  weaker, and i got no coffee in the taste too. if it hadnt been for the enjoyable malt taste, i could have wasted the beer just after a shot. I didnt finish the glass anyway. Even in this condition the beer is not that bad you could think. but i hate too much licorice in stouts. bad choice to celebrate the #stoutday.

330 mL bottle.  Pours an extremely dark brown with a tan head. Very interesting aroma, very creamy vanilla coffee, raisin, and sweet cocoa, a little soy.  Flavor of sweet cocoa and coffee, dark fruit again, and again a touch of soy, finishing with definite coffee grounds.  Delightful.
scura schiuma media dscreta persitenza naso tostato caffe vanigli in bocca piuttosto morbida tosature caffe ancora vaniglia nel final eamaro da tosature meno da luppolo cioccolato amaro

Intense coffee nose that blows off a little and leaves a choclatey, rich more imperial stoutish aroma, with coffeeish notes, some hops and a touch of alcohol. Good medium bodied stout character. Big, but not too big. Coffee is present and well integrated but not the only element of the flavor. Well done.

Appearance:  into a snifter--jet black with a thick than head slowly shrinking to a collar, a bit of lace.  Aroma: smells like an americano coffee, with a bit of chocolate and worn baseball glove.   Taste: extremely acidic espresso flavors at first, which mellow as it warms, then you get notes of chocolate, raisin, and ash.   Finish: long, smoothly bitter, with coffee notes mainly persisiting.   Notes: Best at near room temperature.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2015 Tasted from bottle into standard pint glass. Poured a very dark brown, almost black color with chill haze and fluffy beige head which was somewhat lasting with lace. Pleasing aromas of bread, toast, coffee, no late hops, some fruity ale yeast esters. Very complex flavors: mild malts, toast, caramel, molasses, roasted barley, nuts, black coffee and dark chocolate, plums, sour cherries. Medium body and "chewy" mouthfeel. Creamy, fruity, long-lasting, bittersweet aftertaste which finishes dry. Very tasty.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Pitch black colour, small brown head. Aroma is espresso, wood, some roasted notes and mild cold dark coffee as well. Flavour is quite similar. Very wellbalanced coffee stout, which leaves a very long coffee aftertaste as well.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle. Thick dark pour with a monster foamy reddish tan head. Big espresso nose with some chocolate. Palate is actually a bit thin. Taste is milder espresso, chocolate, and a bit of licorice. Really nice stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 Bottled at "Osteria della Birra" - Bergamo (BG).
Creamy nut and resistant head, much elegant, voluminous and elegant aspect. Dark and impenetrable one. Pleasant cooffè aroma with notes of liquorice, ash, roast wood and malty. Alcoholic, powerfull and fraught body. Complex cortex and burned cereals notes, ashed caramel and toasted coffè. Amazing.

330 ml purchased at Winooski Beverage Warehouse (Vermont), on August 2, 2011. Black, small beige head. Aroma of sweet espresso coffee, less intense Péché Mortel from Dieu du Ciel, a little barley. Good taste of roasted espresso coffee, burned malted barley, aftertaste of coffee not too bitter. Definitely a beer to coffee lovers!

33 cl bottle @ hotel room, Kyoto. Bottled 06/2011, BBE 12/2011
Aroma has surprisingly lots of coffee. Also some roasted malt and hints of sugar. Flavour is really rich on espresso, it overrides everything. As a coffee lover I cannot say that it would be a bad thing.Some chocolate, sugar and roasted malt can be observed behind the coffee wall though. Some harshly bitter coffee at the end and the palate becomes a bit sticky in a sweet way after some sips. However, deserves its place as the highest rated beer in Japan.
Kind of reminds me of Nørrebro La Granja Espresso Stout.
Black colored brew with a nice brown head. Nice coffee, espresso, roast in the aroma. Flavor is moderate bitter, nice creamy feel. Roast, coffee and chocolate.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: pours pitch-black with an incredible, solid, lasting mocha head, smell is sweet roasted coffee & roasted dark malts, taste is a nice slightly bitter coffee taste upfront & roasted malts with minor espresso & some milk chocolate, a slight roasted bitterness lingers on in your mouth as you finish, bit creamy but not thick, great beer

Black pour tan head light sticky lacing .... aromas incredible coffee and cocoa, roasted malts .... tastes roasted and of cocoa, fruity light vanilla but mostly cocoa and roasted malts with dark fruits a tasty and complete stout .... dry bitter roasted cocoa finish ... abv hidden well .... awesome well done flavors

Bottle from GBBF drunk at home.  Now there cant be many beers that I have anticipated as much as this one.  Been looking for it for about 2 years.  Black as black with big thick lasting tan head as it sits in a Duvel glass.  Strong espresso coffee aroma.  Bit of roast too.  Boy that is good.  Better than I was expecting to be honest.  Wow.  I had the Birrifico Sally Brown coffee edition before this and thought it was good and I have a Mikkeller Weasel in the fridge, so really have something there to compare this to.  Very intense aroma.  The mouthfeel is pretty much sublime and the swallow and the finish, just how the beer makes you feel is pretty much amazing.  Yes the way it makes me feel is pretty incredible.  Not harsh.  Just a touch of alcohol on the finish.  Pretty damn good.
Bottle pours a pitch black color with a tan head.  Roasted chocolate malt aroma with coffers and dark chocolate aroma and flavor.  Very nice.
UPDATED: NOV 11, 2011 Very nice beer for one brewed with coffee, its smooth and the coffee isnt overbearing.

Pours a dark brown, almost black color. Completely opaque. Dark fruit and toffee flavors up front. Lots of espresso flavors at the end. The Russian Imperial Stout base is very evident and works quite well.

(Bottle) Poured opaque (but not cloudy) black with a short-lived coffee-coloured head. The aroma was quite subtle, but was distinctly coffee and chocolate. Full bodied and creamy with plenty of fine carbonation. Flavour has a rich coffee and chocolate start with a short but intense bitter coffee and burnt toffee finish. Overall, very interesting, but a bit extreme.

Bottle at Southwark Rose Hotel - shared with Mette. Black - brown head. Lovely espresso, coffee and chocolate aorma. Nice hoppy, oiley, smooth body, fruity, grassy, light bitterness, dark fruits, roasted. Nice.
Bottle from GBBF, 2011. Drank at home. Black pour with a beige head. Heavy coffee aroma with some caramel and toffee. Very nice full on coffee flavour with a splash of smoke. Dry, smoky finish.

GBBF 2011. Bottle. Pours black with thin brown head. Nose is rich sweet black coffee. Taste is sweet expresso coffee with lactic and vanilla notes. Chocolate sweetness but not sickly. Strong but not cloying. Very well balanced, but good for drinking in smallish doses. Ideally share a bottle.

11/07/2011 Brasserie 4:20 (330ml bottle). Nera, densa, impenetrabile, piccolo cappello di schiuma crespa color grigio-marroncino, abbastanza persistente. Aroma intenso di malti tostati, caffè e una punta di spezie. In bocca è caffettosissima, forte e decisa ma un po monotona, specie a lungo andare. Corpo medio, carbonazione generosa e forse un filo eccessiva. Stout interessante e di indubbio valore, ma a me non ha impressionato particolarmente.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2014 Black with brown tint and a tan lasting lacy frothy head. Deep overpowering smell of espresso with rich malt character, brown sugar and chocolate roast. Medium frothy oily body. Sweet initial taste of malt and fills into a burnt roast and finishes with ash and burnt.

Pours a five+ finger brown head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Good carbonation and heavy bodied.  Black color, no highlights.  Nose is coffee and flavor is black coffee and some sweetness from the malt. Pricey at $5.65 for a 330ml bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.

33 cL bottle courtesy of JB, served at a tasting at Chris place. Poured in a snifter. Pours black with a moderate tan head. The head remains and leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. The aroma is very roasty, with herbs, hops and espresso. The flavour is dry, with roasty malts, coffee and earthy hops. The finish is moderate in length and dry with roasty coffee notes. On the palate, it is medium in body with a dry texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a decent dry stout with espresso elements. 2011-05-22

Pours a nice dark brown with little head.  Aroma of medium toasted malt and coffee.  Nice smooth flavor profile, a bit more than medium bodied with a good balance.  Really good without being a huge beer.
This beer was sort of a roasted or burnt coffee. Light texture makes this kind of weird.

Roasted chocolate goodness. You will taste the vanilla. I actually got in an argument with someone at work about it. They said there was none and they suck, but this beer does not. Dark black pour and a coffee lovers treat.

(11.2nd bottle) deep espresso brown pour, thick and soapy deep tan bubbles, excellent lacing. Couldnt look much better. Nose of sweet espresso, cream, raisins, sweet cracker, small rice character. Taste of fresh coffee, cream, mild coffee acidity in a good way, has a fair amount of milk chocolate also. The body is damn near perfect. Creamy, oily body, soft carbonation but abundant. A delicious chocolate and coffee linger. Excellent beer!
Black with a small tan head. Aroma of toffee, cold coffee and chocolate. Sweet toffee dominated flavour with a reasonably balanced coffee character.

Pours black but thin with a full thick brown head.  Smells of bitter roast espresso, chocolate, molasses and vanilla.  Lots of bitter malt, coffee, a touch of vanilla and a metallic flavor.  The finish is fairly long and bitter.

I thought this was much worse than the Sweet Stout, which is amazing considering their vastly different scores on the site.  I thought this one kind of a had a cigarette ashtray quality to it in the finish that really detracted from my overall enjoyment.
Bottle. Dark pour with tan head.  Roasted malts, espresso, creamy vanilla and chocolate aroma tones. Flavor is smooth with coffee, vanilla, chocolate and some light spice and dark fruits.

Bottle; Pour is Dark Brown with a nicely retained beige head with some light lacing as well. Roasted and Chocolate malts on the nose, its nearly underwhelming, but the I find that the flavor profile really meshes well together. There is a creamy richness from the head that brings up the espresso note present here - I found the roasted and chocolate malts as well of course, as well as a hint of vanilla. The bitterness does remind of a Russian Imperial, after reading the description. Anyway, just a great brew that I drink in support of Japan.

Pours a clear and black beer with a beige head. The aroma is cold coffee, pepper, sweetness and ash. The flavor follows the nose with some additional berries. The palate is dry and roasted. Overall a good beer.
This is kind of like a light version of a coffee beer like Speedway.  Very quaffable and well made.  Nice complex flavors of coffee roast, chocolate, vanilla, and caramel.  A real treat.
Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, cold coffee and green pepper. Flavour is roasted malt, heavy cold coffee and green pepper.

Dark black with a thin layer of dark tan head. Aroma of dark fruits and root beer. Rich and chewy texture with flavors of raisin, dark chocolate and lemon zest. Roasted coffee beans apparent on the finish.
UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 Questa Giapponese spacca di brutto... sembra un cappuccino... una grandissima birra...
Very dark pour with brownish white head that didnt last.. aroma of coffee and burnt, and chocolate. Strong tasting, get hints of chilli spice, coffee, and chocolate. Pretty tasty but quite strong
Faint coffee aroma but the flavor is very strong chocholate.  Very good stout, among the best Ive had.
Bottle @ Norweigan Tasting, Odense. Pours black with a creamy beige head and lacings. Nose is roast and expresso. Chocolate and cold coffee. A bit of vanilla.  Full bodied. Smooth.

05-MAR-2011, bottle in Orlando, from Whole Foods.
Black with fine beige head.
Roasted with espresso (!) and then the hops kick in with a fine bitterness.
My first rating of a Japanese beer and I did not expect such complexity.
Slightly sweet with that coffee and hoppy bitterness, Uhm...!

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Strong coffee aroma but not too overwhelming. Black, light brown head, good lace. Sweetish, roasted bitter, espresso of course. Medium body. Flavourful but not too strong, balanced.

Aroma of strong coffee and alcohol.  hints of chocolate and caramel and fruit.  I agree with the description but I cant tell what type, maybe plum.  Great dark black opaque look with a lasting tan head.  Medium sweetness.  Chocolate and coffee all thew way.  the finish is nice and smooth.  This is delicious

Thanks to Mane Liquor for this one.
Almost jet black pour with a big tan head. Big coffee on the nose with chocolate and caramel playing a part. Big woody flavour with coffee beans and chocolate. Fantastically thick. Hitachinos best brew
Love me a good espresso stout, this is no exception. Im afraid this is all the beer thats any good from hitachino so far, strong coffee on palate and nose, long finish. Highly recommended.
Bottle.  Pours near black with thick head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, caramel.  Flavor is amazing.  Definitely can taste the vanilla.  Really enjoyed this beer.
33 cl bottle @ Rome. dark brown/black with a not too persistent cappuccino foam. flavour of fresh coffe beans and chocolate. Mediun body . Very long lasting in mouth. A perfect Espresso Stout

Aroma of burnt espresso, soy sauce, coffee, chocolate and faint raisins. Pour black with finger thick tan head. Taste chocolate, coffee, faint soy sauce, espresso, and a woody tone. Palate was dry super rich with mild carbonation. Overall a surprise pretty tasty beer.

Pours dark, dark brown/black with one finger of foamy dark brown head, which subsides slowly to form chocolate milk lacing all around the glass. Aroma contains lots of coffee, as one might expect, alongside dark chocolate and roasted malts. Very pleasant taste, sweet "quality" coffee flavor with more balancing dark chocolate. Roasted malts provide a solid backbone. Prickly carbonation, smooth and milky.

Pours clean black resembling a dark cup of coffee with a cappucino colored head. The head was thick and about two fingers in the glass provided at the Sugar Bowl. It faded rather quickly and left decent lacing on the glass.

The aroma is of espresso beans and dark chocolate. There is a distinct burnt smell. The coffee notes smell like a fresh espresso.

The taste is of strong and old coffee. The freshness you would hope for in the espresso flavor is lacking. Something is off about it (a bit of research has shown me this is probably because they add espresso beans directly to the boil). There is a nice taste of dark chocolate and roasted malts. There are not hints of hops in the beer.

The mouthfeel is smooth and velvety with gentle carbonation. The mouthfeel was one of the more impressive parts of this beer.

This beer was not terrible but I consider this type of beer one of my favorites and can name at least three direct competitors that are clearly superior. To shy away from giving this one a try but you will likely find yourself lead away permanently by better coffee/espresso stouts.

Havent rated a beer in years, but this one really inspired me. Such a richly balanced combination of coffee and chocolate. Beautiful full palate with gentle carbonation, carries these flavours so nicely. This is one lovely beer.
1/8/11.  On tap.  Sour caramel latte aroma with a caramel latte flavor that leans towards too bitter.  Eh.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2012 Darkest black, frothy tan head fades. Roasted malt  and coffee aroma. Burnt roasted malt and coffee taste, Some caramel, chocolate and dark fruit. Medium bodied, softly carbed. Burnt bitter finish. NFL (Not For Lagerboys)

New beer Distributors 11.2oz ($3.45): Pours a light brown, long-lasting head over a pitch black body. Aroma of espresso (obviously), roasted malts, and a few other things. There are "sweet" notes in the aroma thus implying a fruity presence, but I couldnt quite figure out which ones they were. Definitely has an element of imperial stout in it (they did use the base after all, but it is lighter in body). Taste lets loose some of the licorice. There is a little bit of bitterness in the finish. Very light sweetness throughout. Lots of coffee in the taste as well, but we know that already. Chocolate bar of great complexity might be a way to describe this super creamy feeling brew.

Appearance: pours a nice clean black much like coffee without the cream. Thin cappuccino tinged head fades into a thin ringlet. No real head but swirls with some nice lace, cappuccino hued of course.

Nose: chocolate covered espresso beans are in the house to stay. Burnt wood. Black chocolates in raw bark form; break a chunk, nibble, and enjoy. Black cherries. Espresso crema. All around an intensely thick aroma profile.

Palate: smooth and a tad bubbly; velveteen. Creamy up front with chocolate and vanilla for an almost ice-cream experience. Burnt bitterness lingers long and black in the back with pure cacao chocolate bars and crunchy espresso beans; love it. Vanilla root. No cherries.

Final Thoughts: a bit simple but very tasty. Followed through on her promise of espresso and stout delights. Another winner from Kiuchi, masters of both sake and beer (which are one and the same but shall save that digression for another date).

From a 330ml bottle on 18/12/2010. Has a strong aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate and seaweed. Has a rich, creamy texture, with moderate carbonation. The flavours are burnt malt, dark and milk chocolate, and a touch of fruit, finished off by unusual spicy, slightly salty bitterness. A nice and quite powerful stout.

This beer is a brown color dark enough to be nearly opaque w/ a small light brown head. Nose is sweet w/ an acidic sharpness as well as a bit of roast and raisin. Tastes of old coffee. Or, more specifically, it has the acrid old coffee taste you get from adding coffee beans directly to the boil in homebrewing (looks like the commercial description verifies this). A bit of chocolate and roast are rather nice but dont make up for the flavor flaws. Palate is a bit thin and fizzy which doesnt help matters. It is possible that my bottle sat on the shelf too long but given it is a seasonal which I am drinking in season, I suspect that I just dont like this beer.

A nice and delicious stout. Aroma was nice. Dark roasted malt and chocolate with a little vanilla. Pour was a nice deep dark brown with a tan ring for a head. Taste was good as well. A heavy mix of roasted malt with just a hint of chocolate and the espresso barely making an appearance until the aftertaste on the top of the mouth. Nice carbonation and thick chewy mouth feel. Good beer
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 1, 2011 bottle.   pours a deep brown with red highlights and a big foamy tan head.  leaves some neat layered lacework on the glass.  aroma of bright roasty espresso beans, molasses, smoke, char, and rich high cocoa dark chocolate.   taste is  cocoa, fresh coffee,  smokey dry dark high cocoa chocolate.  touch of dried dates.    dry.  awesome.  such a good beer.

(330 ml bottle (stamped "ES 10.04") from Rising Tide) Pours dark brown with ruby and amber highlights. Tall brown head recedes to a rather thick, lasting cap. Big espresso aroma with some dark chocolate. Mouthfeel smooth, medium-thick. Light, broken lacing. Flavor of big rich espresso with a bitter, coffee finish. Tasty and well done stout with no off flavors.
Coffee roasty aroma. Visually perfect - black as the ace of spades and a nice tan hat. Nice coffee flavours, pleasant carbonation.

pours pitch black with a huge mocha head...lively...great retention and lacing!  aroma is roasty with notes of dark fruit, milk, coffee, and chocolate...noticeable alcohol here.  flavor is also roasty with significant coffee flavor and a hint of chocolate...not as bitter as i expected.  mouthfeel is thick and creamy with a long roasty espresso finish.  very nice beer but as imperial stouts go the aroma was a bit tame.

a pretty amazing beer. Would like to try an imperial version of this beer. the pour is deep black, purely opaque with a nice cap of tan head. aroma is sweet roasted malts, brown sugar and delicious coffee and chocolate. a
wonderful beer.

330ml bottle. Pour tar black with a thick latte coloured head that looks solid enough to walk across. Big and small bubbles join together to form a tight knit blanket of foam Roasted coffee beans and bitter dark chocolate in the nose and a roasty coffee flavour that is thick in the mouth and coats the tongue.

wow, this was really impressive. smells like actual coffee, looks like actual coffee and the taste is mildly coffeelike, turbano sugar sweet with some cocoa and dark roasted grain notes. who knew the japanese could make such great beer?

Let it warm up a bit and this will impress. Very dark and thick looking with a foamy, mocha-colored head. Huge chocolate nose. Sweet chocolate flavor at first followed by a roasted bitterness from the coffee. Very smooth palate.

There is no doubt this beer delivers on the coffee front. Stacks of dark chocolate on the nose but the palate shows more roast together with softer milk chocolate notes. Nice fruit tingle note runs right through the palate, perhaps pointing to the RIS base, albeit in a much lighter form. Very nice beer.

(11.2oz bottle) Purchased at Cook Street Liquor Store in Victoria, B.C., for $4.90.Pours a large, brown head atop an opaque black body. Nose is alcoholic, coffee, molasses and vanilla. Great texture and palate - grainy coffee, toasted malt. Its very good.

Pours black with a dark tan head.  Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate and a heavy scent of what seems like some whiskey.  For me the taste doesnt match the aroma, but is still very good...a tingling from not sure what - alcohol and pretty decent carbonation?? - kind of overpowers the expected roast malt and strong coffee flavor expected.  Nice mouth feel - creamy.  Surprisingly bitter for a stout, with a strong stout aftertaste.  Very unique and definitely worth a try.

330ml bottle.  Black pour, chocolate head.  Aroma of sweet espresso, dark cocoa, cocoa nibs. Tastes of dark roast coffee, raisin and dark fruit, chocolate, roasted barley.  Nice burnt quality.  A bit of acidic sweetness.  Very full flavored.  Powerful and delicious.

Bottle. Thanks to Vertical bacon strips for the trade!! Pours black with a one inch tan cap. Moderate lacing. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, caramel, sugar and roasted malts. Taste is very coffee and plenty of darker flavors like dark chocolate and espresso. Plenty of sweetness and more roasted malts. A long bitter aftertaste. Full body with a very creamy texture. Another great beer from this brewery.

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark black with a large long lasting tan head. It has the aroma of dark chocolate and espresso. This beer is wonderful. It tastes intensely of unsweetened dark chocolate and espresso with some vanilla and smoke. Ill definitely try to drink more by this brewer.

330mL bottle
Pours pretty much a picture perfect stout; thck orange tan head atop an opaque black body; cant ask for any more.
Deeply roasted aroma; cocoa, coffee bean, woody spice, smoke, aniseed, and just a hint of floral hop.
Oily texture, full body but certainly not as overly rich as I was expecting.
Flavour is quite suprising, not particularly sweet at all; bitter chocolate and espresso, with meaty roast malt,. brown sugar and distinct woody spice. Noticable floral/citrus flower hop on the finish with assertive bitterness and roast astrigency.
Interesting take on the coffee stout. Far drier and more bitter than others ive come across, which are generally sweet. Great flavour and complexity!
Draft at Popeyes (Tokyo), black with a brown head. Yep, definitely smells like an espresso. Tastes very much like an espresso as well. A creamy palate, feels a bit like a coffee frappucino. It works.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a dark brown to black color with a tan head. The aroma is roasted malt and coffee with a touch of chocolate. 

The flavor is chocolate and coffee with some roasted malt.

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Relatively straight forward, but well done.
Pours black with lasting tan head. Nose of port, raisin and light coffee. Taste of coffee, bitter dark chocolate with oily body. Quite earthy. Finish is bitter and long.
Pours dark brown with medium brown head. Aroma is of beautiful rich coffee. Rich brown malt flavors and rich coffee flavors is matched with bitterness. Tasty.

Pitch black with no light shining through it. Pours a nice tan color head that sits pretty well. An aroma of chocolate. Nutty flavor with a bit of a dry tart twang. Slight alcoholic burn. Big body on this beer. Has imperial stout characteristics.

bottle: this stuff is my jam. Black pour with tan head. Huge roasty, complex malt. currents, black molasses, brown sugar and hint of toffee and prune. Dark chocolate, creamy milk shake body rounded out by a nice bitter. Earthy, coffee bitterness with a shot of espresso. caramel base with an edge of vanilla beans. Long, smooth finish, perfectly balanced. Delicious.

12oz bottle pours an opaque, oily black with a thin, creamy, tan head.  Nose is bread, malts, burnt toast, molasses, licorice, dark pitted fruits.  Flavor is sweet, molasses, licorice, malty, brown sugar, coffee with cream, cola.  Full bodied, sweet sticky finish.

Another beer with a spooky owl!  Poured black with a thin brown head.  Aroma has lots of roasted malts and coffee.  Some dark fruit and vanilla as well.  Taste is very roasted and quite bitter.  Some smooth vanilla flavors help balance out the chocolate and coffee.  Finish is interesting, it is definitely mostly chocolate malts, but there are hints of dark fruit and vanilla.  Slightly creamy/oily texture.  Overall pretty good!

Bottle. Looks amazing in a tulip glass with a matt black body and a dense bubbly cafe latte coloured head that lasts and laces nicely. The nose is dominated by freshly roasted expresso coffee with background molasses and a hint of liquorice. The taste is again dominated by the coffee but it is not nearly as sweet as you would expect and in fact finishes with a quite sophisticated woody roasted coffee bean bitterness that lingers on the palate. Medium bodied with a rich almost syrupy mouthfeel and a low carbonation. An outstanding Imperial stout for those sip and savour moments.

(11.2 oz botle).  Pours almost black with thin tan head.  Sediment suspended in the brew.  Aroma is of dry roasted coffee grinds, some dark fruit, maybe some pine, and tobacco and unsweetened chocolate.  Taste is semi-sweet with roasty bitterness.  Very much like cold, bitter coffeee.  Medium to full bodied with oily/creamy texture.  Finish has a roasted coffee bitterness with some green from the hops.  Ive only had a couple of beers from Hitachino, but this one is my favorite so far.

12oz bottle in an English pint.  Pours black with a thick, lingering, beige head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, and roasted malts.  Flavor of roasted malts with some chocolate and a little bitterness that doesnt fit well.  A strong coffee/chocolate finish.  Full bodied, but could be thicker.  Pretty good for a stout.
330mL bottle, pours black with a tan head. Aroma of rich espresso, roasted malt and light cocoa. Flavour of rich espresso, burnt flavours and roasted malt. The best of Hitachino.

Pretty excited to try this one. The pour was pretty damn sexy with a thick brown foam head. The aromas that I got were coffee, chocolate, and a little bit of soy sauce. Its not super thick and the ABV is hidden very well amongst the all the flavors. The carbonation is pretty good and the head retention is too bad either.
Bottle. Strong coffee aroma. Tastes of coffee and dark chocolate. The texture is a bit grainy, bottom of the coffee pot feeling, which lowers the grade a bit for me.

Smells like coffee, very strong aroma. Pours black with a creamy looking head. Laces the glass. Strong roasted bitter flavour, very smooth and clean. Palate has a long finish, very very good coffee stout!

Bottle.  Pours a slick and dark brown with a thin head that disappears quickly.  Aromas are very weak at first, just a hint of peat and dark coffee with a little soy and brown sugar.  As it warms, more and more molasses starts to show up, but it seems a little off.  Flavor is pretty blah as well.  I honestly expected this to be far more appealing.  As it is, it is a molasses and soy dominated stout with little roast or espresso to hold the aforementioned flavors in check.  I dont know if this is a bad bottle or if this just doesnt hit the sweet spot for me, but I can do without this in the future...
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Wonderful Mokka-like aroma and fine espresso sweetness, acidity and bitterness elements in balance. One of the more complete espresso stouts Ive had, perhaps due to the quality of the coffee grounds used.  Overall really interesting and worth trying, despite the relatively high price.

An unusual sour, woody aroma rises off this dark ale with a finely laced dark tan head.   Even in a bright light, I couldnt see any light at all coming through this beer; its definitely one of the most opaque beers Ive ever seen.   Given that, its surprising how light bodied this is.  Creamy, chocolate, and dark roasted coffee come first followed by a sour/bitter cocoa flavor and a barrel aged roundness with a hint of vanilla.   Given all the things going on in this beer, its really well balanced and surprisingly drinkable.

A: The pour is nearly black with a thin tan head.

S: The nose has plenty of strong coffee to it along with quite a bit of bittersweet chocolate. A bit of burnt malt, and licorice.

T: The coffee flavor is up front and lightly bitter. The chocolate provides a nice sweetness along with a smooth, creamy flavor that I was not expecting.

M: The body is medium and really just quite smooth. The beer is fairly lowly carbonated.

D: Pretty easy to drink for an "imperial" stout. Nice coffee flavor and an even more impressive chocolate quality.

330mL bottle poured into a tulip.

Pours dark brown out of the bottle and sits almost completely black in the glass with a huge tan head that shows excellent retention and lacing.

Aroma is like a mocha with some espresso and cocoa sweetness.  Lightly roasted black malts, caramel and vanilla.

The taste has a little bit of lactose sourness with the sweet vanilla and espresso bitterness.  Pretty sweet taste where the coffee isnt nearly as dominant as I expected.  Some caramelized sugar as well.

The mouthfeel is excellent, super smooth and creamy.  Lightly bitter in the finish.

This is a solid if not spectacular stout thats extremely smooth and drinkable.

All I need was a tiny naked Japanese girl to walk on my back. I bet thats what they do in Ibaraki when sipping this excellent brew. Im drinking this in my pool with the heat at 98 and still loving it. I have to drink it too fast though cause its so hot. Ill grab a few more of these for the November chill.

Pours a dark, dark brown with a thin, creamy, tan head that slowly fades away to a thin ring.  Nicely roasted coffee beans with a touch of acidity on the nose.  Almost smells like there are still some unroasted (green) beans as well.  Lots of bitter coffee grounds and dark malts in the taste, but they are balanced out by some sweeter chocolate notes.  Finish is smooth and balanced.  An enjoyable coffee stout.  Somewhat basic, but still a fun beer to drink

Pours black with a liquorice brown creamy short-lived head.
Nose is full of intense coffee and sweet dark chocolate. A mix between a mocha and a rich chocolate cake. Plenty of roasted malt later on.
