Roasted coffee really hits as a flavour but underneath theres still a lot of dark chocolate and sweet roasted malt. Some soft alcohol.
Creamy high carbonation, very rich, smooth body.

Pours a black color with a brown head.  Aroma is of coffee, malts, molasses, and some dark fruit.  Flavor is similar to the aroma.  Malts, dark chocolate, coffee, and cocoa.  Leaves kind of an oily coffee malt finish.

Black with a huge long lasting and lacing khaki head.  The aroma and flavor are dominated by roasted coffee notes (obviously), and they work quite well. Medium bodied with medium carbonation on the palate.  Overall, a good coffee beer, but not overly interesting or unique.

I know Japan has a rich beer history but it was the last place I expected a big coffee stout to come from. Pitch black with a long lasting tan head, if anything there is just a touch to much carbonation but it might be my glass (Headmaster). Not much on the nose, certainly the coffee is there. Strong coffee flavours come though on tasting and there is a long lingering bitterness. Very smooth mouthfeel with this one.
Overall a good stout that achieves what it sets out to do by delivering a big coffee hit. Ill certainly take a look at the rest of the range.

If I was from colombia Id probably love this beer; if I ate coffee grains for breakfast Id love this beer; if I was shopping for a coffee stout I would get this beer. With that being said this was not my style, I thought it was a great find: a rare stout rated in the top percent. Well, it pours wonderfully dark opaque brown with deep tan head nice creamy retention-not overly carbonated. Aromas of coffee, burnt coffee that has sat on the pot burning for hours, and hints of liquid feces....I give it bonus points for being so intense. Excellent palate light carbonation creamy full body simply offensive coffee taste over over over the top, out of the ball park, in an adjacent galaxy some where. I thought I was finished but Im still tasting this "gem" 10s of minutes after the first sip dry cocoa/espresso bitterness. I will let it warm, in the mean time pray that it changes from toilet water to stein worthy. (get it? water to wine with beer twist! mmyes! chuckle) Alright, more milk comes through as it warms as well as roasted malts and hints of chocolate but I stand by my original score, overly offensive coffee (and some sh*t!)

Bottle at Håndverkerstuene.
Sweet milk, cocoa, coffee. Too much boiled milk and sugar, but there is a little bitterness in the tail.
UPDATED: SEP 26, 2016 Quite delicious.  The bitter of the coffee balanced excellently with the sweetness of the malt.   Serving: Bottle

Bottle, pours a syrupy walnut w/ an oily mocha head, aroma is deep roasted espresso w/ some light chocolate, smooth and velvety w/ deep roasted coffee flavor, surprisingly light and buoyant for a stout, very tasty brew

[2860-20100501] 1pt8.3floz bottle. Roast wood plank aroma with heavy plastic. Dark dark brown body with a medium-lasting dark brown creamy head. Roasty malt flavour has a little bitter seaweed, a coffee bean finish and long coffee aftertaste. Full body. Wow, something strange about that seaweed part.
(w/ jerc, tupalev)

11.2 oz bottle. Pours very deep mahogany nearly black with a small creamy tan head. Aroma is very espresso, black coffee, burnt coffee beans, spent coffee grounds, very rich. Flavor starts and finishes with a lot of espresso and coffee as well, sweeter than expected, but still bitter as one would expect espresso to be. Dark fruits and dark chocolate round out the very complex and rich flavors. Medium to full creamy body and a soft carbonation. Excellent stuff

11.2 ounce bottle purchased quite some time back.  Pours a pitch black with giant brown head that has great retention and lacing.  Aroma of woody dark roasted malts, chocolate, dank dark coffee, and some ash.  Flavor is earthy semi-burnt dark malts with lighter notes of coffee and chocolate.  Lingering dark coffee in the finish.  Pretty good stuff.  (451, 318)

Back -N- Black  Brouwers Café  Seattle Beer Week 2010
Aroma  Good coffee, chocolate aroma nice and thick.  
Appearance  Black in color, Clear with a thin head.   
Flavor   Rich dark malts with coffee flavors.   
Palate    Dry finish with a Nice Mouthfeel. 
Overall  Good beer.

On tap at Brasserie V in Madison, WI - Ahh, Hitachino. Ive only had two of your beers so far, but they are so, so good. When I saw this one on tap locally, I had to go get me some. It didnt disappoint, with a foamy tan head adorning a dark body. Tons of coffee on the nose. It has some coffee ground characteristics, but it integrates so well into the roasty malt that it doesnt detract too much. The taste is--wow. Big, full roast flavors with lots of coffee that has just enough bitterness. Some sweet milkiness, chocolate, and Irish Cream are playing around in there, too. Smooth and velvety, with enough body to make it interesting. This is world-class, and I now expect nothing less from Hitachino.

12 ounce bottle purchased at the Davis Food Co-Op.  Aroma is very pleasurable with lots of sweet chocolates, vanilla beans, and a little bit of coffee present.  Not overly roasty, but nice and sweet.  Scantly transparent dark dark brown body with a strong, creamy tan head that persists nicely.  This beer has a very smooth and velvety body, which is actually the first thing I notice.  Starts a bit sweet, but not too sweet with significant espresso and coffee flavors coming through.  It is followed by a mild vanilla and choco sweetness in the middle.  There is just enough roastiness in the finish to balance this off and prevent it from being overly cloying.  This is really fucking good.

12 oz bottle served in an English pint.  Pour was onyx with two inches of thick mocha foam on top.  Nose is vanilla, espresso, roasted malt, and cellar.  Taste is much the same with a nice caramel that lasts into the finish.  It is like a beer version of a fancy coffee shop beverage.  On the whole, a pretty decent brew that is worth a try.
roasty, coffee, earthy, woody, black, cloudy, minimal head, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, sticky, soft carbonation,

Bottle 330ml. Full marks! Feels like an imperial stout. Aromas of chocolate, coffee (dominating), liquorice, spice, cherries, and a hint of alcohol. Taste starts sweet, with bitterness taking over for  a long finish. Palate is syrupy, and full bodied. Black, with a frothy off-white head.

Draft, Brouwers.  Black pour, tan head on it.  Big, slightly acidic espresso nose on it.  Coffee is definitely the dominant flavor of this.  Theres some char, chocolate, and vanilla, but its all about the coffee.  This is a pretty good espresso stout, but its kind of one note with the way it smacks you in the face with coffee.
11 ounce bottle-black pour -lite brown head-aroma and taste of coffee, chocolate, -creamy expresso finish

2010-05-01. Black body with a nice creamy beige head. Modest aroma, pleasant coffee and roast malt blend. 7+ Flavour is similar, pleasant dry coffee accents, modest roast bitterness, sweeter underlying dark malt. 7+ Palate is on the light side for a stout but pleasantly creamy still. Rather good, I enjoyed this much more than I expected since I am not a big fan of coffee beers. Bottle via trade with Savvy1982

Bottle split with Linh, paired with alaskan and eel sushi rolls. Pours a pitch black body with a tint of brown, and a dark brown head. The aroma is strong coffee roast, expresso, bitter chocolate, malts. The palate is thin to medium with great flavors of expresso, chocolate, and some vanilla.

Pours black & foamy dark chocolate thick fine  and faomy head. Roasted coffee malt and vanilla. Supe rdry bitter choc  finish. Creamy body mouthfeel.This is a really,  really great Imp stout. From Nectar Brisbane.
Thick tarlike molasses and coffee grind tones. Brownish lattee head. Jet black pour. The first beer from this brewery that I really liked. Rated 4/10/10

Pours brown/black with a thin brown head. Aroma: roasted malts, dark fruit, dark chocolate, notes of coffee & vanilla. Taste: roasted malts, chocolate, mild hops, vanilla. Mild bitter finish. Mild carbonation. Overall good: medium to thin body, some depth, balanced. Glad I tried it once but doubt I will buy another.

330mL bottle.  Pours opaque black with a thick brown head that settles down to a thick ring.  Aromas of roast, chocolate, coffee, some dried fruit, pine, citrus and spice (possibly from the hops).  High bitterness from the roasted malt and hops and coffee, with a little sweetness and some acidity.  Medium bodied, average carbonation, reasonably creamy, quite astringent and a little floury.
Beautiful near-black pour with a big foamy tan head and lots of clings. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and red fruits. Tastes of chocolate, vanilla, cherries, and of course espresso. Wonderful.
A great espresso stout.  Pair it with Theo Chocolates bread and chocolate bar

Deep black with just the slightest mahogany highlight just below a two-finger deep tan head that left nice lacing. Strong espresso and molasses aromas up front, with generous helpings of chocolate, licorice and molasses. Flavors are somewhat more muted, highlighted by the coffee and sweet chocolate, but including vanilla and a near salty earthiness. Creamy smooth mouthfeel, medium carbonation, medium to full body and a lingering milk chocolate sweetness.
330ml bottle at cardinal. Dark, almost black colored body with rusty red-brown head. Convincable coffee taste and aroma. Not very bitter. Balanced aftertaste.

12 oz. bottle from Belmont Party Supply.  Pours a dark opaque brown with a half-inch brown head that leaves some creamy lacing.  Aroma of espresso, roasted malts, dark fruits (cherries, dates, plums), dark chocolate, vanilla, and lactic acid.  Flavor follows suit pretty well, with the same notes as above, as well as mineral notes, tobacco leaves, and smoke.  Medium-bodied, with sharp carbonation.  Roasty finish and aftertaste.  Pretty nice espresso stout.

Bottle (designed by someone with talent). Black, crema head. A fair bit of carbonation. Smells of sweet black coffee with hints of roasted malt and vanilla. Taste has upfront roasted bitterness followed by coffee flavours. Body is perhaps a little thin for the intensity of flavours. Good, but unsubtle and any complexity is masked.

Biggish shiny brown head. Opaque black body. Pine needle and coffee aroma with chocolate notes, very harmonic. Dry chocolatey coffee taste with burnt earthy notes. Thinnish body. Mild mouthfeel. Dry chocolatey earthy coffee aftertaste. Very nice. (0.33l bottle, Håndverkerstuene.)
Very strong chocolate and coffee aroma. A very dark color. Coffee and chocolate taste. Usually I dont like stouts, but this is one I can drink often.
From a 12oz bottle,Brown head,Black in color,Great coffee taste,chocolate and some hints of dark fruit.Great beer from Japan.

Bottle. Pitch black pour with a creamy tan head that lasts quite a while. Espresso stands out on the aroma along with chocolate, vanilla, caramel and some roasted malt, giving the combined impression of mocha, or even cafe latte. Flavour is less sweet and a lot richer, but the otherwise very similar to the aroma; the espresso is a lot stronger but is balanced nicely by the malt and hints of dark fruit and vanilla. Thick, creamy mouthfeel with moderate carbonation and a long roasty, bitter finish. An excellent stout which balances richness and subtlety perfectly.

Large rich tan head a very dark stout carbonation not strong say medium aroma vanilla coffee malt caramel flavour coffee taste is smooth has a bitter of good quality vanilla and caramel sweetness liccorice finish strong smooth coffee taste malt freshness nice bitter to the palate and fizz

Bottle, home. Excellent coffee stout. Pours wall-to-wall black with a mocha head. The aroma has coffee, roasted barley, dark chocolate, earth, dark stone fruit, bit of spice and raisins. In that general order. The flavor is rich and sweet. Creamy espresso runs through the dark malt, like a dark chocolate ice cream swirled with coffee syrup. The mouthfeel is smooth and good. Its a great stout and the best or second best coffee stout that Ive tried so far.

A pretty solid stout for a Japanese stout. Has a nice coffee flavor but is a little light on the finish. I can overlook that small detail for a good solid stout anyday! Founders breakfast stout is a better fit for me but i would recomend trying!

330ml bottle shared with KnutAlbert, Nice, fawn-coloured head gradually diminishing atop of ruby-brown body. Faint lacing on the glass. Aroma of sweet malts with a spicy touch. Coffee, cocoa and vanilla in flavour countered by fruity hops. Dry bittersweet ending. Creamy texture and medium bodied. Prima stout (Håndverkerstuene, Oslo 19.03.2010).

12 oz. bottle to snifter. Pour is brown black thin with tan head that dissipates to bubbles around glass. Aroma coffee malt. Taste is strong coffee and malt. Palate is full and fizzy with dry finish. Overall very solid and a great stout from Japan.
Looked good in the glass, black in body with large tan head. Coffee notes on the aroma, with some cocoa in the taste also some burnt characters,medium body and very easy to drink.

Pours black with red transparency at the edge of the glass. Creamy brown head. Distinct coffee aroma. Flavors are strong roasted bitterness and sweetness. Short touch of mature cheese in the middle until a long roasted malt aftertaste takes over. It grows a bit in the mouth, but is still a really smooth drink. (33cl bottle at Cardinal Onsdag^2, 17.2.2010)

A black beer with a minimal fading head. The aroma is nice being sweet, roasted espresso, chocolate. The taste is very roasted with a nice coffee flavor mixing well with the roasted malt. Very nice stout.

330 ml bottle. Black body with a fine brown head. Aroma is mild roasted malt with a dominating espresso coffee aroma. Flavor is smooth, sweet, light roasted malt with delicate roasted coffee. Fine balanced bitterness, actually everything is extremely nice balanced here. Easy drinkable, balanced flavored beer.

0.33 L bottle, shared with Kestral@Håndverkstuene, Oslo. A tall, coarse-laced, light brown head over an opaque black body. Coffee dominated aroma and flavor.  An utterly fresh and inviting coffee aroma, with notes of cocoa and mild roastedness.
And a rounded, fresh and chocolatey coffee flavor, with some burnt, malty-bitter notes. Gently sweet, with a fine hop bitter foundation. Rich and full. Smooth in the mouth. Lasting, dry and bitterish coffee ending. A well-crafted, tasty and elegant Stout.

330 mL bottle.  Black, with a dense, large, foamy, brown head.  There is lots of espresso and some spice and roast in the aroma.  The flavour is fairly complex as well, with roast, espresso, vanilla, and herbs.  Excellent balance.  Not your run-of-the-mill stout.

bottle.  Pours black with a large, brown head and good lacing.  Nose is chocolate, espresso and ash.  Taste is of chocolate and espresso.  Yummy!  Mouthfeel is medium and creamy, yet dry.  this was a very nice stout.

Red wine, currant, dark chocolate, espresso nose.  Black, thick brown head. Charred oak and currant initially, with soy sauce making an appearance. Grassy finish with an impression of charred meat, a little smoky. Very well done, pun intended. Great balance and fantastic for the style. Tempting to rate this a perfect 5.0.

Bottle. Pours a clear black with brown highlights, big soapy buggles on top of a creamy head. Looks awesome. Its mostly just a ton of fresh coffee on the nose, loads and loads of it, along with some cocoa and dark bitter chocolate. Not much else. The raw coffeeness is actually a bit harsh in the mouth, only just kept in line by the slight sweetness lurking underneath it all. Ends dry, with a more herbal tinge to it than pure coffee rush. This is a thick stout as well, viscous with loads of tiny bubbles making it feel very smooth and creamy. About as massive on flavour as a lot of the big imp stouts, but with half the abv. Fairly straight forward, but tasty and drinkable. Nice one.

Bottle/11.2 - Poured a very dark black/brown with a small tight tan head that settled to a thick covering over the beer.  Aroma is strong of coffee/espresso, chocolate and dark roasted malts.  Flavor is bitter and heavy with coffee and chocolate with just a hint of some dark fruit.  Nice palate.  A bit of an alcohol burn going down, but not unpleasant.  Pretty good...

Poured a clear very deep brown color with a tan head.  Big aroma of espresso but with an old coffee smell that happens in all too many of these beers.  Milk chocolate underneath with light notes of ash.  The flavor was roasty with sweet chocolate and more big old coffee.  Light to medium bodied.

11.2 oz. bottle shared by goldtwins.  Pours a very dark brown, not quite black, with a light brown head.  Pleasant aroma of coffee, chocolate and just a bit of vanilla.  The flavor is smooth coffee, roasted malt and mild chocolate.  Some mild roast bitterness at the finish.  Enjoyable.

330 ml bottle @Cardinal, Stavanger.Pours pitch black with a huge tan head.
Aroma of strong roasted coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is more of the same, but also some nice dark sweet maltiness, the espresso are almost overwhelming here but thanks to the malts its rather nice. Finishes off with a nice bitter hop bite.

12oz bottle from grape & gourmet. pours black and slightly oily with a thick, brown head and a solid sheet of lace. aroma is great with big, dark, roasted malts, burnt coffee grinds, ash, and dark, pitted fruits with a hint of soy and cocoa powder. flavor is unique and excellent as well with loads of bitter espresso, chocolate, and roast up front with notes of vanilla cookies, plum sauce (i swear its in there, not just because its a Japanese beer), sweet dark fruits, cigar smoke, and spiced rum leading to a bittersweet, roasty finish. palate is smooth and medium bodied with solid carbonation. overall, a damn nice stout from the far east

Pours a deep deep deep ruby nearly black wih a nice tan head and leaves very nice lacing... Aroma is a touch creamy roasty with dark fruits coffee and a faint touch of chocolate.. the fruits dominate the roastiness.. Flavor is of dark fruits with big coffee notes and some roastiness and a touch of creaminess.. dry finish, medium bodied...

Smells like beautiful coffee with the malts playing sidekick.  Flavor is a minor bit astrigent, from what I actually believe is coming from the coffee.  Otherwise is pretty sweet.  Finishes a bit surprisingly dry, but is tolerable by all means.  All right enough.

Bottle. Opaque black body. Big, frothy, multi-hued brown head, slowly diminishing. Aroma of coffee, cream, vanilla, roasted grain, powdered chocolate, milk chocolate. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation. Tastes like a strong latte spiked with chocolate. The sweet, creamy first sip leads to coffee bitterness on the tongue, a bitterness that lingers. Not complex nor subtle, but it also doesnt have any nagging flaws either. Nice.

330 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 7.5%. Pitch black colour, big brown head. Nice roasty aroma, notes of coffee and chocolate, hints of dark fruits and vanilla. The flavour has a distinct roasty character with strong notes of espresso coffee and dark bitter chocolate, some malty sweetness, bitter finish. Excellent rich mouthfeel.

Bottled sample via Savvy1982 and shared with oakbluff. Pitch black in colour with moderate carbonation. Huge earthy espresso aroma with some powdered chocolate coming through on the back end. The espresso features prominately in the mouth as well, but the backing notes of chocolate, plum, and creamy vanilla are stronger here. Very thick milkshake-like body to this beer. Interesting that the bitterness comes more from the coffee than any hopping. Very nice. I think it would pair well with BBQ.
Dark brown pour, creamy tan head.  Dark toasty malt, chocolate, vanilla, and lots of coffee beens.  Very tasty coffee stout and quite "big" for a stout.

Pours black with a dark tan head; medium size for the style. Initial aroma is soysauce. That leads to one of those what the f--k moments. Then I get the coffee in the aroma. The taste is nice, very crisp finish. The aftertaste is long lasting with hints of chocolate, roasted malts and expresso, especially at the end. First beer Ive had from this brewery and its a solid performance.
A dark almost black pour with a tan head and lace. Aroma is chocolate and medium coffee. Flavor is an ashy choco dryness. A good malt bitter finish. Good carbonation and mouthfeel. Very nice beer.

Solid black, frothy creamy brown head. Aroma of roast coffee bean, toffee and vanilla. taste is sweet espresso with some dark chocolate/coffee bitterness. Thick creamy texture, smooth carboantion. Leaves somewhat of a bitter finish.
This enters the realm of the blackness rubbing against your skin in a great furry way.  I can describe this beer and my cat at the same time.

~Strong chocolate aroma with wet coffee grinds, chocolate and coffee dominate over all other scents. Maybe also some oat like scent.
~Pours opaque black with small creamy tan head.
~Strong chocolate flavor with coffee. Taste like a homemade mocha. Coffee and hot chocolate mix.
~Med full bodied, med CO2, roasted coffee chocolate finish.
~ Good coffee stout. I drink coffee and hot chocolate mix every morning and this reminds me of drinking them. Could do with less CO2 bubbles to create a smoother feel. Still enjoyable brew.

11.2 ounce bottle.  Served in a Sam Adams BL glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch frothy brown head.  Head retention and lacing are both pretty good.  Aroma is roasted malt, coffee/espresso, chocolate, burnt/charred malt, and some dark fruit aroma also shows up as the beer warms.  The taste is pretty much the same as the aroma, but with the coffee/espresso flavors being the strongest.  Has a nice bitter and dry finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit creamy but also on the thin side for a stout.  Its also well carbonated.  Drinkability is good, its enjoyable and easy to drink.  Overall I think this is a good brew.  If you like coffee and/or espresso, then you would probably like this beer too.
Bottle.  Poured black with dark brown head.  Aroma of coffee, vanilla and fruit.  Flavour is roasty with coffee, vanilla, peach and chocolate notes.  Roasty finish.  A great stout!
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text:
Bottle: &nbsp Black, very slight deep ruby hues, moderate foamy beige head, few rings of lacing. &nbsp Fairly assertive coffee grounds on the nose. &nbsp Minor roasted malt, milk sugar, and cocoa. &nbsp Certainly smells like an 

Espresso Stout. &nbsp Tangy on the tongue, a little sharp, minor sourness, otherwise roasted malts, lactose like sweetness, with a good dose of coffee bean. &nbsp Even a minor hop presense. &nbsp Smooth, with a body and mouthfeel that 

are fairly moderate. &nbsp Finish is clean, lingering coffee bean and roasted malts. &nbsp Remains a bit sweet. &nbsp Not as big or hefty as most Stouts, which is welcomed in my book. &nbsp Very enjoyable, and tiz directly as the label 

states, an Espresso Stout.

Pours a lovely medium brown.  Great coffee roast aromas and then you get another java hit with the first sip then it drifts into an unexpected sweetness that really works.  Almost like a coffee drink at Starbucks.  I am a big Hitachino fan.

Pours Black, brown head. Strong aroma of coffee and roasted malt. Thick and rich. Strong coffee flavour very thick and rich. Very dry finish. It is a good stout. I like it but the complexity is not really there though. It is an excellent stout. But I could use a little more.

Smells dark, sweet, malty, coffee is present in the backround. Quite dark, really nice foamy brown head on pour but then it sort of dissipates and looks like theres tadpole eggs in it or something. Lacing is actually great though. Smooth creamy mouthfeel and very even flavour, nice strong malt and coffee flavour. Leaves a nice dark malt taste on the tounge.
sweet, rich, alcoholic. Tasty and filling. Just the thing for a winter treat.

A lot of good stuff in hre, but not as much as I expected. It is not smooth and really dries out your mouth. Tghere is lot of bitter black coffee taste. Definitely a stout and not an imperial stout, which I was hoping for. Not worth going out of your way for, IMO. Bottle from Knightly Spirits in Orlando.

Bottle. Pours black, with a thick medium-tan head, that is surprisingly presistent. Excellent lacing. Nose is rich coffee, surprisingly expressive considering how dry this stout is. Notes of ash, coffee, bitter chocolate, roast malt, and a hint of dark fruit. This is perhaps the driest coffee stout Ive had to date (although many of the comparables were Imperial Stouts, which are generally sweeter), this beer really reminds me of the Jerome stout, with its dry, dusty ashiness, and gunsmoke/flinty note, which I really like. In addition there is the mocha/cocoa notes that let you know this was brewed with coffee. Overall an excellent stout, one of the better ones Ive had.

An outstanding stout.  Think Guiness + a unique mixture of chocolate, coffee, nuts, fruit, and spice.  Pours great with a almost black body, with caramel head that lasts.  The taste is very unique but not overpowering.  Great drinkability.

720ml brown bottle. Black with garnet edges, opaque. Full creamy, thick brown head, good clinging lace. Coffee and chocolate nose, light hop hint. Flavour is dark chocolate, dark roasted coffee bean. Finish is roasty, bitter and long with coffee aftertaste. Soft carbonation. medium body, great drinkablilty. Becoming a quick fan of this brewery.

Black with a rich chocolate cream head. Aroma is dark coffee, a hint of chocolate and the now familiar Japanese scent. Smooth body! Rich coffee, Japanese familiar flavour, a bit of tin and some chocolate notes. Definately tasty.

Bottle. Pour was dark with a nice sustained dark tan head. Aroma was sweet with vanilla, chocolate, roast, and smooth espresso. Flavors were well balanced with more sweet malt, which made for a smooth drink. Very fine brew.

Superb beer...unexpected mix of subtle and in-your-face flavor, but just this side of over-the-top. Thick dark brown head, serious coffee note (of course), great aroma, smooth bitter finish with a nice touch of mollasses on the end. This beer has an interesting viscosity to it. Sampled from teh bottle @ 57.5F.

Black pour with thin brown head, aroma of sweet roasted malt, chocolate, and alcohol. Tastes of caramel malt and yeast, chocolate, vanilla and dark fruit. Nice bitter finish of roasted coffee. Great brew.

330 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Dark brown, almost black, pour with a thick tan head.  Aroma is pure dark roasted espresso.  Espresso dominates the palate but there is some dark chocolate and dark fruit as well.  The alcohol is undetectable.  I really, really liked this one.

330ml bottle.  Pours very dark brown, black in the glass, with a huge three-finger brown head.  Head eventually settles down to a light cap.  Rings of sticky spotty lacing.  Rather attractive.  Aroma big on coffee, with a slight funkiness, roasted malts, and some dark fruits.  Flavor is coffee, chocolate, dark cherries, and other dark fruits with a light sour tang.    Delicious.  Wonderful smooth creamy mouthfeel, low carbonation.  An excellent brew!  Only thing holding this back is the price @ $4.99/bottle.  Still worth it and Im glad I finally got around to trying this wonderful beer.

Black pour with a dark tan head that dissipates rather quickly. Aroma is dark roast coffee, cream, lactic sugar, dark chocolate, lightly roasted barley, and molasses. Flavor is unsweetened chocolate, cocoa nib, creamy mocha, roast, and gratuitous coffee notes. Palate is thick and rich for the style with a distinct caressing velvety smoothness and a dry chalky finish. Quite tantalizing.

Beautiful black pour, brown head, small but attractive. Aroma holds coffee, cream, sweet chocolate, caramel, roasted malt- really solid aroma. Flavor is also excellent; lots of coffee and roasted malt, along with caramel and cream and chocolate. Flavor notes are similar to the aroma, but hit in a different order; coffee is robust at the front and the bitter roast complements it well, then the sweet aspects come through closer to the finish. Palate is very full for a regular stout, and glides across the tongue beautifully. Really nice brew, particularly for a Japanese brewerys efforts on such a good style.

Very nice.  Has a strong coffee taste that I think would cover up any other delicate or less-pronounced flavors.  Only complaint would be that I didnt think it had the gravity or fullness I would expect from a stout.  However as a coffee snob as well, I loved it!

A lot of chocolate in the aroma-dark chocolate. A great great pour. Very black with thick dark head. Taste is thick, both chocolate and coffee. Finally a truly great beer form these gives, especially given their relatively high prices.

13th August 2008. Glorius thick tan head on this beer with a wonderful tangy coffee creaminess. The beer itself is opaque black with a very strong coffee flavour. Also has tang about it that borders on fruity. Not that bitter even in the finish which has that espresso roastiness about it. Thought I wouldnt like this beer. Very pleasantly surprised.

THOUGHTS: Almost mocha like. Incredible beer. I will buy this again if I can find it. Not super complex, but the flavors and aromas are perfect. Almost like a coffee drink instead of a beer. The best Asian beer I think Ive had so far and one of the best stouts overall. I recommend it highly.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown that was nearly black in the glass with slight red highlights and a small tan head that mostly diminished, but left good lacing. The aroma was heavy coffee and slightly less dark chocolate. The initial flavor was sweet and slightly sour; while the finish was sweet, a little sour and fairly bitter with a fairly duration, but consisting almost only of coffee bean. There was coffee, chocolate, fresh ground coffee, coffee beans, hints of vanilla, slight dark fruit, but mostly coffee bean, and roasted malt. There was also some bitter and sort of sour coffee. The overall flavor was more coffee bean than the actual coffee. The medium to full body was a little oily, yet creamy with very fizzy and tingly carbonation and a slightly chalky and lightly alcoholic finish.

Black colored with little beige head. Very rich aroma with real cocoa note, strong coffee roastiness also here, mild vanilla also comes up. Medium to full bodied, creamy palate. Flavor is similar with very rich and dry coffee-cocoa, some berries and dark chocolate also here. Aftertaste dries with berries still, roastiness and wood is also present.

Source: 12 oz bottle purchased at Cool Springs Wine and Spirits.
Glass: Brooklyn Pint.
Appearance: Dark black pour with a two finger brown head.
Aroma: Coffee dominates, with a hint of bitter chocolate.
Flavor: Pretty simple coffee and chocolate flavors.  Very well done.
Palate: Medium body with mild carbonation.
Overall: Excellent coffee stout.  Wish it werent so expensive though.

12oz bottle from somewhere in nyc... Pours a pretty dark brown with reddish brown edges... Burnt and really ashy with tons of coffee notes with vanilla... Flavors are very smooth with big coffee and roasted malt note.  Nice body and good all around flavor.

Brewed in Japan... Pours a very deep brown almost black in color with super foamy beige head that dissipates in time. Aroma of yeast, wood, milk chocolate and dark fruit. Taste of cheese, wood, cocoa powder and dark fruit. Mouthfeel is thin, but smooth and finishes on the dry bitter side. Not what i expected yet pretty interesting !!!

Bottle from Crown #6. Pours very pitch black with thin fading dark brown head. Nose is strong espresso, some brown sugar/burnt cookie, and roasted malt. Flavor is heavy on the coffee with a nice roasted malt taste and very thin. Very bitter overall, but has a nice strong flavor...mouthfeel just seems a little thin/distracting.

33 cl bottle at Haket, Göteborg. On Ocotber 10, 2009
Very dark brown to black color, brown head. Salty, acidic, coffee taste. 
Coffee aftertaste, also grainy. Dry grainy scent. A bit thin mouthfeel, low bitterness.

~ Purchased this 330 ml bottle from New Beer Distributors in Manhattan, NY. Appearance is a deep dark brown color with a creamy tan head. The aroma is predominately coffee, followed by some hints of chocolate. Taste is the same. Body is medium to full. The incredible flavors do an exceptional job at masking the 7.5% ABV like its not even there! There is no bitterness, just a smooth tasting stout that leaves behind a wonderful aftertaste.

When it comes to brewing quality beer, the Japanese really know what they are doing. 

Highly recommended! ~

Pours a thick dark brown with a large tan head that eventually lowers and appears two tone from the side. Big stout aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malts, lactose, and vanilla. Strong and sweet flavor, lots of roast, coffee, and chocolate. Bitters nicely. Creamy rich mouthfeel with faint carbonation. Delicious.

Honestly, I had heard great things about this one. I had it on draft at Mahaffreys pub--a reputable beer bar thats the best of Canton--and it was a major dissapointment. Beer had oxidation and tons of flavors of metallic ice cubes and bread yeast. Very medium palate and a bit watery, especially on the beerest flavors as in malts hops and anything roasted....it tasted like a yeasty cocoa-ey mess. Ill have to try this one again, but I was very let down.

Bottle. Pours a thick dark black color with a foamy tan head. Head gushed from the bottle upon opening and was very creamy. Nose is coffee and chocolate up front and a heavy lactose and cream note. Palate is thick and creamy with a light fizz and bitterness in the finish. Flavor is heavy on the coffee and roasted malt with a nice milk chocolate flavor.

Bottle - thanks beerbaron420.  Pours a deep brown color with a finger of rich brown head.  Lots of bubbles; visibly well-carbonated.  Aroma is certainly an intense coffee smell with lots of bitters and just a little sweet cocoa.  Tastes rich in coffee with a little roastiness and light amounts of dark chocolate.  The espresso is the theme here and definitely takes the lead.  Rich and lingering finish.  Nice.

12oz bottle. Pours a black body with a two-finger width, dark brown, foamy and rocky head that fizzed out of the bottle upon opening and left a foamy lacing. Aroma is sour dark fruits, a light woody chocolate, and barely a hint of roasty coffee. Flavor is a little better with a distinguished roasty coffee. Starts with a sour cherry, dark fruit, light maltiness with some milky chocolate and acidity. Roasty coffees throughout with a blackberry acidity. Finishes with a chocolate, acidic berry roast-coffee with a bit of a burnt taste. Dry with an acidic roast, berry chocolate coffee aftertaste. Light to medium bodied with a higher level of carbonation. Overall, Ive come to expect the acidic taste in most of the Japanese beers I try. This is no different. A nicer, fuller flavor with plenty of roasty coffee, but Im still not digging the berry acidity taste that these beers keep offering. I like my American stouts.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of toasted, dark chocolate and strong coffee, moderate resin and earth for the hops and yeast, with wood, tar and solvent in the background. Head is average size, frothy/fizzy, light brown with fair lacing and is almost fully diminishing. color is very dark brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then the long finish is moderately acidic, heavily bitter and a little sour. Palate is medium to full, oily, with a soft carbonation and finishes chalky, lighty astringent and very dry, like chewing on fine coffee grounds. This is a powerful and robust Stout, but a few off characteristics knocks it down a bit for me.

Pours black as night with a 3 finger, very creamy, burnt sienna head that has great retention, but becomes alot chunkier over time and leaves some nice lacing. Aroma is roast, milk chocolate, lots of espresso, vanilla, hot cocoa, tree bark and some ethanol. Flavor is roast, stale coffee, more tree bark like tartness, cocoa powder, light caramel, vanilla, havarti cheese, light dark fruit notes. Finishes with roast, char, espresso, pretty strong bitter hops and cocoa powder fade. Palate is creamy and a little slick all the way up the the finish where it dries out quite a bit really suddenly, which I dont find to be the most pleasant. Overall I think this brew could cut back on the bitter hops and chocolate a bit and get rid of the odd, tart flavors, they dont really work well with this stuff, however weak they are. That being said, I still really enjoyed this stout, I really think it would be absolutely phenomenal if the above changes were made though.

12 oz stubby compliments of an extra from Beerlando. Bryan, you are the man. My first Hitachino brew. Pours a near black opaque pour with moderate darker brown head that laces ok, dies to a decent layer eventually. Aromas are interesting, a touch sour with coffee and chocolate, lactose, with some lighter roasty character but a strange almost sourness comes out on the nose. Almost, cheesy? Initial is creamy, a bit of vanilla and lactose stand behind espresso, coffee grounds, and dark chocolate that bitter well. Roasty, but still smooth. A strange lactose feel comes in, a bit sour almost but moving to almost a custard creamy vanilla that tempers and balances the roasted malts. Light bitterness, roast in the finish with a lingering creamy smoothness and sweetness. Interesting, to say the least.

Sample at JaBiers refrigerator reduction tasting on 08/15/09. The beer is an opaque black color with a medium tan head that diminishes steadily. Small patches of lace. Aroma of weak coffee and chocolate. Medium body with a strong bitter (nearly acidic) coffee flavor as well as some grainy malt and spiced hops. The finish is dry and bitter with a coffee aftertaste. Overall this was an okay Stout but I would have enjoyed it a lot more if the coffee had more of a roasted character versus bitter.

Dark brown to black in color. Not much head. Typically coffee, roast, espresso flavors. Light chocolate as well. Medium to light bodied for a high alc stout. Better than I expected, but not as good as the average score posted here. Good Stout overall. One of the best of the Hitachino beers.

Bottle at my refrigerator reduction tasting on 8/15/09.  Pitch black pour with a medium tan head.  Espresso bean aroma with malt, creamy chocolate and a hint of licorice.  Creamy malt flavor with some chocolate and a lasting bitter coffee finish.  Probably best beer of the night I hadnt had before.

Beautiful black pour black with creamy-looking, thick mocha head. The mocha head reappears with each agitation. This is a beautiful work of art. Aroma of canned chocolate syrup, dark roast coffee, soy sauce, and a slight hint of grass. Flavor is grounded coffee beans, Hersheys chocolate syrup, wheat, and grass. Moderately creamy mouthfeel. The finish of bitter hops is surprisingly strong. Im not into the earthy notes in this. It seems like an odd sidekick to the dark roast flavors of a coffee stout.

Tap at Blind Tiger. Poured a deep rich black with a thin beige head. Big coffee and chocolate nose. Mouthful was slightly on the thin side for the style, but flavor was rich and complex with great chocolate and coffee notes, and a firm bitter finish.

On tap at The Ginger Man 
Appearance:   dark brown with creamy fine top , fine lace noted. 4-Nose: deep roasty espresso nose , very slight sourness on sides. Bit of chocolate on top. Gentle long lsting aroma. 8-Flavor/Palate : Bold , dry roasty character welcomes you up front. Cocoa , coffee nd dry roasted barley.  Good , bold rich with espresso side ale.
Poured black with a medium tan head.  Aroma was strong coffee, chocolate, molasses.  Taste was coffee, dark chocolate, slight bitter, alcohol.  Pretty good beer.

Notes from Seattle International Beer Festival. Obviously smells strongly of coffee and chocolate. Not sure how "espresso" is included, but it certainly has enough coffee to provide an espresso-like jolt. Dark, black even, with a slightly sweet finish.
Smells of espresso.  Flavor is espresso bean.  Little sour on the finish.  Balanced well.

Poured a nice black hue with a moderate tan head with decent retention.Aroma had a good coffee note and some cocoa.  Flavor seemed to have a good mix with nice roasted coffee notes and some cocoa. Finish was smooth. Really light though.

This poured a nice opaque black with a big tan head. Aroma was really roasted, coffee notes as well. Flavor was was really dark and roasted, but not overdone, rather smooth hints of chocolate. This one has a great balance of coffee and sweetness.
Bottle. Pours deep dark black. Huge roasty aromas along with coffee & chocolate. Taste is roasty, chcolate, coffee, hints of vanilla. Nice mouth feel . Nice beer

Bottle. Poured black with a brown head. Aroma consisted of alcohol and coffee notes, quite acidic. Flavor is nice and full of dark espresso notes which leads to a quite acidic beer. Quite one note but I still enjoyed it.
Nice coffee flavor. More espresso with a little bit of bitterness in the body. A good round beer with a chewy body, almost.
Bottle: pours dark black with a frothy tan head, aroma of coffee and spices, taste is coffee, malt, chocolate, some bitterness, fairly thin mouthfeel for a stout but it is well balanced.

Opens with notes of espresso, chocolate and a bit of spice. Pours a deep black, opaque. Large bubbles with high carbonation. Deep mahogany head with little retention. Opens with caramel and coffee. Sweet with balanced bitterness in the middle and a long finish that sticks to the palate. Mouthfeel is medium high thanks to the carbonation keeping it sprightly. This is an excellent blend of espresso and beer. The balance is great and doesnt give you that coffee overkill! The sweetness keeps it tasty and makes you crave another drink.

brown/black pour, mocha notes compliment the thick espresso taste, there was a grittiness I wasnt expecting, but overall, strong stout with heavy malts and a borderline bitter finish. only for coffee stout lovers.

4 oz. pour at Seattle International Beer Festival. Dark black with 1/2 inch thick brown foamy head. Sweet aroma. Very thin with mild coffee taste. Grainy taste that is kind of funky. Not that great. Should have only been one ticket.

4 oz. taster at Seattle IBF.  Pours black with a brown head.  Aroma is purely fruits, roast, and alot of graininess.  Flavor is hoppier than expected, roasty coffee, pretty dry.  Mouthfeel is a little too thin, medium bodied with lots of carbonation.
Pours black with foamy tan head.  Amazing aroma of roasted coffee, vanilla and chocolate.  Very smooth drinking, strong espresso flavor.  Cant find another bottle of this soon enough!
Bottle. Pours black with a thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Lightly sweet upfront with a bitter finish.

Bottle 330ml.Clear dark black color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, coffee, heavy burnt, moderate chocolate. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and heavy bitter with a long duration. Instant coffee bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090320]

pours black and thick with a thick tan head aromas of coffee lots off coffee,vanilla,chocolate and roasted maltsflavor is of of mainly coofee with a little chocolate and vanilla seeping thur creamy sweet and smooth
Really? The aroma smelled of cheap coffee. Appearance was black with mocha head. Flavor has cheap coffee flavor and a hint of chocolate. Palate was bubbly. Not impressed. Overrated in my book.
Strong flavor, strong aftertaste.  This is a heavy beer.  One to sip and savory.  Very good but a little overpowering for me.

Black oily body and massive lasting light brown head. Smell of coffee, caramel, and roasted grains. Tastes like dark chocolate, sweet malts with a heavy coffee roast. Glorius! Chocolate and coffee rule supreme. A very thick rich palate, medium finish.

The beer pours a jet black with a deep reddish brown head and some decent retention. The aroma is complex with deep coffee and sweet roasty malt with a little cherry like sourness. The espresso dominates the flavor of this stout. The roasty flavors are abound and the beer is very bitter and mildly smoky with a nice little burnt toast thing going on. Are we sure this isnt an imperial stout, this certainly rides the line if anything.

330ml bottle. Pours black with a huge creamy tan head that looks like a sponge. Nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and sweet malts. Big espresso flavor with dark chocolate, vanilla, and hint of balancing sweetness. Light and smooth on the palate. An excellent, drinkable coffee stout.

330 ml bottle from Country Club Liquors. Nose of espresso, coffee, light vanilla, and chocolate.  Black with a medium, glass-lacing, tan head. Flavor is heavy coffee, light bitterness, and some vanilla and pepperiness.
pours black with a large tan head. aroma is COFFEE and espresso with some chocolate, malt, and sweetness. drinks similar with tons and tons of espresso/dark coffee.

330ml bottle pours black liquid with a big beige long-lasting head. The aroma of strong coffe,malt,sweetness.Mouth feel medium and silky smooth. The flavor is lightly sweet. espresso, with a full malty  light bitterness. There isnt a complexity that would be nice, but the light espresso bitterness lingers on and on. Finishes with long chocolaty bitterness, dried fruit, and of course espresso. I wasnt so sure of it at the first few sips, but it definitley grows on you. If you like coffe and you like beer, then kanpai!

Bottle. Pours a black color with a longlasting tan head. Has a roasted malty espresso coffee aroma. Roasted malty coffee flavor with some hitns of chocolate. Has a roasted malty bitter espresso coffee finish.

Bottled at Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Very black, beige head. Aroma of tabasco and espresso. Dryish and lightly sourish with strong coffee flavour. Medium bodied with heavyheanded roastiness. Long salty bitterness. Interesting and powerful, but also oily and a bit too sourish.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm) Pitch black colour with frothy, brown head. Roasted, malty nose with distinct notes of freshly ground, heavily roasted coffee and dark bitter chocolate. Roasted, malty taste with strong black coffee, cocoa powder, hints of dark fruit and prunes, and a dry finish with a generous coffee bitterness. Medium body with smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Dry. Maybe a bit one dimensional, but a lovely beer with and impressive coffee character.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of espresso, slight tart fruit, chocolate, cream, light roasted malts, and hints of berries and vanilla.  Poured pitch black in color with a small brown head that lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of espresso, bitter chocolate, roasted malts, slight sugar, and some cream.  Medium to full body.  Very chalky texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly bitter, chocolate coffee, and slight sugar finish is chalky and lightly dry.

Bottled at Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in an opaque black colour with a rich bubbly beige foam. Rich and almost in your face espresso aroma with notes of dark chocolate. Medium to full-bodied with notes o cocoa, espresso and nuts. Compact yet elegant airy mouthfeel. Long aftertaste of dark coffee, almonds, brown sugar and salt.

Bottle at Monks Wallingatan, Stockholm.
Pours black with a rather big and dark brown head. Smells of coffe, chocolate and sometihing burnt or smokey like a whiskey barrel aged beer. The aroma develops and changes over time as the beer gets warmer.
Smoothest imperial stout Ive ever tasted!
Tastes of coffe, rosted malt and some acid like in a very dark chocolate.

Bottle. Look: Black, big and thick beige head. Smell: Complex. Coffee, chocolate, someting bourbon-like (and smokey). Taste: Lots of coffee, some strange sharp flavor, (acid) dark chocolate, nutty. Lacks of real power/character. Overall: Full bodied, thick and incredible smooth. Well made and unusual stout.

From bottle at Wachi, Kyoto. Almost black with a creamy, persistent, light brown head. Strongly roasted aroma. Tastes like an over- roasted espresso, like a wake-up call, but hiding its strength nicely. Body could be fuller. Still an impressive specimen.

Pours a dark brown color, with a medium-small tan head.  Aroma is coffee and roasted malts.  The flavor is certainly a nice, balanced coffee flavor, that isnt too overpowering, but serves up a nice powerful kick that any coffee and beer lover would enjoy.
Black with a half-inch tan head. Aroma of coffee and sharp, roasted malt. Flavor is much the same with a very starchy, ricey thing going on. Didnt care for it.

The pour was thick dark brown, threatened to be viscous at one point in fact.  The head was brown and more robust than I expected.  The initial aroma was very nice.  Rich chocolate that reminded me for a moment of Breakfast Stout.  Coffee comes out as well.  The flavor was coffee, chocolate and some almost sour, acidic flavors that were quite distracting.  Mouthfeel was almost medium in body and the finish had the aforementioned acidic, sourness that left me a bit disappointed.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2010 11.2oz bottle.  Pour is black with tan head. Nose is sharpie.  Taste is dark chocolate, burnt malt, charcoal, cigar, espresso and maybe black licorice. Mouthfeel is medium, medium full.  A big brew but pretty approachable.

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of yespr/Ungstrup. Pours black and opaque with a light brown head. Distinctly burned coffee aroma. Medium body with very burned malt accents and coffee. Burned, malt bitter finish. 200309

From the first pour, this one was obviously a good stout, produced a good amount of head after the pour.  Had a nice aroma, and a relatively strong coffee taste, but not overpowering.  Still found hints of chocolate and toffee.

Bottle.  Poured Black with a short brown head.  Nose is full of burnt malt and espresso.  Flavor is major espresso some roasted/burnt malts, anise, a little smoke, and a very mild sourness.  Nice warming alcohol.  Finishes dry with coffee and a touch of wood.

Orlando, Fl.- Knightly Spirits - 330 ml bottle. Pours a nice tar black with a thin, but sticky mocha colored head. Very fragrant aroma with tons of fresh dark espresso and a bit of bittersweet chocolate. Bold flavor with some chocolate syrup, unsweetened espessso, some earthiness and a back end of roastiness and a hint of pepper. Mouthfeel is thick and rich,. Probably the best I have had from these folks.
Pours black with a medium mocha head which fades quickly.  Aroma is stale coffee, with some earthy astringency.  Taste is much better.....a decent amount of mocha, cocoa, and some vanilla.  Deec.

Thanks to my bro for sharing this.  Pours a deep dark brown color with thin tan head.  Aroma is of stale coffee, you know, the last bit of sludge in your coffee that is ice cold.  Ugh, the aroma made me think this would be an epic fail.  Anyway, but the taste, man the taste is great.  Large amounts of french roasted coffee and chocolate and toaste grain.  Finish is creamy and clean just what I was hoping for.  Good stuff.
what a hidden gem... tons of coffee in this one, big soapy head ... amazinly smooth .. great aftertaste .. a coffee lovers dream... i drink this in my coffee mug in the mornings..

Dark black pour with a dark brown head. Aroma is of roasted malt with hints of coffee. Taste Taste is of roasted malt, but it has a real bitter aftertaste which leaves a dry mouth feel. The bitterness does subside a little but it is too much. The head lasted the whole drink leaving a nice lace. Loved the aroma.

Bottle (330ml).  Poured deep chestnut red, impenetrable once in the glass - very large and lasting frothy tan head (4-).  Dry aroma, complex - deep nutty roast, alcohol, raisin, coffee, and lactose.  The taste follows, natch - dryer, more lactic and stronger coffee notes - quite acidic - seems to have a bit of cranberry or tart cherry lingering in the background.  Average body, decent carbonation, and a long roasty + bitter finish.  Very solid, really makes you puzzle over it .... * now I read it, I can totally get the RIS base to this one, its borderline imperial.

Bottle.
Dark brown coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Light roasted aroma of fresh grinded coffee with notes of dried fruits.
Roasted flavour of fresh grinded coffee with notes of dried fruits and liquorice.
Roasted finish of coffee.
Bottle, 7.5%. Good coffee aroma. Black colour. Very small brown head. Good, distinct flavour, some coffee, strong liquorice. Some yeast, a little smoke. Creamy finish. Quite good.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a thin dark brown head. The aroma is very sweet with strong notes of roasted malt and espresso coffee. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, chocolate, espresso coffee, and abit of wood, leading to a dry roasted coffee finish.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a light redish rim and a small chocolate brown head. Roasted malt, chocolate and herbal coffee aroma. Dry and dense chocolate malty flavoured with a distinct coffee bitterness coming through. Smooth vanilla notes too. Ends slight herbal and roasted coffee flavoured and bitter. Chocolate into the very far finish.

12 oz bottle courtesy of daknole. Pours an opaque black with a generous tan head. The aroma is rich with multilayer coffee and mocha sensations. The flavor does not quite live up to the aroma there is plenty coffee but it is a bit of an "old grounds" taste. The finish is long with lingering coffee. The mouthfeel was just a bit thin with an acidic quality. Overall: I really the aroma of this but the taste just did not measure up. Still, a fairly good brew. Thanks dakine.

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge, Lisle, IL. Served in a trappist glass. A rich, black/brown pour with a thick, foamy, light brown head and solid, clingy lacing. The aroma was roasty, with  bitter espresso and dark chocolate and a little cream mixed in. The flavor was also roasty, bitter, espresso, bakers chocolate, with a little molasses thrown in. Full bodied with a rich, silky mouthfeel. Impressive variation of the style.

Smell consists of chocolate and coffee, a little chalky, but excellent aroma none the less. Aroma also consists of come vanilla. The pour is black with a  large brownish tan head. Flavor is prominantly cofee with some bitterwseet chocolate. A little funky, slightly burnt malt.

Bottle...  Poured a great looking deep brown--almost black--with a light brown head that lasted forever.  Aroma of cigarette smoke and coffee.  Tasted of roasted grains, soil and had a vinegary aspect to it.  It was a good brew but kind of funky.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is sweet, dry, coffee. Flavour is sweet, coffee, mocca, dried fruits. Full bodied nice beer.
Pours black with a sizable tan head - perfect looking stout. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Has a warm coffee flavor plus chocolate and caramel. Very enjoyable

Appearance: Dark chocolate with a tan head.

Smell: First impression is a frappacino not beer. A little chocolate and hint of vanilla. Smell roasted malts and a little yeast.

Taste: A medium to full bodied beer. Starts with a nice a sweet coffee flavor transitioning to a little bitterness (but not overwhelming). 

Mouthfeel: Has a slight oily consistency but leaves your mouth feeling dry at the end. Has a fizzy light carbonation.

Not something I would drink often. You need to be in the mood for something other than a normal beer. But if you are looking for something between coffee and beer. I think you would like this.
good solid stout, definite, (obviously) strong coffe tones, very prominant.  Good stuff.

Bottle. It pours a dark, dark brown body with a reddish glow and a small, tan head. Dry and dusty on the nose, wtih coffee, mocha and some notes of celeriac. The flavor has some sweetness, but is mostly on the dry side, with mocha, coffee, some celeriac and a nice bitterness to finish it off. Full-bodied. A really pleasant coffee-ish beer, even for a non-coffee drinker as me. Maybe a bit one-tracked. (081229)
Bottle.  Dark black pour with cookie colored head.  Aroma of sweet espreso and not much else.  Flavor was sweet, strong coffee and finished with a litte vanilla.  One of my favorite coffee beers.

Pours very dark brown with brown head. Aroma of coffee grounds, burnt malts and chocolate. Slightly sweet with lots of coffee with some chocolate and caramel. Mild sourness and bitterness also. Full body with above average carbonation for a stout. Nice creamy mouthfeel. A very nice brew.

Had this on draft.  Basically the best way to describe it is iced coffee meets a beer.  Excellent color, aroma, flavor.  Did not think the Japanese could make a beer this good.  Great last beer of the night.

Pours a pitch black with a lovely thin brown head with decent retention. Aroma is dark chocolate & coffee, light alcohol. Nice roasty astringent coffee more than balances a sweet stout base. Lingering coffee finish, light tang to it. Thin body with a bit of creaminess to it, reasonable carb. This one is quite tasty - would have done with a bit more body, but beggars cant be choosers!
12 oz pours pitch with a tan head. aroma is coffee with some tartness that seems misplaced. mouthful is coffee and some more coffee. very nice, as i love coffee almost as much as beer ;)
Bottle from Rustico, VA. Very dark brown espresso appearance. Strong coffee and chocolate aroma. Balanced taste. Clean finish. A great combination of coffee and beer.

Small bottle from PF Changs.  Pours near very dark brown with nice sustained brown head.  Excellent roasty coffee aroma.  Flavor of chocolate, cocoa, coffee was not overbearing which I really liked.  Nice velvety body.  But it is horribly expensive, so I have to dock it a point.

Bottle from City Beer Store in SF.  I just wasnt really that impressed with this one overall.  Someone I was tasting with commented that, "Its like a cold cup of coffee."  It has some quality that makes it similar to Hitachino White strangely.

Appearance is dark brown with a huge tan head that takes forever to go down.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and some funk.  Flavor is coffee, roasted malt, and a sort of sour Japanese quality that I cant quite describe.  Not particularly strong flavor overall.  A little creamy and pretty smooth on the palate.

33cl bottle from Whole Foods (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark brown cola cola color with a massive tannish-yellow two finger head that settles slowly. Aroma is roasted and malty with notes of coffee, pine, juniper, chocolate, asian spice some faint sweetness. Flavor is roasted and malty as well with notes of coffee bean, asian spice, dark chocolate, some caramel and honey sweetness. Generally medium to full body with a roasted malty and spicy finish.
Bottle. Poured deep black with a tan darkish head. Aroma is definitely coffee. Flavor is rich, cream and coffee, with a bit of fruity esther at the end.

Bottle, $4.49.  Pours a rich dark brown with a wispy brown head.  Aroma of strong, black espresso and ash; downright menacing.  And this is from the same country that puts out wimpy-light stuff like Asahi and Sapporo??  Flavor starts with dark chocolate bitter black coffee beans, sweetening slightly with some vanilla and brown sugar in the mid-palate, before finishing with assertive roasts and coffee.  As an avid coffee drinker, this brew makes me very, very happy.  Its like finally finding a restaurant willing to truly cook spicy food:  this brew has unmistakable dark, bitter coffee bean presence. Reminds me of a more balanced version of my favorite coffee stout, Peche Mortel.  I only wish there was a touch more carbonation to liven the flavors.  Delicious!

Served on draft as part of the Black Moonday event at Capital Alehouse in Richmond, VA. Pours a caramel brown color with coffee, oak and cherry notes. Taste is dry roasted coffee w/ cherry and other stone fruits. Full bodied.

Pitch black coloured body, 90% opaque with a very large dense deep brown head. Aroma of funky sweet malt, candy, cherries, cherries and a bunch of vanilla. Medium-bodied; Strong assertive roasted malt up front with cherries and vanilla very noticeable. Aftertaste shows some oak, a lot of sweetness, fake sugars and a bit of a coffee finish. Overall, not much of the coffee is noticeable, more of the fake sugars and a super strong amount of cherries too. Good to try, but not my favourite sweet stout! I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Clarendon (Arlington), Virginia on 22-October-2008, sampled at home in Washington on 24-January-2009.
Thick, near-black pour with a moderate brown head that leaves generous lace. Rich coffee and chocolate aroma and palate. Sweet, with a fruit-nuanced mid-palate and a dry finish. Excellent.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark black color with a huge very dark brown head. The aroma was bitter and roasty with notes of anise and basil. The flavor with bitter, tangy, roasty and odd with light fruitiness, a touch of coffee and notes of anise and basil. Disappointing.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2009 Re-rate (5/19/09): Draft at BEVERIDGE PLACE BODACIOUS BEVERAGES BREWFEST 09.  Super chocolate malts dominate flavor and aroma.  Not as much coffee as I would have preferred as I but you can still pick up.  Very lively on the tongue with a mild bitter finish.

This poured a pitch black color with a tan head. The aroma contains some chocolate, espresso, and licorice. The flavor is slightly bitter but also sweet as well. I taste some chocolate, espresso, and also a hint of some dark fruit giving it a slight sourness. The mouthfeel is rather thick. Overall a very nice stout.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 Bottle from Windmill Farms. Pours pitch black in color. Sweet aroma with a lot of coffee and chocolate. Smooth mouth feel. Strong coffee flavors. Some sweetness as well as burnt roasted coffee and chocolate. Very tasty stout. A must for coffee lovers.

Bottle sampled Pours jet black with a light brown head.Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, and a hint of smoke. Flavor is full bodied and complex with coffee, roast, chocolate and some vanilla notes and has a bitter chocolate finish. An excellent stout

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2012  A Christmas stout for 2008.  The stout poured a deep black with a brown head that overflowed my pint glass.  The aroma of coffee beans hits you immediately.  This is a big stout with flavors of chocolate, coffee and malts. Not being a coffee drinker this is over kill with espresso flavors. Enjoyed my second at a local restaurant.  This one flavors of tobacco. Christams 2011 tasted another.  This one was very cold and the coffee was slow to express itself.  I  tasted more chocolate this time.  the afertaste hasa coffee that hangs in the top your mouth.
Blach with huge beige head. Loads of coffee in the aroma with wooddy and bitter notes. Sweet and bitter flavour with dark bitter chocolatde, woody and coffee notes. Not bad.

Black light brown edges, two thick fingers of puffy tan head.  Green unroasted coffee aroma.  Over roasted malts and typical Hitachino woody spiciness.  Fresh pressed espresso taste over a light but roasty malt body.

[bottle - 330 ml] Dark black pour with a fizzy and lasting tan head. Aroma is dark and roasty with copious amounts of coffee, malt, and some cream. Flavor is sweet at the beginning with a good hint of chocolate that goes to a smooth and roasty middle of espresso, cream, cocoa, and some vanilla. Finishes smooth and bitter like espresso with a nice roasted taste that stays for a while.
Bottle. Deep black color with dark tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate. Tastes the same. The coffee flavor does not have that ash taste like some coffee stouts. Nice.

Pours a dark black that allows some light. One finger creamy chestnut brown head. Very nice looking. The nose is roasty, mild bakers chocolate, coffee, definitely notes of sweet and dark fruits, mild tartness. The flavor is roasty, coffee, bitter coffee and chocolate feel, mild fruity tartness. Very interesting stout, lots going on.
Deep maroon color with very thin tan head.  Aroma of coffee, flavor of malt and light chocolate with unsubtle coffee overtones.  No surprise I suppose.  Well balanced overall.
Bottle.  Pours a dark mahogany with a small tan head.  Deep roasted aromas of coffee, chocolate, and malt.  Thin body with a light but long lasting finish.

Pours a thick pitch black with a fantastic tan and brown rocky swirl of a head on top.   Rich espresso bean aroma, quality roasted beans not some cheap crap, creamy rich vanilla and cream with some lovely chocolate covered fruit notes.  Probably the best aroma of any coffee stout.   Wow some serious yum.  Excellent dry espresso bean finish.  Flavor is soooo creamy like a milkstout, mellow vanilla, faint burntness, chocolate covered cherries, balanced coffee taste.  I love the dryness, doesnt muck the focus up with molasses flavors.  This beer demands some respect.  Super drinkable body, creamy with fine active sharp carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2008 11.2 ounce bottle.  Poured into a nonic.  Pours out like chocolate syrup, fills the glass pitch black with a very dark tan head.  Billowing foam despite a very cold serving temperature, thick chunks of lace, crazy retention.  Aroma is very robust.  Sweetened coffee, roast, dark chocolate, and a bit of soy sauce.  Flavor is black coffee, a slight vegetal note, coffee grounds, bitter chocolate.  A little astringent.  Dry bitter finish.  Body is a touch too thin.  Pretty good beer.
bottle, tar pitch color with wispy crema, nose is a vegetal roast with syrupy flavor of soybeans, coffee and cocoa, nice bitterness on the finish

(Bottle).  Sweet roasty aroma, vegetable and fruit notes.  Black body, fluffy lasting brown head.  Flavor is sweet coffee and chocolate, ripe fruits, roastiness.  A little too sweet overall, but still enjoyable.

Bottle.  Pours a deep black with a 2 finger fluffy tan head and chunky head.  Nose is coffee grounds, roasty malts and cocoa.  Taste is chalky cocoa, burnt malt and coffee grounds.  Medium creamy mouth feel.  Reminds me a lot of Bells Java Stout, and the Bells version isnt $5+ a bottle.

330 mL bottle. Pours a menacing used motor oil black with a powerful dark brown head- fierce. Okay lacing. Aromas of- surprise- espresso, whole Kenyan coffee beans, dark chocolate, raw cocoa. Does not smell like a stout but rather just a straight up great cup of coffee. Taste though is not too overpowered by the coffee- the roasted malts shine through. Mouthfeel is creamy but the body is slightly thin. Aftertaste is dry, bitter, and surprisingly sour. A very interesting brew albeit pricey. I wish it were more intense and went all out.

Pours thick and rich, viscous black with aerated brown head that dissipates fast. Enormous coffee bean aroma, like stickng nose into a bag of beans. Dark roast, would never believe it were anything but coffee if blindfolded except for the whisper of chocolate malt. Fizzier and thinner body than expected. Lingering roasted malt and coffee in the aftertaste. Not burnt. Some lactic sourness at the sides of the tongue and a strange bitterness both detract from the experience. Poorly priced at $4.75 for small bottle in store.

In short: A full bodied chocolaty-coffee stout. Very satisfying. How: Bottle 12oz, consumed fresh a month or two after receiving it as a bonus in a trade. Sorry I forget who sent it to me, but thanks a lot man for this fine brew. The look: Black body topped by a medium tan head. In long: Nose is roasted with some coffee beans. Body is pleasantly full, creamy yet roasted. For an Espresso stout the taste is not really dominated by coffee. A ton of dark malts, chocolate and cacao, espresso, roasted coffee beans, a light astringency (lemony hops?) in the finish increases drinkability. This is very tasty and with a big body showing that you dont need a 9%+ beer to make a heavy stout. This one proves that bigger is not better, and unsurprisingly it comes from Japan.

What a pleasant surprise.Great nose of caramel  and coffee. More carbonated than most Russian Imperial Stouts but this led to a balancing lightness and a great mouthfeel. Sort of like Peche Mortel lite. Love it.

12 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a dark brown color with a small tan head. Faint lacing. Aroma is coffee, tobacco, and esters. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, tobacco, chocolate, and esters. Dry palate. Light to medium body. A nice beer, just a little pricey.

A good balance between coffee and beer. Flavor has a really good mix of the two, with some nutty overtones, but for some reason falls a little flat. Taste is good but has a weird sour astringent character too it. Some fresh melon. Slightly thin.
Black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is espresso, roasted malts, dark chocolate.   Taste is dry with espresso, chocolate, light alcohol.

Bottle (330ml). Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with a large lasting frothy tan head. Aroma: Weird, I get jalapenos first and foremost followed by espresso, dark malt and a hint of chocolate. Flavour: Again I’m getting jalapenos, which is odd I think, along with espresso, some chocolate and light hops. Average roasty/bitter finish. Medium bodied. The jalapeno aspect of this beer doesn’t belong here in my opinion, it’s a detriment to what would otherwise be a good Stout -- as it is I find it just O.K. -- I am obviously in the minority though based on most of the other ratings, oh well, different strokes and all that...

Basically black.  Tan head.  Roasty, vegetal chocolatey aroma.  Rich character.  Burnt bitterness.  Some vegetal bean stuff, hints of scorched cherries.  A bit too heavy on that vegetal character - good espresso does not taste like that.

Bottle from Sam’s. Pours black with a small tan head.  Strong coffee, dark fruits,  cocoa, and char throughout. Velvety mouth feel with a nice warm and roasty finish.  A  very tasty beer overall that I will definitely have again.
UPDATED: NOV 28, 2008 A good solid strong stout, alyhough it has minimal coffee nose or flavour. It does come out more as it warms up however.

Bottle.  This beer smells awesome.  Loads of coffee accents of vanilla, some coco, and chocolate.  Never gets sweet just overpowered by the coffee bitterness and hints of vanilla.  A must try a treat.

I have a very bright LED light and I shined it on the other side of the glass. . . couldn’t even see a hint of light. No joke.
Caramel, chocolate, hint of mint and strong coffee flavor (I don’t like coffee yet I like this beer).  One of if not the best Coffee beers that I have ever had. 
More than full bodied, perfect dark,  and delicious.
Buy me.

Bright and powerful espresso edge, pretty acidic and sharp. Soft earthy character to it, almost like charred chocolate and oak in the finish. I enjoyed this beer after the initial overwhelming espresso sharpness dulled my palate. Its a nice stout, just with a massive coffee edge.

Creamy stout with a powerful chocolate flavor.  The palate has a slight smokiness which has a alcohol overtone.  This stout is deep and thick with a viscous body. There is a deep dark borwn head with a moderate lacing.

Dark brown with large tan head, long lasting despite receding and leaving lacing all over the glace. Nose reminds of Founders, vegetal bean deluxe, some tobacco and smoke, and yet theres also this odd raisin/burnt sugar scent. Flavor carries more tobacco and coffee, and probably vanilla. As it warms, vanilla and chocolate are well-incorporated, so its never singular and over-bitter. Moderate sized body, rather creamy. It doesnt go as far overboard with the coffee and thus allows room for other stuff, and so I think I prefer it to Mikkellers and Founders. Still, coffee stouts arent really my thing.

sweet coffee aroma; that motor oil pour, thick and sparkling brown head, moderate lacing; dark fruits, coffee, roasted chocolate, sugar; pretty tasty, but it ends somewhat bitter and fruity like fruit that sat out for an extra day, and served with some old coffee... meh.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2013 11.2oz from Sams, Durham. Very appealing aroma, initially strong roasts that (to me) specifically recalled Bells Java. But theres a softness to this brew, almost a lactic, sweet stout quality that makes this one sort of a hybrid. Sweet stout and chocolate malts, with intensely bitter espresso, dry but not too burnt, which is quite nice and lets the finest qualities of the bean itself come through. Substantial body, smooth mouthfeel. A good one.

My Bottom Line:
This Stout’s lush mouthfeel expresses roasted caramel maltiness and lenient coffee in a chewy and lightly bitter vehicle.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-Thick foam covers the pitch darkness.
-This bottle feels a tad old, which may have affected the coffee aroma somewhat.
-The roasted caramel takes on pumpernickel and molasses allusions as well.
-Its rich body is one of its best features.
-Some roasted malt bitterness finishes each sip.

Bottle.

Getting notebook online. Bottle. Pours a coffee black with a slight cream head. Espresso on the nose is a little subtle. Flavors are not. Real good espresso flavors with some dried fruit and vanilla accents. Very tasty coffee stout.

Pours thick and black with a smallish tan head.  Aroma is delightful and potent.  It is full of black cherry, coffee beans, and vanilla.  Flavor is more roasted coffee note with chocolate and dark fruit.  Aftertaste is surprisingly tart with a long lasting bitterness.  Zesty and well carbonated feel, even mildly volcanic on the tongue.  This beer is thick and substantial in body and is very good!  Enough coffee one could enjoy it with breakfast.
11.2oz bottle. Big dark black pour, brown head. Dark, kind of sweet, aroma. Big coffee in the aftertaste, sticks to the tongue. Not my style really.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle from South Bay Drugs. The aroma was a dark robust and roasty combination of malts but for some odd reason I scent a whiff of cinnamon.  Appearance is as black as dirty used oil with creamy tanned heading so a very appetizing stout to gaze at. The flavor is strong in coffee and is accompanied by a strong dark roast malt backing. Leaves behind a tart and bitter aftertaste that will reach all way down the throat.

Pours inky black with a medium coffee head that lasts for quite a while.  Nose is coffee, roasted malt, olive.  Flavor of roasted malt and coffee, with a sweet, bright finish, with vanilla bean and plum.  Yum.
Black in color with a generous bronze colored head. Aroma is of fresh coffee grounds, mocha, dark chocolate and soy sauce. Flavor is of espresso and roasted malts.

Pours a deep dark brown/black with a small creamy head that slowly forms.  Aroma is lots of coffee, roasted malt and grain and dark chocolate.  Flavor is huge.  Mostly deep roasted coffee, but with some dark chocolate and ripe fruit coming through as well.  Thick and creamy on the palate.  As readily available as this is, I can’t believe I never tried it earlier.

BIG Coffee.  SO MUCH coffee.  Dear sweet LORD the COFFEE.  I really liked this.  Very nice dark pour.  The chocolate and espresso were really really good.  I really like coffee stouts and give this one my blessing.  Domo origato Hitachino Nest!
Nice brown head, very black, roasted coffee, chocolate nose. Heavy chocolate, espresso taste, sweet coffee finish.
Bottle at home ... From a trade i forget who SORRYDeep black ... big coffee roast ... deep roast malts low level bitterness and huge coffee kick.

12oz bottle poured into an English pint.  HNES pours black, not dark brown, not dark amber but black.  The head is minimal and consists mostly of a ring of dirty white loitering around the edge of the glass.  The aroma is...... wait for it...... drum roll...... ESPRESSO!  I knew you’d be surprised.  The body is nice and chewy.  I actually sliced a piece off for my wife to try.  The taste is....oh never, mind, it’s espresso too.  It has a very nice malt chocolate sweetness and great coffee bitterness, a dichotomy of happiness.  The finish lingers around as a bitter reminder of how good your mouth just felt.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2012 Pitch black, thick, with a fantastically tall and creamy tan head. Strong aroma of coffee, with hints of chocolate, roasted barley, burnt wood, caramel. A slightly sour note as well, almost a touch of dark fruit. Thick, rich body and flavor. Huge coffee but not overwhelming. Great roasted malt and barley. Chocolate, creamy lactic milk taste, brown sugar. A touch of refreshing sourness, and a touch of vanilla. Maybe a touch of aroma hops as well? Perfectly balanced. Great bitterness, decent sweetness. Long-lasting bitter finish of burnt barley, coffee. An excellent beer, not too much on the coffee, well done.

Pours like molasses from the bottle with a creamy brown head of foam that takes its sweet time to settle.  Loaded with robust espresso and faint traces of chili powder.   Quite possibly the reason why anime charcaters have such big eyes.
bottle from Hamilton pub in San Diego. Very strong and focused coffee taste and aroma. Not much else there, but they do this wekk.

Objectively speaking:
Accomplished coffee stout.

I like:
Aromatic, ashey and solidly roasted ale whose alcohol remains hidden. Medium-full bodied, though rather highly carbonated èa la Belgian stout. A malt extraction feature where sweetness is constantly kept at bay by the competent roastiness.

I dislike:
Not much fruit flavours in there. This is what they intended, but this does not taste much more than espresso, extremely focused.

Drank with Bartzilla and others.  Typical jet-black stout appearance.   Nice aroma of Coffee and malts.  Surprisingly tasty beer.  Complex, but smooth and not overdone.  Kind of like a lighter, more sessionable Speedway Stout.

Great coffee stout with obvious coffee from Sumatra in this brew. Full of strong, bold, carbon rich notes with a strong coffee flavor behind it all. Partially chewy, but not overly so. This is about balance with malts and the coffee.

I am happy to say that something decent in the brewing world has finally come out of Japan. The beer poured wonderfully. Little bit of a chocolate head action going on. The beer seem to be pretty thick on its way in the glass, and the beer is also very dark. I think this is a good looking beer. The head could be a bit darker, but still nice. Big chocolate nose on this sucker. Also, there is a nice subtle espresso (I guess)/coffee aroma. Very nice smelling beer. There is a slight roast aroma, but the chocolate and coffee are more pronounced. The beer has a weird flavor.
