It has the coffee and the chocolate, and even a little roast in the flavor, but these flavors are seemingly mild, but also they are not. Little too carbonated if you ask me. This over-carbonation steals away from the flavor. If the mouthfeel weren’t so bubbly then I would probably be able to taste the flavors a bit more. Decent stouts, I would definitely drink again, but there are better stouts.
Black, COFFEE, dark chocolate, roasted malts, dark fruits, caramel, dry, and slightly bitter finish.

Poured black with a nearly brown head.  Nose is pretty fragrant coffee, some roast malt.  Nice body, not overly heavy but solid.  Taste not as intense with coffee as one might expect.  Pretty well balanced with some bakers chocolate/mocha and roasted malt.  Finish was dry with a little coffee bitterness.  This was recommended as something very different, but I found it just what it should be.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: This black ale poured with a generous tan head and a chocolate aroma. There is an intense chocolate malt flavor with a treacle sensation and a bitter coffee finish. Very tasty.
Bottle. Pours a very dark brown, small brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate and roast malt. Flavor is bitter coffee, bitter chocolate a touch of sweetness that never really shows itself.
Bottle. Dark ruby black beer with a brown head. Malt aroma with caramel and coffee. Coffee and roast flavors with caramel, nuttiness, and slight vanilla. Fuller bodied. Coffee and roast linger.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits in SF. Opaque brown/black pour with a good sized dark tan head. Aromas of dark roasted malt, coffee, kind of oatmeal, with a slight chocolate note. Full bodied, smooth, creamy carbonation. Flavor turns to mild burnt malt, and is decently bitter. The start is almost sugar/milk in a light way. Its silken. Finish is dry, but not overly bitter. Any hop just blends in. Quite pleasing. With time the smooth, strong coffee becomes dominant. It really ends up coffee!!

Good stuff if you like coffe. The exact opposite of the Abyss I drank last night (this is all coffee where as the Abyss was all chocolate for me). Thick pour with a largish, lightly creamy brown head with a black body. Aroma of espresso, brown sugar, molasses and a bit of chocolate. Taste is overpoweringly strong espresso, not bad, but not my thing. Litterally like drinking an iced espresso. Mouthfeel is on the thin side.

I woke up with this in my refrigerator so this is either courtesy of SoLan or I owe him money/beer. He is such a fine person Id be willing to tender both. 
Considering this probably came from Japan on a slow boat the espresso/coffee aroma is amazingly fresh and concentrated. I get some earthy soil and old tree bark notes, but they actually compliment the aroma rather than detract. Soot and charcoal also show up and again it smells very right in this beer. The body is full on black and holds a two finger thick mocha head that is quite lasting. The first sip is ash, dark fruit and chocolate. The coffee notes are much less pronounced in the flavor, though clearly still present. The middle gets almost chocolate covered cherry-like. Sweet cream, vanilla, bakers chocolate and more coffee make up the finish. Pretty nice.

Pours like an Impy- viscous black with a full, dark tan head that leaves substantial lacing. The nose is largely coffee of course, and a bit of malted chocolate. The flavor is just as the nose with a clean dryness in the finish. Creamy mouthfeel.
[Bottle] Pours a clear deep brown with a very very dark head. Aroma is grass, coffee beans, and roasted barley. Flavor is the same. Very bitter and slightly acidic.

Bottle @ Tornado San Diego.  Huge roasted coffee aroma with moderate dark chocolate and faint burnt notes. Pours a dark brown, virtually black, with no transparency and a small brown head that diminishes to a small ring around the edges of the glass. The flavor starts with a big dose of dark chocolate with some faint caramel. The finish has lots of roasted coffee, some burnt bitter flavors, and faint vanilla. Full bodied with light carbonation.

One amazing stout.
Pours black, head is nutty. Nose is very pleasant of espresso coffee.
Aroma is a very sweet roasted chocolate/coffee malt filled with flavor.
Mouthfeel is a little thick, leaving an aftertaste filled with a nice espresso taste.

Pours a dark black with a light dark tan head. Wicked coffee and cocoa aroma.
Flavour is burnt malt, bitter coffee bite to it transitioning into a chocolate coffee bean body.
Mouthfeel alternates between bitter bite and oily smoothness. Finishes softly with cocoa nibs bitterness.

wonderful pitch black with tan head appearance.  many components to the flavor with an initial coffee bitterness and late acting chocolate appearance that adds to the bitterness but also gives a great sweetness, the caramel malt is also present.  the hops do not contribute much.  the alcohol is definitely present, making me think there was more alcohol than 7.5%, but  it’s presence doesn’t detract much.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Big C Liquors Orlando, FL for $4.49 Excellent.

12 oz bottle, via SoLan.  Pours a black body, completely opaque, with a nice frothy brown head that had excellent retention.  The nose is excellent, almost more coffee smell than beer.  Tons of dark roasted malt and espresso roast coffee with a nice earthy note.  Smells like the left over grounds from a fresh espresso.  The flavor is very coffee centric as well.  Nice dark roast coffee with a fairly minimal oily bitterness level.  Lots of dark chocolate and cocoa powder and a nice earthy almost grainy finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with soft gentle carbonation.  I suppose that I am a sucker for coffee beers, but even if I weren’t this really is an extremely good beer.

This one has the ideal appearance: inky black with a thick foamy tan head. I can definitely smell the espresso. I also smell some caramel. Very dry aroma, but just a hint of sweetness in the flavor. Coffee dominates, and all but blocks out other flavors. If I concentrate, I can pick out flavors of prunes, toffee, vanilla, and in the aftertaste, roses. Medium (almost thick) bodied. Very smooth and silky going down. Very enjoyable.
Black with a magna huge tan head.  Smell is opening a bag a freshly ground coffee also some dark chocolate, roastiness, and malts.  Taste is coffee, chocolate, mocha like.  Thicker body.

A gorgeous Japanese coffee-stout based on a Russian imperial stout. Beautiful in the glass with a lavish cappuccino head. Big, "dry" aroma of cocoa powder, bitter chocolate and souring milk. Terrific creamy body. Intense espresso flavours with some pistachio nuttiness and a swaggering bitter chocolate finish. An outstanding stout and one of the highlights of an evening of impressive beers. (Bottle courtesy of TimE at Sully’s Sydney RB Xmas 07 gathering. Thanks fellas.)

Bottle. Pours very dark brown with a red/brown head. Strong coffee aroma, smoke, roast, and a hint of sweet vanilla. Medium body. Flavor starts on a sweet creamy caramel and vanilla note, before moving to coffee, roast, and smoke. Very nice, very drinkable and tasty.

I gotta say my first impression was better than the long term. big espresso aroma with malt and dark Chocolate cherries. The body is thick and rich but there is a funny finish it is meaty. Strange. Buck convention, drink cold.
11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown (almost black) with a thick & long lasting tan head.  Flavor: Coffee, chocolate, and a hint of raisins.

A Sim rate (tap at Spuyten Duyvil): Espresso, espresso, espresso. Its coffee. Nothing beer about it. Very stouty look. Way too much coffee in the flavour. I love the taste because I love coffee but theres no subtlety to it so not a great score. All gimmick, no grace.
Black pour from the bottle with a very small tan head.  Aromas and flavors are of one thing...good coffee.  One of the more pronounced coffee flavored beers I have had.  Good thing I like coffee!

on tap at 1702 deep black with small tan head but nice lacing.  aroma of burnt coffee and burnt biscuit.  flavor is up front roasted malt and a lingering coffee finish.  roastiness reallycomes through and the coffee isnt overpowering but definitely is a major component.  nice beer.  I have never seem this on tap before, nice job Austin.
Tasted at the real ale fest.  Black with a foamy tan head.  Good espresso aroma.  Dry chocolate and roasty coffee taste.
Bottled. Poured incredibly dark w/almost no head. Smell was strong and coffee and so was the taste. Alcohol was tastable.

Pours black with light tan foam.  Extremely unique aroma swirling with strong vanilla and sweet rice notes, burnt malts, chocolate, dark fruit, and mellow coffee.  Flavor is also extremely unique, a great combination of mellow sweet notes and slight coffee bitterness.  Cacao, vanilla, coffee, with cream and sweet rice. Very pleasantly surprised with this one, points added for originality.

Appears black in the glass.  Full, large, well-developed light tan foam.  Nose has an expressive espresso character, with mocha, dark roast coffee and a touch of chocolate and vanilla.  Lots of taste, with a really impressive coffee character.  Finish lasts and lasts.  What else to say.  Just a really impressively crafted beer.  If I were in Ibaraki, Id drink this daily.

Black in colour, rich tan coloured head, good size and retention, light lacing.  The aroma is incredibly roasty, LOTS of coffee and espresso, sweet, some chocolate and cream.  The flavour is roasty, again lots of coffee, cream, sugary sweetness, chocolate, a bit burnt.  Very roasty mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes long, very roasty with lots of espresso bitterness.
This was just like a fine cup of coffee, excellent from start to finish.  I loved the roast in this.
330ml bottle obtained in a trade with TheCheeseMan, thanks Dan.
Opened on December 16, 2007
No date.

Aroma of fine roasted coffee, dark chocolate, deepest brown, small cappuccino head. Flavour begins with a big roast coffee punch, some dark chocolate followed by burnt toast. Medium bodied, very well balanced, beautifully bitter. Terrific! Most impressed for a Japanese offering. Thank You Torontoblue.

The pour is a nice deep drown with a medium, slowly dissipating tan head.  The nose while slightly funky and earthy, sings with wonderful espresso notes, chocolate malt and candy sugars.  The palate is sweet refined and strongly coffee, but complex enough so that this stout is not just a cold carbonated espresso.  A nice beer.

Another wonderful beer from this brewery!  I love the fact that they added espresso beans to the boil, making coffee and beer at the same time.  This has the most amazing nose, it would almost beer hard to say this was a beer in a blind taste test, it has such a powerful espresso nose.  Rich and roasty, and completely creamy on the palate.  Does not have any acrid roasty flavors, it is all in balanced moderation.  Chocolate and cocoa along with a bit of caramel.  This is the best example of coffee beers I have ever tried.
reminds me of chocolate covered espresso beans.  smooth drinkability, i could drink it all day.................if i had the cash flow
Bottle - Perhaps my sample was old, but I thought this beer was fairly thin with an overwhelming coffee bitterness that did not reveal any other flavors.  A very one sided offering.

midnight black, small tan head.  full aroma of freshly ground coffee.  not entirely sure what to think here.  one dimensional coffee flavor and texture.  oily consistency, rich flavor, and tasty.  its a good beer, but i dont see what the fuss is about.  i should drink it again later.  isnt that always the best way to know for sure?

11.2oz bottle.  Pours syrupy and nearly black with a slowly receding medium-sized brown head.  Aroma of fresh ground coffee, chocolate, caramel, and hops.  Coats the mouth with a thick, rich, sweet coffee flavor, fading to a bitter espresso bean/hoppy finish.  Milk chocolate aftertaste.  Very smooth, easy to drink.  A little expensive, but very enjoyable.

11.2-oz bottle from 99 Bottles. Smell reminds me of grandmas kitchen, where the coffee percolator was always brewing! Absolutely incredible aroma of rich ground coffee. Creamy mouth-feel. Coffee and espresso flavor, with notes of dark chocolate. Warming finish. One of my all-time favorite coffee beers.

Bottle. Poured a deep black body with thin head. Aroma is a very nice roasty scent. Flavor is coffee roast, light hops and chocolate. Light sugary feel with a slightly dry mouthfeel. Thsi one was good.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle, courtesy Ughsmash. Pours pitch black, with a half-inch of creamy tan-colored head. Very nice thick lacing. Big roasted chocolate aroma, lots of maltiness. Caramel and brown sugar, too. Rich, ground coffee. Flavor also has roasted coffee, and a bitter hoppiness in the finish. Chocolate, caramel, very tasty malts. Refreshing and easy-drinking, chalky mouthfeel, but very smooth.

Bottle 0.33 l from Brooklyn. Really good looking beer, dark brown with a big brown beige head. The foam really came out of the bottle even tho it was properly chilled. Nose has some dark chocolate and ground espresso beans, but mostly it smells like a balsamico based salad dressing with a very wine like acidity. Or maybe its soy sauce or some other fermented beans. Really strange nose. Flavor is very sour, acidic and has the balsamico notes all over. Could be sour coffee roast too, but I cant get over the vinous notes. Maybe something wrong with the bottle? Somewhere between soy sauce, coffee, balsamico and stout.

Pours pitch blask with a thick tan head. Aroma of coffee, milk, toffee, and coffee.  Taste of milk and coffee with a bitter roast finish. Medium chalky mouthfeel. Med-high carbonation. A good mix of sweet and bitter.  Quite a tasty beer.

Dark pour with brown head and lacing. Nice looking. Strong aroma of coffee. Nice rich thick flavor of quality roasted coffee, the perfect amount of supporting milky sweet chocolate. This was really good.

Black with a tan head. Fresh brewed coffee aroma with dark cocoa. Chewy mouthfeel is a bit dry and chalky. Great dark chocolate, coffee mocha flavor here with a lingering coffee bitterness to finish. Spot on breakfast stout. Enjoyed this one.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Solid black, thin brown head. Cold coffee extract aroma. Sweet with a very strong coffee flavor and some tartness. Decent balancing bitterness and roasted flavors. A bit thin in body.

Pours black and opaque, with a deep brown head that dissipates quickly. Coffee is immediately apparent in the aroma (which for me is a good thing), but the taste is much subtler than the aroma would suggest. First sip promises a rich, toasty, chocolatey stout -- but the finish is pure dark-roast coffee. Its as though they found the perfect marriage of my 2 favorite beverages. If this were easier to find and less expensive, Id be drinking quite a lot of this.

12oz via trade that has been on its side in my fridge for probably too long, and I felt like I needed to rate a new beer tonight.  Shared with my girlfriend Cyn.  Pours black wtih a light brown head.  Nose is sweet and chocolaty with a coffee edge.  Taste is quite sweet with a big coffee taste.  Quite sweet, cant tell if this should be a sweet stout or something else.  A one maybe 1.5 dimensional beer, but pretty good overall.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 Thanks to By The Bottle in Washington for this brew!  Poured a deep chalky brown.  Deep and roasty.  Lots of coffee in the nose, but the flavor was well balanced.  Mildly peaty and very clean.  One of the best coffee beers I have ever tasted.

A very nice coffee stout.  This is beer is in between Bells Java and Black Majic in terms of coffee flavor intensity.  A little bit higher alcohol % than I expected, but it was decidable in the flavor.  I would have this again.   Pretty cool to have a beer from Japan too.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2009 Gotta love a beer with a cool owl on the label (and the cap makes a good magnet!)  Pours black with a huge tan head. Taste is very creamy and smooth. Very nice. The coffee is different than most coffee stouts, almost tastes like they pours espresso in the coffee, rather than adding beans to the brew. Most of the coffee is on the backend, but it makes itself more present the more you drink. Very warming for a 7%, but in a very good way. Pretty impressive.

Black body, nice thick brown head. Deep roasted, burnt, coffee aroma. Almost medium bodied, roasty, coffeeish, malts are there to counter roast. But this is all about how intense they could reasonably get the coffee taste...good job.

bottle from rustico.  pours an opaque black, creamy brown head that shows no signs of going anywhere.  nose is (you guessed it) all coffee...caramel, vanilla.  flavor is big malt up front but immediately hits with the roasted espresso flavor.  finish is a hint of caramel but mostly roast.  i cant decide if i like this or not (disclaimer: im not a coffee drinker).  its quite good, but the aggressive coffee flavor is a tad off-putting.

Aroma is strong and mainly of unsweetened chocolate; there are some coffee and malt hints. It pours a deep sable, almost black, with a thick, dark tan head. Flavor is chocolaty and has some smoky, malt and hop undertones. Texture is smooth and pleasant. Drinking this beer is somewhat like drinking liquid unsweetened chocolate that has a little well-roasted coffee in it.
Quality stout from the Japanese. I wasnt a huge fan of this particular coffee flavor, but its still good.

Bottle thanks to Jordan. Pours a deep black with a nice thick cream colored head. The aroma is mostly a strong coffee bean and burnt malts. The taste is also much like a rich and hearty cup of coffee with some malts and creamy sweetness thrown in. A good beer for sure. Perhaps for breakfast would be best. Anyone have some toast and scones?

This one is pitch black with a medium mocha head almost as thick as whip cream. The aroma is roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee. Taste is similar to the aroma with maybe a little more roasted malt. The body is amazingly creamy, in fact, I have never had such a creamy beer. It is a wonderful  dessert beer. I was very surprised by this one!

If you drink Folgers, this beer is for you!!!  Dark mahogany body with cocoa head, the aroma is of bitter coffee and little else.  Flavor is also of bad coffee and the palate thin.  There is no depth here.  Simple, bitter, weak.  Not a favorite.

Shared by robert at stateline. Smells just like an espresso! Taste just like an espresso. Too bad I dont like espresso!!
Good texture. But it was still a good beer. I just dont like coffee or espresso, but if you do this beer is for you.

Bottle: Poured a deep black color stout with a nice foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of espresso coffee is gorgeous with some notes of roasted malt also noticeable. Taste is a well balance mix between some roasted malt, nice black chocolate notes with some lactose also noticeable. Full creamy body is perfect for the style with no discernable alcohol. I must admit having been surprised by the creamy body and the nice balance between all the element in this beer.

Dark black with a dark brown head.  Aromai is quite loaded with espresso, earthy and lightly licoricey character as well.  A bit of plummy sweetness, soft cocoa and a rich roastiness.  Flavour is quite sweet but this is balanced by roast behind all of the espresso.  Sweet and lightly plummy.  Lightly salty roastiness on the back.  One of the best coffee stouts Ive ever had.

2-19-08 bottle thanks to beerlando! 

Black in color with eternal dark tan head.  Head is so long lasting and thick - it almost appears "chunky".  Slight roasted burning malt smell and a very very light coffee smell.  Flavor is overly sweet for my liking.  Coffee notes are present in the flavor but not very much.  Mouthfeel is average - a bit thinner than I hoped.

Let me confess: Im a sucker for coffee/espresso stouts, so it was with great excitement that I cracked this bottle open, that After4ever sent me! Its pitch black and the head is nougat colored, delicious and creamy. The aroma has roasted malt, loads of coffee and licorice. The flavour has a light sweetness and coffee, coffee and coffee - and oh, did I mention coffee?? It also has sweet licorice and a light bitterness in the finish. The body is full and very nice, and the flavour lasts forever and ever - its a really nice stout, right up my alley Tom, thank you so much!

330 ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown in color with a medium sized disappearing tan head.  The aroma is all about the coffee/espresso as well as some dark chocolate and hops.  The flavor is fresh roasted coffee with added bitterness.  The chocolate malt has a very slight tartness to it.  Mouthfeel is spot on with this one.  This is a standout coffee stout.

Bottle thanks to Suttree.  Lots of coffee aromas off this very dark pour with a huge, dark brown head.  Flavors were bitter coffee.  I had expected sweeter, but it was black, bitter coffee all the way.  Pretty good actually.

Dark brown/black body with a small creamy tan head. Moderately sweet nose with coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla and roast. Lightly sweet taste with bitter bakers chocolate, espresso and light berry. Medium/full body is soft with light carbonation.

Bottle courtesy of Beerlando.  Thanks!
Pours fairly opaque black with a big fizzy, foamy chocolately brown colored lasting head.  Smell is strong espresso, coffee grounds.  Taste is strongly of coffee, and not much else at all.  Medium bodied and drinkable, but the coffee flavor almost got boring after a while and was very one note.  Decent, but Ive really enjoyed other coffee beers more.

minimal tan head, dark brown to black body.  a very tempting aroma for a coffee appreciator such as myself.  And the bitter is unrivaled among stouts.  Ive not had a stout this well balanced, and with such a pleasant hoppiness in a while.  I had the opportunity to visit this brewery this summer, and I was delighted to find their winter seasonal available at my local beer store when after I returned to the US.  Yippee!

Pours to a black body with a thin brown head.  The aroma has an amazingly roasted coffee and chocolate.  Almost like the coffee is a fruity/earthy combination with a sweet milkiness.  The flavor is a fruity/earthy bitter creamy chocolate coffee.  Muted spruce hops on the finish.  The palate has a moderate carbonation, is sweet, and has an acetic dryness on the finish.
courtesy of rollinhard.  black pour with a thin dark caramel colored head.  very malty chocolate and wood scent.  very thick, yet smooth and a huge coffee aftertaste.  im quite impressed.

Pours with a frothy, initially two-finger thick, chocolate cream colored head.  The beer is quite black and opaque in color.  The aroma has huge, dark roast, espresso aromatics to it.  Noticed aromas of burnt berry notes, charcoal, dark chocolate, burnt toast and a middle that is made up of sweet, malty chocolate candy like notes.  At times the aroma can be quite rich and satisfying, but at others the roast character is a bit overwhelming and tends to make this seem a bit thin, sharp and burnt.

Very thick bodied and sweet, this is much more of a meal than I was expecting.  Through the middle the thick, sweet, malt flavors do a good job of balancing the roast & espresso notes.  The burnt malt and espresso malt notes are found in the long finish were they slightly dry out the up front sweetness, but there is also a distinct, lingering note that tastes like burnt blueberries.  The sweet notes accent a rich chocolate middle, sweet coffee cream flavors and a blackened toffee flavor.  The body of this thing really is quite creamy, rich, thick and viscous; I cant remember a beer of this strength that is as thick as this brew.

An interesting beer, while the flavor was quite sweet, it was much more in balance than the aroma was.  The huge, dark malt sweetness was needed to balance out the aggressive roast grain and espresso notes.  The aroma is a bit too dominated by the roast aromatics.  Actually based on the aroma I was expecting the flavor to be overly burnt and acidic, quite happily this is not.  The most interesting thing about this beer is that lingering, fruit flavor in the far finish that is a mix of blueberries and tropical fruit.  More than likely this last is from the espresso beans.

Purchased: <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Tucson AZ

Pours a dark brownish black with a thick creamy brown head. Aroma of espresso coffee grounds, chocolate and malt. Has a decent mouthfeel with a really nice bittesweet coffee and chocolate taste.  This is really good and well balanced. I was pleasantly surprised to see a beer like this coming out of Japan.

Bottle. Pours a very opaque ebony with a nice dark tan head. The aroma is a medium, roasty espresso. Its a nice defining aroma, but not too strong. But I like bold, intense aromas. The flavour is bold in coffee and has more subtle notes of cocoa. There are also strong hints of milkiness that lends to a nice, creamy mouth-feel. 

Andyhite mentioned it tasted like a "frappabeer." Id been trying to think of a good description to use and I think "frappabeer" sums up the thick texture, creaminess, and coffee flavours quite well. Its very desert-like and quite enjoyable.

Dark rich pour with a finger thick beautiful tan head.  Roasted malt and chocolate on the nose with a definite sharp bitter coffee aroma.  The taste is great.  Nice bitter chocolate and coffee but the bitterness blends perfectly with the malt.

Very coffeeish and coffee ground stout.Coffee grinds and some chocolate, with above average mouthfeel. Decent stout, and not reminding me of the typical American made one, which is a good change of pace.

bottle.  foamy almond head, big deep space body.  aromas of freshly almost burned espresso beans, dark, roasted malts. it tastes like a frappabeer.  1 point for creativeness and, in my head, originality.  another few for it being a tasty beverage, and having a fresh goumet coffee finish that just coats the palate.  i will retaste this mighty fine ale...and when did the japanese learn how to make quality beer that isnt sapporo?

The aroma was strong espresso coffee with a smoky and roasty presence. The aroma contained dark chocolate and a light estery presence. Deep, dark, and mysterious! The beer poured into the chalice clear black with a low brown head which lasted very well to lace the glass. The flavor was espresso coffee with a light bit of tartness and a strong acidic dark grain presence with a light flavor of caramel.. Dark chocolate was notable as was some fruitiness and enough bittering to keep any malt in check. The finish was dry with lasting espresso coffee long into the aftertaste. The body was medium-full with a moderate level of carbonation. Dang if this wasnt a great espresso stout! 11.2 ounce bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Pours black with a one finger lasting tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of realy rich hot chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt. Taste is heavy roasted coffee and roasted malt. Medium thin mouthfeel with a moderated amount of dark malt tannins and bitterness with the alcohol being hidden very well. Very good.
Pours black into a snifter.  Mocha head recedes to skim rim. Cocoa and espresso aromas.  Sour cocoa hitachino and a little thin with a lasting espresso finish.
bottle. pours black with light brown head.  dence coffee flavors mixed in with some fruit undertones.  impressive stout from the Japanese

Black body, creamy light brown head; Medium sized very dry nose, down to earth complex; Huge full body with a bitterness that has the same fruityness as a dense cold espresso, dry and sweet; Very fruity wine like finish, very fruity bitter, long with lots of dry aromas: Quite nice and somehow very Japanese in its simplicity and elegance.

Dark brown, nearly black, with a rich, roasty tan head, 1/4 ", slowly simmering, but beautiful.

Cocoa, coffee, and cola coming out of the nose...vanilla beans and maple interject. Espresso notes get bigger, more bittersweet, richer, deliciouser. 

Fullish mouthfeel, then flavor explodes and spills all over. Bittersweet dominates the flavor. Huge espresso, some licorice and molasses. Big chocolate, too. 

Could use a fuller body, could be richer. Of course, Im comparing it to things like Bells Java Stout, which is plenty thick. Long, chocolatey, bittersweet cocoa finish. Lays long on the tongue.

Yum. Good stuff, Japan!
Pours thick and black with a huge off tan head. Creamy dry fresh ground coffee aroma. Thick roasted malt and coffee taste. Very smooth and tasty.

1/12/2008:  Hitachino Espresso Stout pours out in a thick stream of near black coffee color.  There is an average-sized creamy brown head that doesnt disapear quickly (or really at all for that matter).  Smells of fresh, black dirt mixed with coffee.  There are some notes of bittersweet chocolate as well.  The flavor is dense with coffee, roasted malts, and bitter chocolate (almost ike unsweetened Bakers Chocolate).  It is also dry and earthy with some old, used coffee ground type flavor coming through just before the bitter, dark chocolate finish.  The palate of this medium-full to full-bodied beer is thick and creamy.  It kind of has the density and texture of heavy whipping cream.  Overall this beer is good and solid, but not great.  I would probably never pick-up another bottle of this again.
11.2 fl.oz. bottle (7.5% alc./vol.) from Rivers Bend in Maineville, Ohio.  Rating #143 for this beer...

Had this bottle. Poured very thick and dark. Sort of similar to an Expedition, but not quite as dark. Really sour coffee flavors. A bit of malt in there as well. A little too thin texture with the sour taste. Prepare the palate for this one.

11.2 oz bottle.  Ebony; a stiff pour produces a bubbly crema head that settles with chunky lacing.  Nose is salty black licorice and musty coffee beans.  Silky sipping with soft peel carb that lightly tickles the tongue.  Taste is surprisingly fruity; earthy plums and orange pith.  Hints of vanilla with coffee drying.  Long, saturated finish with mild sour.  A most interesting brew.

Dark black and thick, minimal head. No doubt this beer is espresso as advertised. Big coffee flavors are prominent, with a tiny bit of sweetness in the background. Nice hop balance at the end to dry it out. This brewery doesnt play, they always come with some solid beer. This is no exception. If youre a coffee geek as I am, this is your beer.

Pours a dark tar like color with a thin coating of tan head. Smell is of burnt sugars, dark chocolate and espresso grounds. Taste is smoky with flavors of dark dark chocolate and espresso with a nutty sweetness mixed in. A bitter bite at the end. Like drinking a very very smooth cup of strong coffee.

purchased at 99 bottles in federal way, washington.
pour is outstanding, thick black with a medium size chocolate mousse head, very nice lacing.
smell is of bakers chocolate, espresso, toffee, roasted almonds, some peanut brittle, wee bit of smoke in the background.
taste is thick, milk chocolate, a little smokiness, some nuts, on the sweet side, espresso, slight bitter finish.
overall a great beer!!!

Oily black in color. Dense and thin tan head. Smokey and roasty. Lots of espresso in the aroma. Dense and challenging with its overly bitter coffee flavor. A faint sourness at the finish. A pleasure to drink.

Bottle: Dark black color, thin tan head, small lacing, very light carbonation. The nose is a combination of light espresso and a dark coffee, some sweet robust roast and sharp fruity acidic chocolate malt. Some tobacco and burnt notes, but theyre vague and ignorable. The flavor is a bit dry, some noticeable astringency and sharp coffee grounds. Very light alcohol though and a creamy full sweet body. Interesting acidity to blend it together.

11.2 oz bottle purchased at Ocean Wine & Spirits enjoyed on Christmas morning. Is this beer a breakfast stout clone, aromawise anyways. Aroma starts off with a blast of black olives but luckily that quickly fades and you are left with espresso, licorice and bitter dark chcocolate. Pours a very nice thick solid bodied beauty with an average size medium brown head. Body is nice and full but the cabonation is a bit too lively and could be a tad smoother. Flavor starts off as burnt coffee but finishes with some nice chocolatey sweetness. Really good stuff but what type of sushi am I supposed to eat with this.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 12oz bottle.  Thick pure black color with rusty colored head.  Rich with fantastic roasted malt and chocolate qualities, while remaining classy, subtle, and drinkable.  The alcohol and general flavor is just barely reminiscent of an imperial stout, and the coffee adds even more depth.  Great coffee stout, among the best Ive had.
Good coming from a foreign world. Large coffee scent. Smell of malt as well. Deep coffee taste but a lacking on the end. Bitter roast malt finish.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: I would not have thought something this good could come from Japan.  Thick and syrupy pour.  Head is tan and decent sized, probably would have been bigger if I had poured it right.  Black as used motor oil.  Wonderful strong brewed coffee nose and dark chocolate laden.  Very roasty, toffee, caramel, vanilla all swirled together...almost like a brownie.  Flavor is sharp up front...dark roasted espresso, bitter sweet chocolate that smoothes out nicely to a silky sweet finish with a medium hop bite.  Nice and thick.

A thick, syrupy, pours black body spawns a massive column of dense, light brown foam.  The head settles slowly to a wavy, completely asymmetrical mound.  Randomly placed, thick clumps of lacing hang on the glass like pictures on a wall.  The aroma is pure, unadulterated espresso.  Nothing more, nothing less.  This is without a doubt the most intensely coffeed-out brew I have ever some across.  Any other scents or aromas that might be present are crushed by the massive avalanche of sharp, biting espresso.  A heaping helping of sweet, malty sugar has been added to make this concoction drinkable, which causes it to sit very heavy on the stomach.  Still, its bitter as hell, despite the sweeteners.  Finishes roasty, with a slight sour tickle in the back of the throat.  Just a hair shy of full bodied.  I cant get past the intense coffee and roast, but if espresso is your thing, this one is a must try.

In the bottle from Beertopia. Pours as black as your soul with an equally dark brown head. The aroma is an intense burnt coffee scent. Flavor is like drinking a shot of espresso, except with a deep sourness that lingers throughout. You miss a lot of the roastedness due to this uniform and thorough tartness. Perhaps a bit of spruce kicks in there as well. This is an oily thick beer. Damn good.

Thanks to CaptainCougar and Secret Santa for my share of this beer.  Pours black with a tan to brown head.  Honestly, this beer looks beautiful.  Aroma of old coffee grounds, dark chocolate, wood, and toffee.  The coffee quality to this doesnt appeal to me as it reminds me of throwing away the previous days coffee grounds.  Tastes basically no different from the aroma; maybe more focus on the bitter dark chocolate.  Medium to thick mouthfeel pretty full bodied, kinda gritty feeling, but I might have been imagining that.  I really thought I would like this more, as it sounds so good.  However, its merely okay.  I guess the best coffee beers are the ones that keep the coffee elements a bit downplayed, like Speedway.
Excellent Stout.  Smells like youre roasting coffee in the glass (very nice) Dark roasty chocolate flavors, some bitterness, but very well balanced.  Extermely dark color

Black coffee nose..not malt...coffee.  Folgers w/ some bakers chocolate and herbal bitterness.  Finishes the same.  

The end

This stout is exemplary.  Probably one of the most beautiful stouts i have ever witnessed.  The blackness is Impenetrably black...like an onyx mirror.  The head was like a living Picasso..alive and minimalistically artistic in seductive ways...the darkness was almost metallic, glimmering lace paints the sides of a glass upon a tilt.  insane.  Nose was like chocolate fog; thick head-explosive chocolate fog with a dose of holiday coffee steam.  The flavors start restrictive but refined. melted chocolate an powdery cocoa,adequately sweetened, and with requisite bitterness...Mouthfeel is thick yet wet & slippery...maybe even oily..the end is almost lactic and most certainly sharp ...the thick chocolate flavors grow...and grow, ceasing their restrictiveness...basically, taking over.

33 cl. Opaque black with a 4 finger head that lasts. Aroma is coffee with cream, charred wood, dry oats, and cocoa. Flavors of espresso with sugar and cream, cocoa, smoky hickory, and green herbs.  Medium-heavy body is smoooooth and has a just-right dry finish. Best... stout... ever.

Fat 12oz bottle pours black with a lasting brown head.  Huge coffee aroma on this one.  Malted milk balls, some chocolate, and a full blast of cold pressed coffee.  Unsubtle but awesome.  Taste is not as good as smell, unfortunately.  Coffee flavor present but a little thin and one dimensional otherwise.  A nice effort and good to try for fans of coffee stouts like myself but not one of the better examples.

Pours black with a large, dark head. First impression of the aroma is sweet, lactic chocolate, uncannily like chocolate milk. Swirling brings out a bitter espresso which mixes very well with the chocolate. The combination is not unlike lightly toasted bakers cocoa. That same combination carries over into the flavor, which ends with a decidedly espresso-like bitterness. Very well done.

Black, with a brown head. Rich. almost decadent aroma of espresso and a hint of dark cocoa. Very rich palate. Flavor is pretty much the same as the aroma, but with a bit more chocolate. This was a nice surprise.

Pours pitch black wtih a mostly receding tan head. Aroma of coffee, roasted barley and stale coffee. Tastes of brewed coffee, strong burnt roast, earthy, chewy dirt like flavors. Mouthfeel is full to heavy bodied with smooth carbonation. Has some nice qualities, but this is very coffee-centric.

on draft and a small serving wasnt sure what to expect but the strong espresso aroma was more than enough for me. tasted very good and not sure i would drink a 10oz glass. was creamy and very strong and thats good. this could be a good last beer of the eveing.

The beer decamps the stubby 330ml bottle a soot black with some light ruby highlights, the head pompous, the color chocolate and the texture creamy, upon its depletion the lace forms a nice concealing sheet. Nose has a rich nut like aroma, chocolate, coffee, caramel and a pinch of hops. Start is nicely malted; sweet with a burnt grain and hop spicy bite at the back, top is full in feel. Finish has a standard acidity, the burnt grain and hops provide a lingering bittersweet bite, aftertaste dry and long lasting, a fine stout.

Draft: This has to be one of my favorite stouts it hits the mark on every level from the wonderful pour and the nose that gives a wonderful mocha aroma to the long lingering espresso finish.   I wish this beer was more widely available in the states.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2007 Single bottle.
Taste: rich, malty, chocolate-coffee taste with complex nutty aftertaste and some bitter hops taste. Its not sweet. Palate is heavy and leaves a filmy coffee aftertaste (I didnt think it was bad). Pretty good beer. I like it better than Dragonheads chocolate stout. A little too heavy and intense for me to give it a higher rating. 
Appearance: Pours pitch black, impenetrable to light, no head, no head retention. Smells faintly of chocolate/coffee. You guys love stouts, lol. Maybe as I rate more beers, Ill appreciate stouts more. The more experienced people seem to love them.

Pours a dark black with a dark brown head.  This beer has one of the most beautiful aromas Ive ever experienced.  Very strong coffee bean/espresso presence as well as a burnt dark chocolate scent.  The coffee/espresso theme again is dominant in the taste but a nice dark chocolate taste balances it out perfectly not making it too bitter.  A nice combination of caffeine kick and alcohol strength.  The best infusion of coffee and alcohol that I have tasted and Hitachinos best beer.

For some odd reason I could never quite get up the nerve to open this, but tonight I decided to go for it.  Not sure what my reservations were, perhaps just a couple of wretched flavored stouts and porters Ive had over the past few months.  In any case, this was a very nice reversal of fortune.  Poured black with brownish ruby highlights at the edge, decent dark tan head fades entirely.  Aroma was just fantastic, richly dark chocolate with smooth espresso.  Flavor was more espresso driven, with chocolate as as the underlying note.  Not as thick in the mouth as the aroma would have made you think, but still full bodied.  Excellent beer.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2008 A solid stout.  Great coffee flavor that doesnt bitter out as many pervasive coffee flavors can.  Actually very little evidence that its a beer at all: really tastes like a derivative coffee drink.

Thanks again to  drmat  for sharing this beer.  Pours very dark brown with a small dark orange head.  The aroma has lots of espresso, licorice, staleness, chocolate and dark caramel.  Medium body with a small amount of sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts with espresso, soda shop malt, some sharpness and lactic acid.  The finish has a small amount of fruitiness.  A decent beer that Id probably like better if I was a coffee fan.

Almost black , caramel head...fluffy, looks like cappuccino...smells like coffee beans after a chocolate bath and a car bomb, ..in Vineland!....amped up coffee ice cream initially, then the beans, my mouth is saturated with them, and it is fulfilled to the maximum fulfillment....palate is even tempered, medium to full, creamy and supple...I love coffee, so I am jaded to non-coffee fans...I love it!!...Yum....Delish....Succulent!

Black body with small tan head.  Smells and tastes like CoffeeTime coffee syrup.  Strong esspresso bean aroma and flavor with chocolate notes as well.  Certainly sweet.  Burnt coffee bitter finish.  Mid to full body with nice mouthfeel.
Black pour with dark head. Strong coffee flavor and aroma with both bitter and sweet tones.

black liquid with a deep brown head that lingers nicely.  heavy aroma of burnt coffee extract, along with roasted malts and some caramelized sugar.  flavors is well-balanced between the roast and sweetness - i wanted to check my glass for coffee grounds at the end.  enjoyable beer.

Bottle. Black pour with a tan head. Aroma of light coffee, chocolate, fudge, and roasted malt. Flavors of dry chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt. Medium body, roasty with a roasty /bittersweet finish.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2010 Bottle. Pours rather dark with a small tan head. This certainly smells like a cup of joe.  Roasty coffee predominantly in the nose with a backdrop of malts. Mouthfeel seems a little thinner than Id like, but its not problematic. The coffee flavor here is certainly strong, but I get residual, milky sweetness as well. No other roast seems to be imparted on my palate other than the distinct coffee flavor, which really doesnt remind me much of espresso. Id say Expedition stout tastes more like espresso than this does. This beer has more of a lighter roasted coffee bean feel to it, with more sharp acidity and less smoke and less caramelized qualities.  Im a little biased on beers like this since I enjoy a good cup of java so much. This is not subtle in its use of coffee, but it works pretty darn well. I could stand a stronger, smokier, ashier feel, but this is pretty good.

[March 10, 2010]

Bottle from some liquor store in Gatlinburg. I wanted to try this one again as I remember liking it quite well but noticing my original rating did not reflect that. The verdict: I bumped up my rating significantly and was nitpicking way too much in my original tasting of this beer. I mustve been in a foul mood or something because this is a solid stout through and through. Plenty of coffee is in the aroma and the flavor in a clean and solid transposition. Still, mocha and barley come through to round things out well. This is one of the better renditions of a coffee stout, something I really enjoy anyway. Im still baffled as to why their lacto stout is so bad, given the quality of the espresso stout.

Great looking beer, smells fantastic as well.  Coffee aroma very apparent, almost too apparent and stands out among the dark malt flavors.  A bit overdone for my taste, but the coffee by 1/2 and this would be superb.  Body, mouthfeel, almost everything else is nicely done.

A thick, stiff foamy head is slow to build and slow to die away. Lumpy and tan. The aroma is distinctly roasty, but its not obviously a coffee beer. The coffee is balanced and blends well with the rest of the beer instead of standing out and being featured. This also avoids the ashy flavors that many coffee stouts suffer from. Dry and tasty. I dig it.

Bottle, jet black with a light brown ring left around the glass. Rich dark cacao bars and coffee in the nose, very nice. Dark, rich earth, soil, espresso, dark chocolate/non-pareils, some caramel and hint of mint (or perceived mint). Moderately sweet. Full, round and creamy body with lively, fine-beaded carbonation. Very nice beer.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2008 pours on the lighter side of black with a creamy cocoa head. aroma reminds me of still wet coffee grounds with some chocolate, wood and astringent malts. theres definitely coffee in the flavor profile but it is kept under control (unlike most coffee beers)so the rest of the characteristics can be sensed...wood, creamy chocolate,caramel and ashiness. its low in sweetness which is a plus. the finish is acidic/bitter with a lingering taste of mediocre coffee. creamy mouth feel. medium to full bodied. 8/4/9/4/18=4.3

 on tap at papago...$6.00!!! wow!. its equally good in all aspects. the aroma seems to be amped a bit and the mouth feel is insane. super rich and creamy but some how it goes down so easily. 8/4/9/4/18=4.3

Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly lasting. Body is opaque black (flashlight tested), bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (coffee, roasted grain, husks), with a strong note of celery, light note of chalk. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter, slightly husky. Medium body, creamy texture, lively/soft carbonation, lightly alcoholic. Big aroma of cold, stale coffee grounds and celery...highly vegetal.  Ok balance but a shade too tart for my tastes, and somewhat husky finish.  Great appearance and mouthfeel, though.  I usually like HN brews, as well as coffee stouts (though not coffee itself), but man, this was undrinkable.  I actually *hope* its an off bottle.

Dark black body with a large rocky light brown head. Heavy coffee aroma with some chocolate and roasted malt. Strong coffee flavor, light caramel and chocolate and a bit of roasted malt in the ending. Medium full body with medium low carbonation with a smooth finish into lingering coffee bitterness.

Bottle courtesy after4ever. Pours opaque blackish brown with a dense and lacy tan head. Aroma of coffee dregs. My prevailing impression of this is more like carbonated coffee than like beer. Pine and espresso finish. Kinda one-dimensional.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown/black with dark tan head. Some mile lacing is evident.  Aroma is interestingly a mix of coffee, oak wood, and vanilla.  Very intriguing.  First sip.  Wow, chcolate and coffee hit with gusto.  The wood kicks in almost as fast and lasts throughout, almost too much, killing the coffee and chocolate flavors.  Continuing to drink, the wood flavors subside to blend in nicely with the rest of the flavors and balance out.  Feeling is medium.  The ending is acidic but the chocolate and coffee are very enjoyable as an aftertaste. Overall a very good brew, if it wasnt for the first shock feeling like i just put a piece of oak in my mouth to suck on, it would be even better.

Bottle. Pours amber black with pretty tall beige head. The aroma is full of obvious coffee, but it combines with an interesting bourbon-like woody vanilla tone and some chocolate to make it quite pleasant smelling. The flavor isnt as obnoxious about the coffee tones, though it is still quite distinct. Chocolate and wood notes keep it together quite well. It gets pretty acidic toward the finish, but in a refreshing way, with some oak and berry notes. I must say, I was pleasantly surprised with this one. Yum.

Bottle into mug, purchased at Frugal MacDougals,  Nashville.  Nice looking stout, with a sizeable medium brown and creamy head over opaque ruby black beer.  Rich dry coffee ground aroma punctuated by burnt wood qualities.  Wow, the coffee in the flavor hits right away, right when it hits the tip of the tongue, before the flare-up of carbonation even has a chance to foam in the mouth.  This is true to its name: it even as the acidic roast aftertaste of Lavazza on the sides.  Besides the espresso, this has a light caramelly sweetness and malt character that rides the foamy carbonation and leaves just a little bit of sweetness for the finish.  Wonderful.  I dont know how a beer of this ilk could taste better.  Its not as complex as the recent spate of "breakfast" stouts, but as a straightforward coffee stout, this is top-tier; this is maybe the highest score I could see myself giving for a beer of this type.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a deep black with small tan head.  Aroma of coffee beans.  Nice thick body, really big mouthfeel.  Palate of coffee with some dark chocolate and roasted malts.  Really tasty brew out the The Land of the Rising Sun!

Bottle at Redlight Redlight. Dark brown, almost black pour, light brown edges. Small, mocha head. Could be the way it was poured though. Poured too cold, had to let it warm up a bit. Nose of chocolate covered espresso beans, dark malts, cocoa powder and dairy creamer. Flavor is very similar, would have liked a bit more chocolate though in this part of the beer. Espresso is very powerful, wonderfully done. Creamy palate, medium bodied. Sweet ending, pleasing and leaves you wanting another sip. I would have guessed around 6% ABV, so that part is very well hidden. Good stuff!

This beer was terrible.   Soy saucy with a horrible coffee taste.  Wouldnt touch another bottle of this stuff.   Oily dark black pour, didnt look horrible, and while the aroma didnt show how bad this beer was gonna be it sure didnt show much appeal.  But the flavor killed it instanly, took away any hope of a good or even descent beer.

(Bottle, thanks OSLO and Guerde) Pours black with a brown head. Roasted and light burned aroma of coffee beans up front but also some chocolate in the background. The usual strong coffee tones of parsley, green pepper (jalapenos) and gravel are all present. The flavour has a bit more complex malt composition with clearer chocolate notes but the coffee is still dominant. Some milk in the middle and the finish holds some dark fruit notes of raisins and figs. Hints of gravel. Light to medium bitter with a dry ending and some sour notes. Medium bodied. A quite good coffee stout but with the usual problem: a lack of complexity as the coffee dominates.

Huge nose of chocolate covered espresso beans.  Huge bakers chocolate note as well, with vibrant coffee grounds and roast hitting the palate.  I mean, it’s kind of just a straightforward coffee stout, but man, is it delicious.

Deep dark color with a quickly dissapating tan head.  Big coffee flavors and sweetness.  Nice after dinner beer.  Slight bittersweet chocolate flavors but coffee dominates and makes this one a little one dimensional.

Pours a solid black color with a thin tan head that lasts all of 10 seconds.  Odd aroma...obvious coffee flavors, but theres something funky/musty about it...after sitting here just testing the aroma for 5 minutes, I still cant figure out whether or not I like it.  Flavor is strong espresso coffee with hints of milk chocolate.  Burnt malts also take over late in the drink. Leaves a bitter, nutty aftertaste that really didnt jive with me.  Unless you like coffee...dont even bother with this one, as it is pretty one-dimensional.

Courtesy of after4ever and shared with after4ever and bitbucket. Pours dark brown to black with mocha head and decent lacing. The aroma is big with a bag full of ground Folgerss coffee beans with some faint roasted malts hidden behind. The taste, how is this not coffee?, it looks like coffee, it smells like coffee and it tastes like coffee. Midway a faint roasted to burnt maltiness shines through the coffee. It finsishes very coffee like. Its more coffee than stout with no sense of the ABV.

12-oz. Thanks, Footy! Black with dense, moussy, bubbly tan head and plenty of thick sheets of tan lace. Enormous coffee nose, almost to the point of sourness. Rich, thick, creamy body with tingly carb. Then comes an overbearingly powerful but still tasty sledgehammer of coffee flavor. Some roast, char, and chocolate underneath the tsunami of coffee. Bitter finish, but its a coffee bitter, not a hop bitter. Nice but out of balance.

Bottle: Poured the expected black color with a thin tan top.  The big aroma isnt much different than the filter bowl in the nasty ol coffee pot in my office ... thick and dirty with burnt coffee bean essence.  The flavor isnt much different ... this is a cold cup of your daddys coffee from the neighborhood diner ... thick with flavor, enough that youre rolling your tongue around in your mouth, convinced youll find some unground beans in there.  Yummy yummy in my tummy.  (#3172, 11/4/2007)

This is strange.  The aroma is slightly toffee, dirty socks, cocoa, and strange.  
Taste is very similar, but more unsweetened cocoa. I feel lines of cocoa!  I am a cocoa head (lame!).
Finish is slightly smooth with a diminishing harshness.  
Very decent and different.

Strong chocolate aroma with hints of coffee. Black in color with a quickly diminishing brown head. Very smooth chocolate bitterness throughout strengthening and developing some coffee character in bitterness in the finish. Super creamy palate.
Pours pitch black with a khaki head.Huge espresso beans aroma with some chocolate.Flavor was roasted coffee, sweet with some bitterness mixed in.This finished off espresso and dry.

Bottle from State Line.  Jet black pour with 1-finger dark brown head; definitely one of the darkest brown heads Ive ever seen.  Complex aroma of heavy coffee, dark chocolate, jalapeno oils...very much like the aroma of Bells Java.  The taste is roasty chocolate malt, coffee, dark chocolate, and jalapeno oil.  Dense, very complex palate that is dominated by coffee, but has wonderful chocolatey notes throughout.  This one is outstanding.
Bottle courtesy of slob.  Pours dark brown with a thin off white head.  Smells of lots of upfront coffee, some hints of molasses but not much else.  Tastes of bitter coffee.  Pretty one dimensional.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2008 Pours thick as oil, leaving a little head.  It looks rich, dark, and slightly intimidating.  The smell tells me differently.  It is rich, malty, and almost overpoweringly coffee.  The taste is about the same, full bodied, with an added touch of chocolate that lingers for a good while on the back of my throat.  It is a great beer for a cold evening.

POurs black, with a very small light brown head.  Smells of monster fresh coffee grounds, chocolate, and nutty malts.  Very inviting smelling.  Liked it.  Full-bodied, the flavor was coffee of course, but more toned down and balanced in the flavor.  i was expecting a coffee attack from the way it smelled.  There was some creamy dark chocolate hat seemed to give it some complexity and balance.  The finish was creamy and mostly chocolate roast, with the coffee too.  Really no signs of bitterness which was good for this beer.  i dug this one from these guys.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2007 12 oz bottle.   Black in color with a dark tran head.  Aroma is very roasty- espresso and ashy, with some burnt sugar and molasses.  Taste is coffee (espresso), tons of chocolate and moderate roast, medium bodied with caramel and molasses and a lingering  roasted bitterness.

Bottle Pours midnight black with a hint of ruby when held up to the sun. Big, wispy, light brown head with good retention. Smells like a double cappuccino. A hint of chocolate, but coffee is the dominant theme here. The flavor is that of a moderately sweet, skim-milk latte thats pretty much the story. Medium-bodied and very creamy with feather-soft carbonation. Espresso, chocolaty, dry finish. Cheers to SoLan for the bottle!
Pours a dark black color with a very thin tan head. Almost no carbonation. Huge hints of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, and candied sugar. Finishes with a thick coffee taste on the tongue.

11.2oz bottle. Black with a creamy medium sized tan head. Nice coffee aroma in this one, to go along with a mild roasted malt nose. A bit of an ashtray kind of smell as well, but not enough to detract from the overall aroma. The dark roasted malt comes on a bit more in the flavor, with the coffee now taking a back seat. Some cocoa and a bit of vanilla round out the flavors. Very enjoyable.

Pours completely black with a small tan head. Its a very strong aroma with a licorice/pruney but almost cleaning-product kind of flavor.  And then a strong charcoal/roast/cigarette smoke coffee bean aroma.  Its strong, sweet, definitely coffee but it also gets weird and over-the-top with some weird aromas. Taste actually starts off kind of watery and empty but on the back end there is coffee and that cigarette smoke roasty coffee thing.  Kind of an oily mouthfeel but otherwise easily drinkable. Kind of weird, I like it a lot but then half way through each sip I am like this is  weird and not so good. 11.2oz bottle, Delerium snifter/tulip cross glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle sampled Pours jet black with a light brown head.Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, and a hint of smoke. Flavor is full bodied and complex with coffee, roast, chocolate and some vanilla notes and has a bitter chocolate finish. An excellent stout
Pours a deep black with a sizeable caramel head.  Smells like a roasted black cup of espresso.  Very sweet and malty.  Flavors of chocolate and espresso predominat.  Sugary and sweet.  Yummy brew.

12 oz bottle from WLV Chicago.  Opaque black with creamy, medium beige head.  Aroma is strongly coffee with roasted malt and grows much stronger and nicer as it warms.  Flavor is less coffee in flavor with a more fruity chocolate flavor taking over but the coffee flavor is still there.  Body is full and creamy.  A nice coffee stout.

A cool night, playoff baseball, monday night G-men football, and hopefully a good brew. Wow! Hige foamy dark brown head. Maybe the darkest head i have seen.  Nose is like a starbucks esspresso with of the physical heat. All coffe, roasted goodness.  Taste has that coffe bite, but I mean that as a complement. Nice touch of smoke, and lingering dark chocolate.  Like a fine belgian choclate to taste with an italian espresso. This is exactly what comes to mind when I heard espresso stout. Quite nice indeed! If I knew this was so good, I would have tried to get more. VER BIG THANKS to Dan from oak tree, I loved this.
rerate-later in the beer... There is even a very nice complentary cream aspect as well, truly a joy, this brew!

Nearly black with a moderate, but lasting, tan head. Heavy isles of lace. Heavy roasted malt and dark (90+%) chocolate aromas dominate. Pretty much what I would expect, if someone were to pass me an espresso stout. Some hints of nougat as I sniff more deeply, but a pour coffee and malt aromas that work for me in this one. Quite acidic from the coffee and dark malts. Roasted malts, burnt almonds and dark chocolate covered espresso beans all in the flavors. The high acidity effects both the feel and the flavor and knocks them each down a touch. Finish returns to some sweeter malt and some fig flavors. Linger is dry and has just a touch of charcoal. This seems to beg for some roasted meat. Time to fire up the smoker.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2007 Bottle: Pous black with just a hint of light at the edge of glass.  I am not a huge espresso fan.  Tight beady tan/brown head, a bit rocky and wavy.  Pretty in glass.  Nose is of acidic coffe and anareobic compost turning.  Ugh.  I viewed this beer with some wariness since my red rice experience was so woeful.  It was MartinTs stories that made me give Japan another try.   Upfront this is too bitter for me.  Mid body is where it turns around to something a bit more pleasant.  Legs are sticky and build upon themselves.  they look like clouds on the side of the glass. I would like to try the stout alone without this espresso baggage getting in the way.  Coffee in the morning.....not with my beer.

(33cl bottle) Black body topped by a small-but-persistent brown head that leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is medium sweet, coffee/roast, some cream, light burnt.  Taste is medium sweet, strong coffee, roast, some burnt, light chocolate, raisin.  Creamy medium-full body, light effervescence, acidity.

Very dark (almost black) brown color with very little head - rousing gives a dark tan head.  Aroma is real nutty and has a sharp espresso note.  Creamy palate.  Nuttiness is in the taste, but a main flavor is the rich espresso, which is stronger through the finish, where a good deal of the roast in the flavor lies.  Another good Hitachino brew.

Pours a jet black color, some hints of mahogony on the edges.  Aroma is not subtle in the least, coffee dominated.  Some roasted grains, but coffee is the order of the day.    There is a hint of smoke, like a campfire aroma.  Flavor is more of the expected, rich bitter coffee, with the slightest notes   Almost like the less couthe version of Beer Geek Breakfast.

Bottle:  Huge roasted coffee aroma with moderate dark chocolate and faint burnt notes.  Pours a dark brown, virtually black, with no transparency and a small brown head that diminishes to a small ring around the edges of the glass.  The flavor starts with a big dose of dark chocolate with some faint caramel.  The finish has lots of roasted coffee, some burnt bitter flavors, and faint vanilla.  Full bodied with light carbonation.

Coffee grounds on the nose, hints of vanilla that fade into chocolate, roasty.  Pours very dark brown pretty much black, with a dense brown head.  This looks great.  Coffee all the way, roasted coffee beans, slightly burnt flavor, hints of smoke, creamy vanilla, slightly oily on the palate, which i like in a stout.  Theres a slight sourness, like in a cup of coffee you let get cold.  This is a great beer.

Pours opaque with a thin brown head. Smokey roasted aroma with hints of tar. Espresso all the way with some chocolate lingering. Very well balance. Mouth feel was a little thin for a stout. Overall a great brew!!!
Pours out jet black with a small lacing brownish head. Aroma of espresso and roasted malt. Complex and full mouthfeel with espresso, chocolate, roasted malt and slight hop on the finish. Good work!

Strong cold burnt coffee. I like it. After smelling the beer, I thought the stout would be lost. Quality stout characteristics are there.  Vanilla on the tip of the tongue. Bitter finish. Half way through my serving I felt it needed something else. I added 3 spoons of mocha ice cream to everyones serving. It was outstanding. ;) Rating is pre-ice cream experience.

As black and opaque as oil; a rich lacing beige head recedes slowly as the beer warms; aroma of -surprise!- coffee,  well-made espresso anyways, some smoky malts and some green (fuggles?)type hops adding dimension, as well as a nice nutty flavor with hints of bittersweet chocolate and licorice.  Perhaps a tad overpowering in the finish, but nonetheless a classy stout.
Dark brown with a big thick brown head. Aroma of rich coffee and dark chocolates. Flavor is pretty roasty with lots of coffee flavor. Burnt finish. Pretty drinkable.

Good strong sweet chocolaty aroma with a citrusy hops quality.  Rich foamy head with a good thick body.  Dark chocolate brown colors.  Flavors of dark bitter chocolate, coffee, and slight sweet dabs.  Thick and rich on the palate with a continuing duration of some developing complexity.  A great dessert beer and one of the best coffee beers Ive had so far.  Very good.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2007 Bottle from West LakeView Liquors, im not sure how they got this but .. hey its WLV.  Pours a beautiful dark brown black with a tall beige head.  Chocolate nutty earthy slightly grassy, smoky, and peaty.  Ill change that slightly to very.  Those notes are dominating the nose as it warms.  Lots of roasted and burnt coffee flavors with dark fruits a bit of alcohol and all that peat.  Underneath those dark flavors the peat is becoming very green like a plant and almost sour with a touch of citrus. The sweetness bitterness and acidity are fighting for dominance all over my tongue.  Finishes with a very dry grassy chocolate.  Complex and interesting.

Bottle: Opaque black pour with a creamy brown head. Has an extremely robust coffee aroma. Smells like coffee beans covered in dark chocolate, with plenty of roast, peat, and a hint of smoke. Creamy slick mouth feel with mild/smooth carbonation. One of the best beers to have captured a coffee flavor. Has an extremely fresh and natural deep roasted bean flavor. Theres tons of dark chocolate in there, along with tobacco, smoky peat, burnt currants & raisins followed by a solid coffee-ish, smoked bitterness in the finish. A rich, coffee-filled Stout experience.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a medium head. Good lacing. Aroma of coffee, dark roasted malt and a little milky sweetness. Heavy bitter coffee flavor overtakes the moderate sweetness. More than any other coffee stout/porter Ive tasted, this is just for coffee lovers. Mmm-mmm.

12oz bottle, brand new to Omaha.

Pours a deep black, with only the slightest hints of ruby peeking through the edges. The head peeks at a quarter of an inch, and fades quickly to a wispy swirling head, leaving behind a thin webbing of lace.

Smell; the espresso really comes through right away. Very roasty, alomst charred coffee at first, but then fades a little to some chocolate and molasses.

Taste; as with the aroma the coffee hits right away, and for a litle while its hard to pick out the other flavors. As it warms though the coffee fades just enough to get some chocolate, molasses and raisins. The finish is all bitter dark roasted malts and coffee beans.

Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with a light smooth carbonation, and the drinkability is good.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Bottle at the Brickskeller.  Black.  Very thin tan head, with a glint of ruby showing through at the bottom.  Fairly rich aroma of fudge and vanilla, dark bread made with molasses, and ashy espresso grounds.  Hint of burnt caramel on tart apples.  Taste is preditably acrid.  Soapy bitterness leads in the fashion of expired americano.  Very burnt, but not smoky, with quiet acid citrus tones.  The stout malts are sturdy underneath, and come valiantly close to balancing this.  Absence of lactose suggestions makes it a bit more palatable.  A slow, painful flowering of burnt butterscotch after swallowing, and just a slight hit of mint.  Medium bodied, slightly acidic with mild carbonation.  Astringent.  Coffee has been integrated far more tastefully than this, but its also not the worst example.

Bottled.  Poured a lovely shade of black with a medium cap of tan head that receded after a minute or so.  The aroma picked up a whole bunch of medium-roasted coffee and espresso with sweet chocolate and coffee undertones.  The flavor had a whole bunch of bitter coffee and espresso throughout, leaving a lenghty bitter coffee finish.. rather one-dimensional, but quite tasty!  Medium + bodied and bitter, with a nice underlying sweet balance.  Good stuff!
What a great aroma on this one, definite coffee.  The palate reveals a fairly robust brew, not in any way light, and actually finishes with quite pleasing vanilla. Very good stuff.

Bottle. Black pour. Almost like a black hole - no light escapes from this thing! The small tan head that accompanied this faded rather quickly. Aroma is coffee, tar, mint, vanilla, molasses and burnt brownies. Almost a burnt BBQ sauce aroma as well. taste is pure coffee with dark chocolate, molasses, soft vanilla, and sweet malts. Burnt caramel coming through in spots too. Body is medium-full to full. Oily in spots. Carbonation tingly but not too effervescent. Ends with more strong coffee notes, dark chocolate, tar, menthol, burnt brownies and molasses. Very nice stuff! This is delicious, really!

Bottle. Pours tar, tan head. Aroma is chocolate, pine, vanilla, coffee, molasses, anise, bark. Flavor is coffee, vanilla, bark, pine, molasses, anise, chocolate, oily mouth feel. More like an imperial stout.

11.2oz bottle, Brickskeller.  Pous a very dark brownish-black color; medium brown head with good retention and fine-bubbled lacing.  Tons of bittersweet chocolate and espresso in the aroma; very bittersweet; cocoa and a slight milky tartness.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: velvety, bitter chocolate upfront; mouthcoating, light carbonation; intense chewiness; chocolatey stout with a huge emphasis on bittersweet and milk chocolate; becomes creamier and softer at mid-palate.  Lengthy, bitter chocolate and cocoa finish, ending dense and slightly dry.

From a 12oz bottle via footy. Intense, perfumed espresso, bean, oak and vanilla aroma. Strong, rich, acidic, fresh earth, roasted carob and bits of spice. Real, delicious strong coffee aroma. Nice. Pours a pitch black, with oily mahogany fringes and supple, silky head in stained hickory. Inviting. A pretty typical middle stout body carries a particularly expressive and delicious coffee flavor. It has to have one of the most forward coffee flavors Ive ever had in a beer. Its coffee first and then malt, yet with some tremendous blending of the two. Theres a great interplay between the salty, bright roast of the malt and the acidic, fruity sweetness of the coffees higher essences. Resplendent. Theres some dust off of the grounds, and a bit of the syrupy sticky resin that comes from a pot of Turkish coffee, heavily seasoned with Turbinado. In the middle salty sea grasses and drying oak. Man, this is good. Finishes on a light crisp note of mint chocolate and leaf. Bright, friendly and percolating. Body is near perfection for the style. Not overly heavy, instead carrying the flavors on just the right amount of sugar and totally undetectable alcohol. If you love coffee, youll love this beer.

From the bottle this poured an inky brown/black that was topped by a heavy lacing, thick & creamy light brown head.  The aroma is chocolatey espresso with a quiet pine hopping.  Creamy mouthfeel.  It tasted of espresso, chopped nuts, chocolate, [pine, and a drop of alcohol.  Nice blending of flavors.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Lakeview Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

Bottle.  Dark stout pour with a filmy brownish head.  Smells like coffee, chocolate, and soy sauce.  There are some hops in there too, and some alcohol.  Not too bad.  Flavor is similar, but with an acrid smokiness.  A little too astringent.  This is a good beer, but I have no idea why its a 3.9.

Thanks to egajdzis for grabbing this...
Appears a near black, dark brown with a clumpy, light tan head that fades into a mild film and cap. Spotty lacing is left around the glass.
Smell is of coffee grounds, caramel, nuts, vanilla, cocoa, mocha, and roasted malt.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas with a bitter, roasted wood-like flavor coming through.
Mouthfeel is slightly tart, nutty, and dry.

Bottle from SL, highly anticipated based on slobs reviewing this before me as it sat in my fridge for quite a while. Pour was deep black, slow developing tan-chocolate head, but it thinned to a circlular ring quickly although retained itself as such quite well (interesting). Lacing was weak. The aroma was rich dry coffee, a touch of chocolate, really quite simple. The flavor started out a bit bitter, disappointingly so, bitter rough coffee. However, temperature was absolutely critical on this one, with warming immense improvements, bitterness less prominent yet not subtle, quality of the coffee flavors started to work, chocolate playing a nice subtle supporting role. Definitely doesnt approach a sweet coffee stout, yet the dry bitterness (turned more gentle with warmer temps) does seem to work well. I tend to like the Breakfast Stout on up in terms of sweetness, so this is a notch below (or more in appearance), yet pretty nice, nonetheless. Mouthfeel is much lighter than those two, silky, slightly acidic, quite drinkable for 7.5% ABV.
12oz bottle. Good choclate aroma. Black body with chocolate milk color head, Coffee flavor with some coco a good mix. Dry coco on the palate good beer.

(Bottle)  Pours an opaque black body with a medium-sized brown head.  Strong roasted coffee beans in the nose.  Flavor of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, toffee, and vanilla extract with a smooth, silky mouthfeel.

Black body with an orange head. The aroma is very strong coffee with some nice fresh cut grass. There is also a little bit of caramel. The taste has some rich notes of espresso with some cream. There is also some hints of lactose, but maybe that is my imagination. A rich, creamy body. Hitachino nails another winner. I would buy more of their beers if they were a little cheaper.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2007 Name: Espresso Stout
Date: 08/08/2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Roadtrip

black, fine brown head, 
strong smokey coffee and dark chocolate aroma, 
rich roasted flavor, strong dark chocolate character, lots of espresso bitterness blended with a dark malt tartness, 
just too much of the black coffee bitterness
-------- />
Name: Espresso Stout
Date: 09/08/2007
Mode: bottle
Words: cellar party

bitterness is tempered but replaced by a dark malt tartness, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.7/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: *4
Black color with a medium tan head.  Powerful espresso aroma.  Wow... outrageous espresso and dry/bitter chocolate flavor.  Moderately bitter roasted malt.  Friggin good!
bottle. smells like morning coffee. mild and a little bland. pretty good.  i had it along with a bunch of other beers, but i think i liked it quite a bit.
wow, i didnt know this was rated so high.  it did have a huge coffee aroma and flavor. it was surprisingly good.  chocolate and coffee.  smooth mouthfeel and full bodied.

Pours an opaque black with a nicely-lacing wispy froth of light brown head.  Aroma of fresh roasty coffee and dark chocolate with some sweet toffee notes.  Body starts with a dark caramel malty sweetness and good viscosity along with fresh roasted and lightly bitter espresso toward a smooth, lingering dark chocolate finish.  Nicely balanced and a very tasty coffee stout.

Intense coffee nose that blows off a little and leaves a choclatey, rich more imperial stoutish aroma, with coffeeish notes, some hops and a touch of alcohol.  Good medium bodied stout character.  Big, but not too big.  Coffee is present and well integrated but not the only element of the flavor.  Well done.

11.2 oz bottle from Greens on Ponce.  I was more than pleasantly surprised by this one.  A tremendous coffee aroma, tar-black color, and, of course, a BIG coffee/expresso flavor.  Alcohol is very well hidden and palate is incredibly smooth for a big stout like this.  Man, I could have one of these at breakfast every morning!  Its that good.  Highly recommend it.

Bottle from State Line.  Big, big espresso nose.  High praise coming: one of the top two or three coffee stout noses Ive sampled, and probably the closest to actual espresso before taking on a more chocolatey tone.  Opaque pitch pour with a dark brown head, soapy and foamy and excited.  Initial taste is pure espresso - less bitter than the actual stuff, but the ring of it is the same.  Roast, chocolate, and even the dregs at the bottom of the tiny cup, with lesser contributing notes of vanilla and faint bourbon.  Bittersweet and burned, big league taste in session form (7.5% excluded).  Alcohol is very well integrated and non-intrusive.  Velveteen feel and a medium, still thickish body.  Aftertaste is dry and slightly woody.  Clean and really yummy!  Ive liked this brewery for some time, and this is another treasure.

11.2oz bottle, no date from Johns Grocery.  Almost black with a 1/2 finger tan head, fades to a ring before long.  Lots of coffee (plus the acidity that comes with it), roasted malts and chocolate (both milk and dark).  A touch of salty soy sauce was in there as well. The flavor was quite roasty with a fair amount of acidity again, some dark and sweet milk chocolate and anise following through to a bitter chocolatey dry finish.  Alcohol was present, but never to the point of Medium creamy body with moderate carbonation.  This wasnt ungodly complex, but what was there is very good.  Glad to have had the chance to try this one.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Oily brown / black with pleasant bright brown "crema."  Aroma is very espresso with cocoa notes.  Taste is same as aroma with evenly biting bitterness in true espresso fashion.  $4/12oz
Beautiful dark brown body.  Bitter coffee aroma with a faint chocolate characteristic.  Ultra bitter body that killed the other flavors.

Pours black with a tan head that lasted.  Aroma was definitely heavy on coffee, with some hints of dark chocolate and toasted walnut coming through as well.  Flavor was an inital blast of both dark chocolate and dark roasted coffee, with a subtle hint of vanilla, which then yielded to a long lasting roasted coffee finish, a very good beer.

Black pour, slightly opaque around the edges with a nice sized, creamy light brown head.  Roasted coffee aroma.  Thick, full bodied and creamy mouthfeel.  Definitely a strong coffee stout.  Primarily roasted coffee, espresso, nuttiness and woodsy/oak undertones.  Long, bitter finish.  Alcohol well hidden.  Pretty good, but I think a bit overrated.  Of course, Im not a huge coffee fan so that may play a part.
This is an excellent coffee beer.  Full coffee aroma, but cocoa is also present.  Very dark brown, and not especially thick.  Flavor is coffee as well, with a cocoa powder-like grittiness.

Sampled from 12-oz bottle at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, Minnesota. Pours an opaque pitch dark brown brew with a thin tan head that quickly dissolves to a tan ring. Aroma of distinct coffee grounds, dark toasted malt, dark chocolate, with a touch of toffee. Taste is thick, full bodied, light carbonation with dark toasted malt and coffee flavors.
