The coffe taste is overpowering of all flavors. Finish has a dark bittersweet chocoalte aftertaste that stick around for a while. Taste from beginning to finish.

New arrival at Johns Grocery in Iowa City. 330 ml bottle served at cellar temperature. Poured an opaque black color. Head was thick and cocoa colored with good retention and lacing. I didnt detect more than subdued coffee in the aroma. Smelled more like milk chocolate to me. There was also an occasional whiff of green chili pepper. Perhaps my olfactory lobe is still overwhelmed with glee from the Ølfabrikken porter I tried a few minutes ago. Sweet and chocolatey with coffee coming out more in the flavor. There was moderate roasty bitterness throughout which strengthened toward the end and lingered with a distinct coffee aftertaste. Good beer.

330ml bottle shared courtesy of egajdzis. Poured a dark brown color with an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of coffee grounds, espresso, vanilla, roast, and chocolate. Tastes of coffee, earthy, roast, chocoalte, and vanilla. I want coffee in any beer that has espresso in its name and this one didnt disappoint me (especially in the aroma).

Poured a deep, dark brown color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of espresso, roast, vanilla cream, nuts, chocolate, and wood, very nicely balanced, with the roast not being too strong.  Taste of chocolate, with roasted malt, java beans, nuts, vanilla, wood, and a dry, woody finish.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2007 [Bottle] Pours black with a dark tan head.  Aroma is very strong of coffee, there is also caramel, and some brown sugar after it warmed.  As far as the taste goes, there is no surprise, it is mainly just very potent coffee.  There is also a little chocolate and very little bitterness.  Good mouthfeel, just the right amount of cabonation.  At the end, the flavor of coffee (again is strongest), chocolate and maybe a little vanilla lingers forever.  Completely dominated by coffee but pretty enjoyable and well done.

Thanks to egajdzis for bringing this over to a tasting.  Porus a deep dark brown/black with a medium bubbly/creamy tan head.  Aroma of espresso, caramel, chocolate, ripe banana and some roast sweet malts.  Flavor of caramel, some lightly roasted sweet malts, coffee grind burps.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2008 Holy moly, it lives up to its name. Pours black w/ a full, bronze colored creamy froth. Superb head retention. Froth reduces to a thick, sticky, creamy lace. The aroma alone is worth buying this brew. Heavy, heavy, heavy espreso. Its so heavily roasted it smells like chipotle peppers hot off the grill. I really have to say WOW! at this point. LOL. Full nectar w/ creamy residual effers. Awsome! Im amazd at this flavor profile. This brew excedes my expectations. Its not sweet at all. HUGE roasted espresso flavors dominate like the tripods in War of the Worlds. Big balancing malts provide the life sustaining backbone to push this brew into overdrive and through the stratosphere. The finish is long and lasts forever w/ perfect bittering. Overall: no words can describe the emotional experience this brew evokes. This is on my list as one the few brews that have left such an impression on my psychi. Good job amigos!  Hghy recommended.

Appearance: Pours a pitch black body with a full, rich tan-colored head. Alright, this looks pretty solid. 

Smell: A very aromatic, expressive nose of heavily roasted coffee beans. While there is a bit of roasted malts and dark, dark chocolate, its mostly all cold coffee.

Taste: Powerful coffee taste through and through. Only a teensy bit of malty sweetness manages to get past it as does a very faint spiciness. The finish is packed with roasty bitterness and lingers incessantly.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Smooth, nearly oily mouthfeel. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Good for you, Hitachino. Espresso Stout is a beer that deserves polite, though not particularly raucous applause. Lets keep our heads, folks.
Bottle: Pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma, espresso, coffee, roasted notes, spice. Flavor, very roasty, dry bitter chocolate, with a nice dose of coffee/espresso. This was very nice.

Very dark brown with tiny brownish/orange head and no lacing. Aroma was weak, light chocolatey malts and coffee. Flavor was bland, and a little bit like sour coffee. I dont mind coffee flavored beers, this was just not well done and too simple. I was a little upset about the $3.99 I spent on it. Best thing about it is the nice graphics on the label.

Dark Dark Brown Color with Dark Tan Head. Sweet Rich Cocoa Aroma. Thick and Creamy...Wonderful Flavor Notes of Rich Chocolate and Dry Bitter Espresso, Vanilla and Perhaps Just a Hint of Bourbon. Tastes Like a Fine Chocolate You Hope to Receive During the Holiday Months..Dry Cocoa and Coffee Roast Finish. Wonderfully Smooth and Well Balanced.  Amazing Stout  Home Run for Hitachino.

Rating #100.  Wanted to do something big for the milestone, but instead of raiding my Trappist reserves, I decided to go with a beer that had few ratings, and belonged to a style that I enjoyed.  Pours a pitch black hue with a very small tan head.  Giant aroma, highlighted by roasted coffee beans and a sweet malt that reminded me a bit of the Lacto Stout.  Bittersweet chocolate and dark, roasted coffee dominate the palate as the beer is consumed.  Not too thick, easily enjoyable.  A great beer, but just lacks enough complexity to give Founders Breakfast/Ky. Breakfast Stouts a run.  Avoid, so I can buy more!

Bottle from Rivers Bend. Poured black color with a large frothy brown head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Solid roasted coffee and chocolate malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Heavy roasted balanced flavor with a heavy chocolate  bittersweet finish of long duration. This is a standout beer.

syrupy black pour with a large orange/brown head.  aroma is loaded with coffee.  flavor is bitter with chocolate, maple syrup and of course coffee.  full bodied.  nice velvety palate.  i really like this brewery.  aftertaste is like a hersheys bar.

Medium sized light brown head, excellent retention with a nice stringy, thin sagging lace. Black color with some faint brown edging showing when light struck. Tart nose, chocolate, plenty of coffee, spent grains, some lacto? and toffee notes. Body is medium with an oily palate, carbonation is soft. Rich chocolatey, coffee flavors with notes of toffe, light fruits, cocoa, bittersweet chcolate. Tangy, house yeast flavors? something sorta spicey not sure what to makle of it though it does get yer attention. Burnt and black malt flavors as well as caramel. Lots going on here. Dry, roasty, coffee laden finish that lasts. An interesting brew indeed. Bottle procured at State line liquors. Yummy!

A very dark brown beer with plenty of coffee in the nose. Plenty of roasted malt in the taste to compliment the coffee.  This is a very well done stout.  It doesnt have the oatmeal piece that the Founders Breakfast does, but nonetheless a very solid and enjoyable brew.

Pours a black color with a brown head.  Aroma is huge of coffee with roasted malts, chocolate, and a hint of sweet malts. But this is almost all coffee in the aroma.  Just as the nose suggested the flavor is mostly coffee with undertones of chocolate and sweet malts.  By far my favorite of the Hitachino Nest.  You definetely have to be a coffee lover to enjoy this beer.

Bottle. Coffee. Lots and lots of cold press coffee on the nose. A bit of roasted malt and alcohol, but lots of coffee. Pours rich motor oil black with a quickly disappearing khaki head. Flavor was coffee, malt, alcohol and coffee. Medium bodied. One of the most coffee loaded beers Ive ever had. Too over the top if you ask me. The flavors werent well integrated.

I like strong coffee and I like this beer!  Very comparable to Founders Breakfast stout, possibly a little stronger on the coffee and possibly a little more on the coffee acidic bite .  Not much in either case.  Coffee with a little sugar please, good beer.

Bottle sample at Union Beer Trade Tasting, NYC in September, 2006. This event was apparently the world premiere for this beer. Pours deep brown with a very still body and no head. Aroma of freshly roasted and ground coffee - very nice. Flavour has lots & lots of coffee, backed by cocoa, malt and a hint of Tootsie Rolls(!), with a long, lingering finish. Body is a little light, but otherwise, this is DAMN good!

A dark brown, near black, opaque beer with a light brown head. Foamy at first leaving a few scant islands of foam on a dark brown sea. Strong coffee scent, light malty sweetness barely peeks through. Same in the flavor, a definite coffee flavor, this was appropriately named. There is a malty sweet middle and a tangy follow that round out this delicious offering from Kiuchi-san and is another fine example of why I think he is one of, if not "the" most innovative brewer in Japan.

You better like coffee.  Pours black, with a large dark tan head.  Aroma is pretty much like stuffing a coffee bean in your nose.  very roasted, very strong coffee.  Flavor is similar, strong, strong coffee.  Mildly earthy.  Very good, but nearly all coffee.  Finish ws toasted herbel hops and mildly bittersweet.  Hides the alcohol very well.  Full body. I love coffee, so I loved this beer.  If you arent a fan of black coffee you wont be a fan of this beer, either.

Instead of drinking this beer, if espresso really floats your boat, you could simply grind up half a pound of espresso beans, mix in some vodka and take it intravenously. There simply is no other beer that is more full on hardcore coffee. Mix in some brownies and vanilla (though barley noticable) and you have this beer. Caffeine freaks rejoice. 

Note label says Happy Valentine, but this beer may be made outside of valentine.
